concern:
title: Anyone else struggle with lab techniques?
Hey, Neuroscience Ph.D. candidate here. I work in a systems neuroscience lab. Therefore, one of the things you probably guess that we do are surgeries, except I could never learn how to do them. In short, the post-doc who taught me was not a very good teacher and the lab environment has not been the best for learning. I was taking so long to learn them that my PI basically said that the staff research scientist would do all my surgeries while I focused on building other skills. This has been probably one of the single biggest blows to my confidence as a researcher. A skill that I was sure I could learn. Everyone else in my cohort was able to learn them but me, and I cannot get over this. I hate being the only one who seems to not be able to do a very core thing in systems neuroscience. 

Any advice is welcome. I am trying my best to look past this, but it's hard. I am not particularly good at anything else. So, I am not bringing some other core skill to the lab that makes up for this deficiency.

dialogue.statement: Hello! It seems like you might have something on your mind. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's been going on or any thoughts you'd like to discuss. I'm here to listen and support you.

Hey, thanks for listening. I've just been feeling a bit frustrated with unclear instructions from my professors. It's like no matter how closely I follow the guidelines, there's always something that catches me off guard.
That sounds really frustrating, especially when you're putting in the effort to meet expectations. What do you think might be contributing to these unexpected challenges?

client(exploring): I'm not entirely sure, honestly. Maybe I'm not picking up on subtle hints or reading between the lines enough? But it just feels like the instructions should be clearer to begin with.

It sounds like you're feeling caught off guard and maybe even a bit overwhelmed trying to interpret these unclear instructions. What impact has this been having on your studies or how you feel about your courses?
Yeah, it's definitely been stressing me out. I end up spending a lot of time second-guessing myself and worrying about missing something important, and it's affecting how confident I feel in my work.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared detailed examples and expressed feelings of frustration and stress due to unclear instructions from professors. The therapist has successfully elicited the client's thoughts and feelings about this issue, showing empathy and understanding. However, the conversation has not yet delved into exploring the client's potential strategies or strengths in dealing with these challenges. Further exploration is needed to fully understand the client's perspective and to identify any preliminary steps towards addressing the issue.

I think reaching out to my professors and asking for clarification when I'm unsure could be a good start. It might also help to discuss these issues with classmates to see if they're experiencing the same thing and maybe work together to interpret the instructions better.

Reaching out for clarification and connecting with classmates sounds like a proactive way to address these challenges. How confident do you feel, on a scale from 0 to 10, about taking these steps to improve your experience and manage your stress?

concern:
title: Professor's instructions often unclear? What's the deal?
I keep running into this issue where instructors will often give vague instructions on assignments and I'm not sure what to do about it. Do I just need to get better at navigating vague teachers? Or is this not supposed to be happening?

___

**Exhibit A:**

For example, I just got my grade back for a programming project in which I was apparently not allowed to edit certain parts of the code that was provided. I got docked quite a few points for this mistake so I double checked the grading rubric and there is no mention of any restrictions on editing the prewritten code. I scroll down to the very bottom and of course, hidden in the middle of an FAQ section, is the warning to not edit prewritten code. Yes, I should probably be reading every single word of every piece of instruction just in case, but isn't the FAQ generally optional reading? Why is there crucial grading criteria in an FAQ section and but nowhere to be found in the actual "Grading Criteria" section?

___

**Exhibit B:**

Another professor, this same quarter, docked me for not formatting the output of a program in exactly the right way. The rubric does mention that "the output must be in the required format" but it didn't specify what the format is. While I was working on this assignment, I read through the whole rubric a couple of times and couldn't find any other mention of a "required format". When I turned it in, I added a note on canvas that basically read: "I wasn't sure what you meant by required format. Please let me know if there are any issues. I can send you the source code if you need to look at it for grading purposes".

She graded the assignment with a very dismissive response saying simply "Numerical output was not in the required format". I had to ask her again about this "required format" and she  responds with "There was a sample line of code provided in the PDF file". I look back at the instruction PDF and there is an example piece of code much later in the assignment that states "you ***may*** use fprintf() to output a ***desired*** format" but the wording does not suggest in any way that this ***is*** the ***required*** format above. The wording makes it seem like a completely unrelated suggestion or helpful tip rather than a strict requirement, especially since it appears many paragraphs after any mention of a ***required*** format.

___

Am I losing it? If this is happening in multiple classes in the same quarter then it must be me right? But I feel like there are *definitely* some huge communication issues going on. I'm not really sure what to think. Hopefully this post doesn't come off too ranty. I'm just not sure what to do. Why does this keep happening? Is interpreting vague instruction just a skill I need to develop? Or should I be talking to my teachers about this?

concern:
title: Physics, Biology: Dilemma on whether I should switch my major ft. mental health
TLDR is at the bottom as well as my questions. This turned out very long, I apologize.

To start out i would like to say this: I love physics, ever since i was in elementary school i've loved physics phenomena, lasers, optics and had marvelled at the fact that we can explain so much about the universe. I took physics as one of my Leistungskurse (elevated courses with more hours in German high schools), did my hs graduation exam in it and finished with an excellent score. I really did enjoy it all the way and our teacher was super chill and supportive, in general all my physics teachers were very cool and made our lessons fun with many very interesting experiments. It's a language that we can explore the universe in and that makes it very exciting.

So it's no wonder i went into university pretty determined on physics, however i didn't make my decision based on one specific job i wanted to do, but coming from a thirst for knowledge.

In high school, my strategy was to pay attention in lessons and thoroughly write everything down and take notes. I wasn't the kid that caught up to everything the teacher said in the lesson and when preparing for exams or revising I would sit and go through everything by myself. This was a very good method for me personally because i could understand the concepts and their connections in my own pace and understand things through my own methods. It might sound weird that the kid who was regarded as one of the top students sometimes couldn't have answered the most simple questions on a new topic, but that's how it was, i just needed the time.

But ever since the bridge courses before the semester i've been struggling. I'm told that it's normal for first years to feel like everyone around you knows everything and only you are behind, but after a semester the feeling is still strongly there. I will admit I have made many mistakes, like starting the more in-depth math courses from the beginning and not revising after every other class. As the workload was immense, I barely slept in the first two months. This in turn lead to me barely being able to stay awake in class and tutorials. I acknowledge these mistakes and have already made adjustments to lighten the load.

Now, as for uni, the sheer amount of stuff we have to learn, on our own, at my university -which might be a normal amount, given this is university- is a lot to approach with my method. We were advised to study in groups and do our weekly exercise sheets together, and though I had some moments of victory where I could do one exercise, mostly it consisted of the other students talking about the topic like they understood it really well while I sat there and listened for any coherent crumbs of info and sometimes asked for a tip on how to proceed. Admittedly this was not a good method and I found some people closer to my pace who I could study with, but they weren't always there or we ended up sitting with our sheets well into dusk. So by the time I got home I was tired and turned to my phone for an escape lot of the time. Now I know that delaying catching up with our topics is a bad strategy due to time and the amount of material. But it seems like it's good if i take the time to catch up and revise by myself, also because the way things are explained in class don't always work for me.

As for the social aspect of it, there wasn't really a time where I felt that I fit in or that I have much in common with anyone there except maybe when we were talking about art. I also found myself rethinking my choices a lot. I missed my friends and my family immensely and honestly struggled to feel human at times. I haven't really been able to find the motivation to study beyond the desire to get through another week.

When I look into what kind of scripts belong to classes in later semesters, the topics seem interesting, still it's pages of text with about the same amount of equations which i'm sure contain so much interesting and informative stuff.. Still right now that aspect of "woah that's so cool" is kind of missing. Maybe that will come later, i figure when we get to more stuff that's beyond mechanics.

I suspect I might also have ADHD and may be nd in other ways which i will get checked out with a professional if i am able to. So to be clear i'm not self diagnosing, but i'm constantly reading up on these subjects and honestly everything seems to make so much more sense.

So that's a little bit on how I have felt about my first semester of physics.

The thing is, beside physics, I'm also very interested in biology. Our university has a small biology faculty and it seems to be much cozier than 200-300 people in physics. The longer i've thought about it, the more i find myself interested in life and the parts of science that deal with living things. I took biology as a Basiskurs (a course that has less lessons and is more simplified compared to Leistungskurs) and I loved it. At school i've done several presentations in both physics and biology (and ethics) and I loved doing those, I find it's so much fun to research things and share them with others in a way that's engaging and comprehensive. I watch science videos and listen to podcasts in my free time as well, like Scishow (both vids and podcasts) and books like The Selfish Gene (that i found super interesting and recommend!!), and generally beside physics, a lot of them have a lot to do with biology. I find that these pieces of media don't overwhelm me and i want to know more about them, in general all kinds of stuff that have to do with life feel like tangible things to me and they kind of fall into place in the big scheme of things. I hope i phrased that in a way that's understandable.

I will implement new strategies in the coming semester and am in the process of hopefully getting a private tutor. I'm determined to go through my second semester in physics and reevaluate things after, but the way things are looking for me mentally right now, i think going with something that is naturally and directly engaging and has a sense of novelty and many little rewards that are directly applicable (so: biology) would lighten the load for now. Going into uni i talked with some advisors from both faculties on doing two bachelors, they said it was possible but i should rather wait. I would even consider doing them one after another with no overlap (of course i'd have to start working a job too eventually, to afford rent and basic expenses, right now i have a very amazing scholarship and mainly my parent's support paying for that)

The direction that would unite like, almost if not all of my interests well (given my current level of being informed) would be neuroscience. I think it's just in the sweet spot between big stuff and small stuff -ie. humans between particles and the universe and it has that direct application to life that i'm looking for as well as physics and biology. My dad is a surgeon and he has inspired me a lot to look into things that have to do with humans and with medicine, and when we learned about the brain in bio in hs i was always like "heh i can't wait to learn more about this". So far it's been the most definite career that i could see myself pursuing in the area of science. I want to help people and i want to feel like i am needed.  
I still wish to pursue physics, because i love it after all and I Want To Understand Those Things!!!!(tm) also the experience and learned methods are definitely very valuable and give good prospects. I know it will remain a passion. But maybe it could be better to do it when I have the resources, support system that i also have control over, and maturity to do so.

TLDR: first semester of physics was a lot to handle partly because of inexperience and partly because it's A Lot, took a toll on me mentally. Implementing new and improved strategy for second semester, will see how things turn out. However, also want to do biology at one point, maybe doing it earlier would benefit my mental wellbeing more? Would love to combine both in future job, not sure of the road to there though.

Question to you: Have you had any experiences like this? Is it worth it to keep pushing? Will things change?  
Also: if you have experience starting out in physics and then going into biology later (maybe even not from a bachelors, like from a masters with overlap in bio or a job) how is that road?

Thank you kindly if you read this far and if you have any questions i'd gladly answer, I know my points are a little bit all over the place.

concern:
title: 6 Ways to Beat Procrastination in College
 

Many college students often have a problem with procrastination or putting tasks on the back burner. It could be you have procrastinated completing that term paper which is vital to your final grade, doing your laundry or cleaning your room. Procrastination can easily prevent you from achieving your full potential. While it can be a hard habit to overcome, there are certain ways you can beat procrastination.

1. Prepare a To-Do List

There’s a certain feeling of satisfaction that occurs when you check off a task on your to-do list. You should always try to prepare a list of tasks, school assignments, and other chores that need to be done. This helps you to stay on track and offers a confidence boost once you complete a task on the list.

* Make a Routine

One of the best ways to beat procrastination is to turn responsibilities into habits. By making habits, you will train your mind to be focused on completing a task during specific days or times. For instance, if you make a habit of doing your assignments in the evening, when that time comes, you are able to remember to do your homework.

* Divide Tasks into Smaller Pieces

If you have a long assignment, it helps to break it down into smaller pieces. The assignment will also seem less daunting if tackled in small bits. If you have a long essay to write, start with just preparing the essay outline. You can then write the body paragraphs in the coming days and edit the essay on a different day. This way, you are able to enhance creativity while increasing your attention span.

* Get Help

If you have an assignment that is secretly giving you nightmares and you can’t simply gather the courage to sit down and start working on it, you can ask for help. You can [**get help with your essay**](http://tutorsnest.com/), term paper, dissertation, and other assignments online.

* Switch off Your Phone

Your smartphone can be a great source of distractions when you’re doing an important task. You will always be tempted to check social media pages and notifications on your smartphone while working on an important school assignment. This eats into your productive time and drains your mental strength and focus. Try to switch off your phone for a couple of hours when you’re busy doing something important.

* Stay Focused on the End Goal

Whenever you feel like procrastinating, try to imagine the awesome feeling that you get when you reach the finish line. Think of the feeling of receiving your degree. That thought alone can be a great source of motivation to complete important tasks in college.

There you go – the top 6 tricks to avoid procrastination for college students. They all boil down to planning your tasks meticulously and using your time wisely.

dialogue.statement: Hello! What would you like to talk about today? I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey! I've been feeling kinda down and lonely since coming back home for the summer. Just trying to figure out how to deal with it.

Returning home can feel quite different, can't it? You're feeling down and lonely because the change in environment might not be what you expected or hoped for. What's been on your mind about this transition?

client: Yeah, it's been a big shift from being surrounded by friends all the time to being back home where I don't know many people. I guess I'm just struggling to find ways to stay connected and not feel so isolated.

It can be tough when such a big part of your social life suddenly changes. You're missing that connection with friends and feeling isolated because it's not as easy to find the same support network at home. What have you been doing so far to try and stay connected, or what kind of connection are you hoping to find?

I've been hanging out with a friend who lives nearby and we go to a club meeting once a week. It's nice but it doesn't fill up all the empty time, you know? I'm hoping to feel more engaged and not just waiting for summer to end.

statement.reasoning: The client's story has been elicited thoroughly, covering their feelings of loneliness and isolation, the transition from college to home, and the context of their social environment. The therapist has established rapport and understanding, explored the client's attempts to stay connected, and the essence of the client's concerns is clear. Moving to the Guiding phase is appropriate to strengthen motivation and evoke Change Talk about coping strategies.

dialogue.statement: Keeping busy and finding meaningful connections sounds important to you. It seems like you're seeking more engaging ways to fill your time and create a sense of fulfillment. How do you imagine your summer would look if you felt more connected and engaged?

client(guiding): I think if I felt more connected, I'd have a more balanced mix of spending time with friends, maybe picking up a new hobby, or just having things to look forward to regularly. It'd be nice to have plans that don't make the days feel so long and uneventful.

Having a mix of social time, hobbies, and exciting plans sounds like a fulfilling way to spend your summer. You're aiming for variety and activities that break away from monotony. What new hobby or activity are you curious about exploring to add that sense of engagement and anticipation to your days?

client(guiding): I'm kinda interested in learning how to play the guitar or maybe trying out some local art classes. Just something different to focus on, you know? I think having something new to work on might help break the routine a bit.

Trying something new like playing the guitar or taking art classes sounds like an exciting opportunity for growth and connection. These activities could bring a fresh perspective and energy to your summer. How confident do you feel about taking the first step towards exploring these interests?

client(guiding): I'm a bit nervous, to be honest. It's always kinda intimidating to start something new, but I'm also kinda excited about the idea. I think I just need to push myself to actually do it and see where it goes.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a desire for more engagement and connection through activities like learning guitar or taking art classes, indicating a specific change goal. They have expressed a mix of nervousness and excitement about starting these new activities, showing a shift towards Change Talk. The confidence level, while not explicitly numbered, suggests readiness to take the first steps despite some apprehension. The conversation effectively explored the discrepancy between their current and desired state and evoked Change Talk. It seems appropriate to move to the Choosing phase to develop concrete action plans. OARS feedback: The reflections helped deepen the client's exploration of interests, and open questions effectively guided them toward potential changes.

dialogue.statement: Your excitement about these new possibilities is inspiring. To make this happen, would you like to set a goal to either enroll in a local art class or start learning guitar by a certain date? We can also consider which small steps to take first. For example, you could research classes or watch beginner guitar videos online. How does that sound as a starting point, and what might be a useful first step for you?

client(choosing): Yeah, setting a goal sounds like a good idea. Maybe I could start by watching some beginner guitar tutorials online this week. It feels less intimidating to start in a low-pressure way like that. Then I could look up art classes near me and see if any catch my interest.

Watching beginner guitar tutorials online sounds like a fantastic and approachable first step. It allows you to explore at your own pace. Once you feel more comfortable, you could research local art classes to see what options are available. How about we set a goal for you to watch a few tutorial videos this week and check out art class options within the next two weeks? What potential barriers might you anticipate, and how can we plan to manage them together?

client(choosing): That sounds doable and setting a timeline helps me stay on track. I guess one barrier could be losing motivation if I don't pick it up quickly, or if the art classes are expensive or far away. Maybe having a backup plan or reminding myself it's about having fun could help keep me going. Could we maybe brainstorm some backup plans or ways to stay motivated if things don't go as planned?

Absolutely, having backup plans and motivation strategies can be incredibly helpful. If beginner guitar tutorials feel challenging, we could explore alternative resources like apps or short online courses. For art classes, perhaps consider free community workshops or online sessions if local classes are costly. How about setting small milestone goals and rewarding yourself for reaching them? This could keep the focus on enjoyment rather than pressure. What other backup plans or motivational techniques do you think might work for you?

client(choosing): I like the idea of using apps or short courses for guitar. And for art, online sessions sound like a good backup if I can't find anything nearby. Setting mini-goals and rewarding myself could definitely help keep things fun and light. Maybe even sharing progress with my friend who's nearby could be motivating too. What do you think about that?

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear goal of engaging in new activities like learning guitar and exploring art classes, along with a concrete action plan including watching beginner guitar tutorials and researching classes. They have also identified potential barriers such as losing motivation and proposed strategies like using apps, setting mini-goals, and involving a friend. The client has expressed commitment and readiness to take steps, indicating confidence in their plan. It's appropriate to move to the Terminating phase to support the client's independent execution of their plan and provide closure to this phase.

dialogue.statement: Sharing progress with your friend sounds like a wonderful way to maintain motivation and keep it enjoyable. Having someone to celebrate your achievements with can add a layer of accountability and fun. Apps and online sessions provide flexibility, allowing you to explore at your own pace. Let's aim for you to watch a couple of guitar tutorials this week and explore art class options in the next two weeks. Reward yourself for each step, and involve your friend for encouragement. You've got a solid plan, and taking these steps is a big move towards a more engaging and fulfilling summer. You've got this, and I'm here to support you every step of the way!
Thanks, I appreciate the support and suggestions. I'll give it a shot and keep you updated on how things are going.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear plan to address summer loneliness, with defined goals and strategies. The therapist supported and affirmed the client's ideas, enhancing motivation. Providing this structure and encouragement aligns well with termination goals.

concern:
title: How do yall cope with summer break depression/loneliness?
I just finished with my first year of college and it was amazing. I lived on campus so I went out a bunch and made new friends and passed all my classes. But I'm back home and home is where I'm lonely af because I don't have many friends here and I can't drive so I can't go out anywhere by myself. 

The good thing is that one of the friends I made only lives 10 minutes away and we're planning on hanging out every so often and I'm part of a club that meets to do stuff every Wednesday evening on campus (same friend is also part of it and will drive me there) but still. I'm not sure why I'm feeling depressed and lonely despite this but how do y'all cope with it especially since summer break is so long.

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. What would you like to talk about today? Feel free to share anything that's on your mind.
Hey, thanks. I guess I'm just feeling a bit down about not having any Halloween plans. It's tough seeing everyone else having fun while I'm just at home.
It can be really hard when you see others enjoying themselves and you feel left out. What about Halloween usually brings you joy or excitement?
I usually love dressing up and hanging out with friends, but this time it just didn't happen. It's just the whole vibe of it, you know? The spooky stuff, the energy—it’s fun to be part of all that.

It sounds like Halloween holds a special place for you, with the costumes, the spooky atmosphere, and the chance to connect with friends. Not having plans this year might feel like missing out on something you truly enjoy. What do you think might have kept you from making plans this time?
I'm not really sure, honestly. I think I just got caught up in schoolwork and the days slipped by. Before I knew it, it was the weekend and nothing was lined up.

statement.reasoning: The exploration has effectively captured the client's thoughts and feelings about missing out on Halloween plans, along with the underlying reasons such as schoolwork. Empathy and rapport are evident, and there is a mutual understanding of the client's enjoyment and disappointment regarding Halloween. It seems suitable to move to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation for change and explore potential ways to address the current feelings of isolation.

dialogue.statement: Balancing schoolwork and personal time can be challenging. Reflecting on how you missed out this year, what might make future events like Halloween more enjoyable or different for you?
Maybe setting reminders to plan ahead or reach out to friends earlier could help. I think I need to find a better balance between work and fun so things like this don’t sneak up on me again.
That sounds like a thoughtful approach—giving yourself reminders and reaching out to friends earlier. How might finding that balance between work and fun benefit other areas of your life as well?
I think it could help reduce stress overall. Having some fun stuff planned might make the workload feel less overwhelming and give me something to look forward to amidst all the responsibilities.

Finding that balance seems like it could bring some joy and relief into your life. Having events to look forward to could make a big difference. On a scale of 0 to 10, how confident are you in your ability to make these changes and find that balance?
client(guiding): Maybe around a 6? I think I can do it, but it's going to take some effort and getting used to. I really hope it helps though, because feeling overwhelmed by school isn’t fun.

statement.reasoning: The client identified a specific change goal: setting reminders and reaching out to friends earlier to balance work and fun. Confidence is at a 6, indicating some belief in their ability to implement changes. The client has expressed understanding of the benefits of this balance, suggesting readiness to move forward. Change Talk is present, with a focus on reducing stress and enhancing enjoyment. To transition smoothly, collaboratively developing an action plan with strategies for potential barriers could be the next step.

dialogue.statement: With a confidence level of 6, it sounds like you're open to trying new strategies to find that balance. Based on your ideas, possible options could include setting a regular reminder to plan social activities and scheduling some downtime weekly. Which of these options, or others you might be considering, would you like to explore for setting a goal?

client(choosing): I think starting with setting a regular reminder sounds doable. If I can just remind myself to check in with friends or plan something small each week, it might help make things feel less rushed and more enjoyable.

Setting regular reminders sounds like a manageable first step. How would you like these reminders to fit into your routine, and what specific times or methods do you think would work best for you to ensure they become a helpful habit?

I think maybe setting a reminder on Sunday nights could work, like right before the week kicks off. I usually have some downtime then, so using that time to plan ahead for some fun stuff seems like a good idea.

Therapist(choosing): Planning on Sunday nights sounds like a great option since you have some downtime then. It could be a relaxed moment to think about the week ahead. How do you feel about setting the reminder on your phone or using a planner to help keep this new routine consistent?

client(choosing): I'm leaning towards using my phone since it’s always with me, and I can set an alert that actually pops up. I think that’ll make it harder to ignore and could help me stick to it better.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear goal of setting regular reminders to plan social activities, and has decided on Sundays as a practical time for this routine. They have also chosen their phone as the primary tool for reminders, addressing some anticipated barriers. The client has expressed a confidence level of 6, indicating readiness to start taking steps. Their commitment to trying these strategies and adapting to a new routine signals their motivation for change. OARS Feedback: The client effectively identified practical steps and showed willingness to implement them. Encouraging more reflections on potential barriers might enhance ongoing planning.

dialogue.statement: Using your phone for reminders is a fantastic choice since it's always nearby and can give you timely alerts. This step could really help you stay on track and create more enjoyable moments in your week. Establishing this new habit on Sunday nights may gradually help reduce the feeling of being overwhelmed. Remember, you're making a positive change for yourself, and it's okay to take small steps. As you start this new practice, know that it's a work in progress and you're doing great by taking action. Keep at it, and you'll likely see positive changes as you go along. Looking forward, perhaps setting a follow-up time to reflect on how this strategy is working for you would be useful. Keep believing in yourself—you've got this!
Thanks, I'll give it a shot and see how it goes. It feels a little daunting, but I'm hopeful it’ll help lighten things up a bit.

statement.reasoning: The session effectively outlined strategies for balancing work and leisure, with specific plans for reminders. The client feels hopeful about the changes, and a follow-up is encouraged to assess progress. OARS feedback: Affirmations and reflections were skillfully integrated to build confidence.

concern:
title: Anyone else alone on Halloweekend?
I’ve got no plans and I’m all alone, playing sims and watching horror movies.

dialogue.statement: Hello! It seems like you're here to chat. What's on your mind today?

Hey, thanks for checking in. I've just been feeling really lonely in grad school, even though I do have some friends here. It's just not the same as what I had in undergrad, and it's been tough adjusting to this new environment.
It sounds like you're navigating a challenging transition and missing the connections you had before. What has this experience been like for you?

client: It's been pretty tough. I often find myself thinking about the good times I had with my undergrad friends and how easy it was to connect with them. Here, it feels like I'm on the outside looking in, and it's hard to find that same level of closeness.

The longing for the closeness you felt with your undergrad friends seems to be a significant part of what you're experiencing now. What have you tried so far to create new connections or deepen the ones you have?

client: I've tried joining a few clubs and attending social events to meet people, but I still feel like something's missing. I guess it's just not translating into those deep connections I had before.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their feelings of loneliness and missing deep connections from undergrad, providing insight into their context and emotional state. They have also discussed attempts to address this through clubs and social events. The therapist has established empathy and rapport by exploring these experiences and emotions. Now, it would be beneficial to move to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation for change and evoke Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: It must be challenging feeling like something's missing despite your efforts to connect. What do you think might help bridge the gap between where you are now and the closeness you hope to feel?

client: I'm not entirely sure, but maybe finding people with similar backgrounds or interests might help. It would be nice to meet others who understand what it's like to be far from home and going through the same grad school struggles.

Finding others who share your background and experiences could indeed create a deeper connection. How confident do you feel, on a scale from 0 to 10, about finding these connections and building the closeness you're looking for?
client(guiding): I'd say maybe a 4 or 5? I'm hopeful but it's just been slow and I haven't had much luck yet. It feels a bit daunting to put myself out there again and again.
Taking those steps repeatedly can feel overwhelming, especially when results aren't immediate. What might help you move from a 4 or 5 to a higher level of confidence in making those connections?

client(guiding): Maybe setting smaller, more manageable goals could help, like just trying to have a meaningful conversation with one person at a time. Also, being more open about my experiences might make it easier to connect with others who might feel the same way.

statement.reasoning: The client is experiencing a clear discrepancy between their current lack of deep connections and their value of meaningful relationships. They've discussed potential strategies, like setting smaller goals and being more open, to increase their confidence, even though they currently rate it at a 4 or 5. Change Talk is present, with a specific goal of building deeper connections. However, confidence is not yet at a 6 or higher, indicating they may need more support in the Guiding phase to solidify their readiness and confidence for the Choosing phase. Continue guiding.

dialogue.statement: therapist(guiding): Embracing smaller goals and sharing your experiences sounds like a thoughtful approach to fostering connections. What do you envision as the first step towards these smaller, meaningful interactions?

client(guiding): I think starting by engaging more in one-on-one conversations with people I already know a little might be a good first step. Maybe inviting someone for coffee or a study session would make it easier to have those deeper conversations.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire to connect with individuals who share similar experiences and has identified a specific first step—engaging in one-on-one conversations. Change Talk is evident, and the client has outlined actionable steps, suggesting readiness to develop action plans. Confidence, while initially low, seems poised to increase through smaller, manageable goals and self-disclosure. The conversation effectively explored the discrepancy between the client's current situation and desired connections, making a transition to Choosing appropriate.

dialogue.statement: Inviting someone for coffee or a study session is a wonderful first step toward building deeper connections. Based on what you've shared, possible options include scheduling a coffee meet-up once a week or joining a study group focused on shared interests. What are your thoughts on trying one of these approaches, and do you foresee any barriers you might encounter?

client(choosing): I think scheduling a coffee meet-up once a week sounds more my speed, it's less intimidating than a big group. The main barrier is just my anxiety about reaching out and maybe not having the conversation feel as natural as I'd hope.

Choosing a coffee meet-up once a week sounds like a comfortable and personable approach. Your awareness of the anxiety and natural flow of conversation is insightful. Would it help to prepare some topics or questions in advance to ease into the discussion? We could also explore strategies for managing your anxiety when reaching out. How does that sound to you?

client(choosing): That sounds like a good plan. Having some topics ready would definitely make me feel a bit more at ease, I think. I'd also appreciate some tips on managing anxiety, especially before reaching out to someone new.

Preparing some topics ahead of time can certainly create a sense of ease, giving you a foundation for your conversations. As for managing anxiety, techniques like deep breathing or visualizing a positive outcome can be helpful. Would you be interested in trying these strategies, or is there something else you feel might work better for you?

client(choosing): I think trying deep breathing and visualizing a positive outcome could be really helpful. I've heard about those techniques before but never really practiced them intentionally. I’m open to giving them a shot and seeing how they work for me.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear goal of scheduling weekly coffee meet-ups and has agreed to specific strategies for overcoming potential barriers, including preparing topics and managing anxiety through deep breathing and visualization. These steps indicate a commitment to action and demonstrate confidence in executing the plan. The client is open to trying new techniques, suggesting readiness to apply these changes. Therefore, the goals of the Choosing phase have been met, and it is appropriate to advance to the Terminating phase.

dialogue.statement: Giving deep breathing and visualization a try sounds like a wonderful step toward managing your anxiety. It’s encouraging to hear your openness to exploring these techniques. To summarize, your plan involves scheduling a weekly coffee meet-up, preparing conversation topics, and practicing deep breathing and visualization to manage anxiety beforehand. You’ve set some thoughtful goals that align well with your desire to form deeper connections. Remember, each small step is a victory in itself. If you ever feel the need for support or adjustments along the way, I'm here to help you. Keep embracing these new experiences with kindness towards yourself.
Thanks for all the suggestions! I'll definitely start by giving these strategies a shot and see how they work for me. It's nice to know I can reach out if I need more guidance.

statement.reasoning: The session has effectively addressed the client's concerns with a clear plan: weekly coffee meet-ups, conversation preparation, and anxiety management techniques. The client feels supported and open to trying these strategies.

concern:
title: How to deal with loneliness in grad school ?
I'm in my first year of grad school. I do have friends to hang out with but that doesn't seem to help with me being lonely. I am also finding it hard to form "real" connections in grad school similar to how I did in undergrad. My undergrad friends were the best and I miss them a lot. I had to move to a new country for grad school and I often miss my life back home. Is this common among grad students in general ? How do you deal with it ?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It’s great to have you here. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, I've just been feeling a bit stressed about my college classes. I had to withdraw from a couple, and I'm worried about how it'll affect me in the long run.

Navigating college stress can be overwhelming. Withdrawing from classes might feel like a setback, but it sounds like you're trying to make choices that are best for you right now. What led you to decide to withdraw from those classes?

client(exploring): It was really about balancing work and school. My job was taking up more time than I expected, and I just couldn't keep up with all the coursework. I didn't want my grades to suffer too much.

Balancing work and school can certainly be challenging. It seems like you were prioritizing your well-being by making sure your grades didn't suffer. How are you feeling about the decision now, and is there anything specific you're concerned about regarding the future?

I'm still worried about how these withdrawals might look on my transcript. Like, will it affect my chances with jobs or grad school? I'm also hopeful that I can better manage my time going forward, but it's a bit nerve-wracking.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared the essence of their story, including the context and feelings about balancing work and school, withdrawing from classes, and concerns about future implications. The therapist effectively used reflections to empathize and explore the client's thoughts and emotions. Goals are mutually agreed upon, focusing on managing time better and understanding the impact of withdrawals. Moving to the Guiding phase will help in strengthening motivation for change and evoking Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: It’s understandable to feel concerned about how withdrawals might appear on your transcript. On one hand, you're hopeful about managing your time better in the future, which shows your desire to improve and adapt. What might it look like for you if you successfully managed your time and workload in the upcoming semesters?

If I could manage my time well, I think it would really ease my stress. I'd feel more in control and confident, and hopefully, I wouldn't need to withdraw from any more classes. Maybe I could even enjoy my courses more and focus on learning.

Finding that balance seems really important to you, and envisioning a future where you feel more in control sounds quite positive. What small steps do you think might help you start feeling that way about your time and workload?

I think starting with organizing a detailed schedule could help. Maybe setting aside specific times for studying and work, and sticking to them as much as possible. Also, I might try to communicate better with my boss about my availability when school gets intense.

Creating a detailed schedule and improving communication with your boss both seem like practical steps that align with your goals for balance and control. As you think about implementing these changes, how confident do you feel on a scale from 0 to 10 about your ability to stick with this plan?

I'd say I'm around a 7. I feel pretty motivated to make things work, but there's always that worry that something unexpected will throw me off. I guess I just need to be flexible and adjust as needed.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively used OARS strategies to explore the client's concerns about college withdrawals and time management. The client has expressed a specific change goal of creating a schedule and improving communication with their boss. Their confidence level is at 7, indicating readiness to take action. The client has also engaged in Change Talk, expressing a desire for better balance and control. This suggests readiness to move to the Choosing phase to develop specific action plans and address potential barriers.

dialogue.statement: It sounds like you're feeling quite motivated and have some solid strategies in mind. Considering the possibility of unexpected challenges, what do you think might help keep you on track if something disrupts your plan? Maybe having a backup for your schedule or ways to adapt quickly?

client(choosing): Having a backup plan sounds smart. Maybe I could have a list of quick stress-relief activities or a plan for prioritizing tasks when things pile up. I guess just being kind to myself when things don't go exactly as planned would help too.

Having a backup plan and practicing self-kindness are great ways to stay on track. To support these ideas, perhaps you could create a list of stress-relief activities you enjoy and identify priority tasks ahead of time. How does having these options sound to you, and is there anything specific you'd like to include in your action plan to help ensure success?

client(choosing): Yeah, I think having a list ready would be super helpful. I might include things like a short walk, some deep breathing exercises, or even just taking a few minutes to listen to music. Identifying priority tasks in advance sounds good too, like making sure I tackle the most important assignments first.

Creating a list of quick stress-relief activities and prioritizing important tasks are excellent strategies to maintain balance. Based on what you've mentioned, options like taking a short walk, doing some deep breathing exercises, or listening to music could be part of your plan. Would you like to set a goal for how often you'd like to use these activities, and how might you monitor your progress with this plan?

Tracking how often I use these stress-relief activities could definitely help me stay consistent. Maybe I could start with aiming to use one of these activities at least once a day and then keep a simple journal or checklist to note when I do them. That way, I can see what's working and make changes if needed.

statement.reasoning: The client has established a clear goal and a concrete action plan, including creating a detailed schedule, improving communication with their boss, and having a backup plan for stress relief and task prioritization. Barriers, such as unexpected challenges, have been anticipated, and the client has proposed self-monitoring through a journal. The client shows commitment and confidence in their ability to change, expressed through setting goals and tracking progress. Therefore, the client is ready to move to the Terminating phase. OARS feedback: The client’s motivation and self-reflection have been effectively supported, but future sessions could benefit from deeper exploration of emotional responses to challenges.

dialogue.statement: That sounds like a thoughtful and practical approach to help you maintain consistency and see what's effective for you. Keeping a simple journal or checklist can provide insights and help you adjust as needed. It's great to hear that you're setting an achievable goal of incorporating one stress-relief activity each day. Remember, it's okay to be flexible with your plan and seek support when necessary. You're taking significant steps toward managing your time and stress more effectively, and you're doing a wonderful job at that. As your next step, why not start setting up your journal and identifying your priority tasks for the week? I'm here to support you as you continue on this journey.
Thanks, I really appreciate your support. I'll start working on that journal and priority list this week. It'll be good to have something concrete to focus on.

statement.reasoning: The session successfully summarized the client's goals, coping strategies, and steps to improve time management and stress relief, alongside planning next actions. This closure supports the client's journey with practical tools and emotional encouragement.

concern:
title: How many W's did you have in college?
This is my first semester in college and I had to withdraw from 2 classes because of some circumstances involving my job and time management. I don't want to do it again and I just wanted to know if it's a bad thing and if you guys had a similar experience before? And how many W's is too many??

dialogue.statement: Hello, I'm here to listen and support you. Feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for being here. I just feel like I've taken on way too much with work and school, and now I'm just really overwhelmed. I can't stop thinking about how I'm letting my professors down.
It must be really tough juggling both work and school, and feeling like you're not meeting expectations. What has this experience been like for you on a day-to-day basis?

client: Honestly, it feels like I'm constantly racing against the clock. Every day just blurs into the next, and I barely have time to catch my breath. It's like I'm stuck in this cycle of stress with no end in sight.

That sounds really exhausting, feeling like every moment is a rush and there's no break in sight. What's the impact of this stress on other parts of your life, like your personal time or relationships?
client: It's been rough, to be honest. I barely have any personal time, and when I do, I'm just too tired to enjoy it. My relationships are strained because I'm always busy or stressed out.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared the essence of their story, including their overwhelming workload, stress, and the impact on personal time and relationships. There's a clear understanding of their feelings and context, including concerns about letting others down. Empathy and rapport are evident, and the client's desire for tips to improve balance indicates a mutually agreed goal. Moving to the Guiding phase would be beneficial to strengthen motivation for change and explore Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: It seems like the stress is really impacting areas of your life that are important to you. If things were different and you had more balance, what might that look like for you?

Honestly, having more balance would mean actually having time to relax and enjoy things I love without feeling guilty. I'd love to be more present with friends and family and not have to constantly worry about deadlines or work all the time.

Imagining that balance sounds really meaningful—time to relax and truly connect with the people you care about. What steps do you think could help you move towards that sense of balance and presence in your life?

Yeah, I think maybe scaling back on the number of classes could help, even if it means taking a bit longer to finish my degree. Also, setting more boundaries with work to protect some downtime sounds necessary, even though it's easier said than done.

Taking those steps to scale back and set boundaries seems like a thoughtful way to move toward the balance you’re seeking. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about making these changes?

concern:
title: No Clue What to Do About Nightmare Roommate
I live in a triple, and my one roommate, we’ll call them A, is a nightmare. My other roommate, we’ll call them B, is very nice and accommodating, and I feel like she doesn’t want to do anything about A because of how accommodating she is.

First of all, I’ve only physically seen A shower twice since we got here a month ago, and she smells very bad. Any space in the room she walks in will stink. And I mean STINK. It’s awful to not be able to come back to my dorm after a long day of classes and relax because of her smell. It’s only been a month, so I don’t know how long I can keep this up for because I’m already tired of it. She also never does her laundry, as in I have not seen her do laundry the entire time we’ve been here. 

Second, she won’t let me or B touch the AC. If I manage to change it to a more comfortable temperature, she will change it back twenty minutes later as if I won’t notice. We don’t pay extra for AC so I don’t see why she’s so adamant on not using it, even on 80 degree days. I wake up drenched in sweat. 

Third, she hits snooze on her alarm clock AT LEAST 5 times before she wakes up. Today was 7. Not exaggerating. 7. It’s so annoying when I get woken up every 10 minutes for two hours straight. 

The alarm clock thing I feel I can just address with her face to face because she’s not a mean person necessarily, and I’m not asking much. 

However, I don’t know if I can look at someone in the eye and tell them they smell. Maybe I can ask B if she has noticed it, too, and we can talk to her together, but I really don’t want to create animosity in the room. 

I fear if I tell the RA, it will humiliate A and thus create animosity in the room. 

I really like my dorm and B, so I would rather not move out, but I can’t live like this with A anymore. What do I do?

concern:
title: Roommate brings her friend to sleep at our dorm every other night
I know these kinds of posts show up every day on this sub and that if I have a problem with my roommate I should talk to them about it, but I can’t help but wonder if I’m being over dramatic. 

My roommate for the past few months has been bringing her friend to sleep in our dorm. At the beginning, she asked me if it was okay and I said yes. And at first, everything was fine. She’d bring this friend every so often to our place and they would sleep the night with us. 

But more recently, she’s been bringing them almost every other day and it’s starting to get quite unnerving to say the least. Mind you, I am 18F and her friend is 18M so it makes it kinda awkward for him to be sleeping here. 

And this would all be fine if we lived in a suite of some sort, but our dorm is traditional style and so we don’t have the luxury of our own private rooms. In fact, I can literally see her bed right across from mine while she is sleeping with her friend.

Before, she used to put a mattress on the floor next to her bed for him to sleep on, but now it’s literally them both sleeping together in the same bed which has made it even more uncomfortable. 

Is this a normal thing to do in college? I don’t really know if this is something I should tolerate or how to go about confronting this issue if it’s something I shouldn’t.

concern:
title: I hate it when professors say something is "easy"
Literally the quickest way to make a student feel bad about themselves because they don't quite understand or it's not actually "easy" for them.

I was told recently during office hours for a CS class that the file and code I wrote was not needed and that I was doing it wrong and all I had to do was this and that and whatever and she ended by saying "It's easy." 

That made me feel like shit cause I didn't know how to do it despite it being "easy" and I was in a depressing mood for the rest of the day and the following day as well. 

Saying that an assignment is easy is just unnecessary. You have no idea what someone's struggles are, with the content/class **and** outside of that as well. While an assignment could technically be easy, that doesn't mean it's easy for someone to get up and sit down to do the assignment if they're struggling with their mental health, family issues etc.

dialogue.statement: Hello! How can I support you today? Feel free to share what's on your mind.

concern:
title: PSA: “do not disturb” means DO NOT DISTURB (this is a post about respect)
Living in a dorm is hell as it is. I can’t tell you how many times people have disrespected the “do not disturb” sign. 

If somebody has that kind of sign, kindly DO NOT DO IT AND WALK AWAY. They don’t want to talk to you or anybody else. Even if you’re an RA, just email or text. Why? Because I’m sleeping. Or I’m taking a test. Or I’m doing homework. And I need to concentrate.

And you… you decide to be the snide mufker who knocks on my door with the “do not disturb” sign. The “you” I’m referring to is the guy who hosts dorm parties every Tuesday night, and knocks on my door to ask if I was the one who called the cop. Comes to ask me random questions at 3am. Or another one, my neighbors who are curious about something.

*Does no mean no?* Then why does “do not disturb” not mean *do not disturb?*

If you do this and you live in a dorm, please, kindly go live off campus. Or just drop out of college all together. Because if you do not respect other people’s boundaries, you’re not gonna go far in life and you might as well give up now.

concern:
title: A Friend and Terrible Project Mate at the Same Time
My friend asked to team up with me on an important course project which I valued very much. The whole course is evaluated totally based on the project. I accepted the invitation because I am actually the dumb one among us. However, in the project, I got mad at him. Whenever we came across problems, he would say he didn't know anything and "sorry, I really can't help you", as if this was my personal project. I talked to him so many times about this, and he was tired of me pushing him to think. Then right before the deadline, when we had trouble meeting the minimum requirements, he said he didn't think we need to meet the requirement, and I shouldn't care so much about the project. I worked for two whole weeks with little sleep before the due date, but still, I didn't get any results for the report in the end. When he said "I am sorry that you didn't get the right results", I almost shouted at him.

I feel awkward now talking to him and disappointed with this collaboration. I don't feel proper to complain to the professor. We are friends and still need to meet on lots of occasions. My complaint can make things more complicated. Is there any way to make myself feel better and let go?

concern:
title: How do I get through grad school?
Pretty sure there are several posts similar to mine, but I don't know who to ask for advice. I naively joined a master's program in computer science this September, simply because I felt like my undergraduate degree taught me nothing and i want to learn the concepts in a better institution. One month in and I am barely holding back my tears. I know it wasn't going to be easy but I took a subject called mathematical foundations, and I am absolutely unable to comprehend it. The other 2 subjects i took are definitely hard but i feel like with an extreme amount of effort, i can do my best and learn well. But with math foundations, i don't know what to do. I don't know how the rest of my classmates feel about the subject, but i do know that one friend is finding it quite easy. I have spent several hours going through the basics of linear algebra and it still doesn't change the fact that i am not able to comprehend the subject. I'm not saying I've given up, but i want to ask if this is a natural feeling that some of you all may have felt for some subjects. How did you get through this, and 4 semesters of this? Can you provide some tips on how to manage the semester, especially if you've considered yourself an average/below average student?

dialogue.statement: Hello, I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

It sounds like you're weighing the familiarity and continuity of pursuing a master's in Criminal Justice against the potential opportunities with geography. Feeling apprehensive about such a big shift is completely understandable. Can you share more about what appeals to you in each option?

client: Well, CJ feels like a natural extension of what I'm doing, you know? But geography, especially with the GIS stuff, sounds like it could be really versatile and open up different doors. It's just the whole starting-from-scratch vibe that's intimidating.

concern:
title: help me pick major?
A bit about me. When I was 18 i took a dishwashing job at a local nursing home. It was my first job. I ended up becoming a cook and have bounced around from cook job to higher paying cook job. It's all ive ever done. Im decent at it. Ive learned and covered alot of kitchen management aspects along the way as well. It's been 10 years now. I dont love it, but it really feels like my only applicable skill.


I have dabbled in college courses along the way but i always get swallowed into the fast cash of overtime at a new higher paying job. So ive never truly commited. Now, i feel like its either sht or get off the pot and im not sure what i should truly pursue a degree in.


I spend all of my free time making music, its a huge passion and hoby for me that has landed me a few really nice paychecks but betting everything on that would be insane. other than that i spend my time reading self help books and learning different aspects of finance.  


My gf has asked me to join her in the medical field but it doesnt peak any interest. My buddy has always told me i'd be great at what he does in the behavioral health field and that does sound super interesting and purposeful to me but i havent done enough of it to know.


I feel like im looking for something that could umbrella a career and all of my interests. Like, maybe a degree that would require me to learn skills that can be applied to music and personal finance like some type of management or accounting thing. Even then, ive never really met an accountant that made enough money to just be an accountant. 


Does anyone have any pointers?

also I am trying to transfer from a community college to a university, so I still have some required classes to complete that's why

concern:
title: Time management
Hello all! 

My situation: 
-go to class Tues, Wed, Thursday all day. 
-days not at school working (20-25hr a week) 
-feed and maintain for 6 animals at home
-am the main “cleaner” at my house
-pick up and drop off my sister to school every week day
-have a bf that I spend about 4-8 hrs a day with
-need to meditate and journal daily to maintain sanity 
-need to study 

My question:
How am I able to maintain something like this? Wat needs to be cut out?

dialogue.statement: Hello! Feel free to share whatever is on your mind today. I'm here to listen and understand your story.

concern:
title: Should I transfer halfway through college
This has been a thought that keeps popping into my head and I want to know what others think.

I’m currently a sophomore at a large (hard to get into / very “good”) public university. Engineering major with a minor, consulting/big tech company/a less technical job that makes good money is the goal.

I’m someone who never would have thought i’d ever consider something like this, in no way am I seeking “the college experience” or anything like that, to start. I see the (fun) social aspect of college to be quite superficial, and in no way is that playing into this idea. All of this in centered around being successful / not failing life. 

A little background for how college has been so far:
I’m not doing great and I have nothing going for me / to assure me i’m going to do well at all. GPA is currently at a 3.4 calculated before this semester ends (don’t expect it to hurt it much more but it def won’t get better). In terms of classes, I feel as though i’m doing poorly, even at the things that shouldn’t be too difficult, and I feel as though i’m in a huge academic hole. I don’t see how much grades could really improve. Extracurriculars: none. I gave it my all in applying to professional clubs that would have very much helped my ass but I was never accepted, and that was when I didn’t look like a dumbass in comparison to my competition (a lot of people). Professional experience: I’ve had a couple stupid summer jobs but nothing ever remotely relating to my major or area or interest i.e. working at a restaurant. so none. social/networking: none. I have an extremely limited social circle, messed up and got “stuck” with a lot of higschool friends, have no connections to any job/internship/good club prospect and my parents/family have no such connections either. I can talk to people and make a good impression, but i’m bad at “putting myself out there”. 

My concerns for my situation:
I need to be good at something (grades, knowing people, etc) but none of that is going well and I don’t see how I could improve it. I’m ambitious and to get to where I want to be in my adult life I need to be good at something. when it comes to a job or an internship or any future prospect I don’t see why anyone would ever pick me, I know I wouldn’t.

I used to be extremely successful with everything I did. I had very very good grades at a well renowned private high school and got into many very good universities (didn’t attend because of money and I thought this “made sense”). I was on par or better than all the peers I can’t remotely compare myself to now (at the same college where they are doing just fine). I am extremely unhappy with my life now. I don’t do anything fun, I just work. My university is very work hard play hard, but all I do is work without success. I hate that I see zero indication of being the person I want to be in terms of success. making money matters to me. my parents worked their asses off for me and put a massive investment into my education and I couldn’t feel more guilty with myself for fucking it up especially when I used to go above and beyond for them before. I wish I could start all over from scaratch. if I had no one counting on me I seriously would consider dropping out with how much I hate this. i’m reaching a limit with how much effort i’ve been giving to and idk how much I can keep going. 

I find this school very unsupportive of students like me and again I feel really stuck in terms of the people I know and the social situation i’ve put myself in . Another goal of mine is to live somewhere else. my thought is that if I transfer away I can be someone i’m not, and at least attempt to build a network of people I know in a place where my desired field is much more accessible as an attempt to increase chances of being hired. even if that doesn’t work and I fuck that up too I could start my failed adult life in a place I want to live?

dialogue.statement: Hello! What's on your mind today? I'd love to understand your story and what brings you here.

Hey! I've been feeling pretty torn between choosing mechanical engineering or facilities engineering. It's a big decision because it impacts my future a lot, especially with the career path I've planned. Just wanted to talk it out and maybe get some clarity.

Choosing between mechanical and facilities engineering seems like a significant decision for your future career path, and it's understandable to feel torn. What aspects of each option are important to you?

Well, with mechanical engineering, I really like the flexibility and broad scope it offers, which could open up more opportunities later on. But with facilities engineering, I feel like I'd gain more hands-on experience directly related to my USCG 3rd engineer's license, which is crucial for my plan to work on ships after graduation.

Balancing flexibility and hands-on experience sounds like a challenging choice. The broad opportunities of mechanical engineering appeal to you, while facilities engineering aligns closely with your goal of working on ships. How do you feel about the potential future outcomes of each path?

Thinking about it, pursuing mechanical engineering might keep a lot of doors open for me down the line, which is nice. But on the other hand, facilities engineering seems like it would prepare me better for the specific path I want to take right after graduation. It's tough to weigh the long-term benefits against the immediate practical experience.

statement.reasoning: The conversation provides a clear understanding of the client's dilemma between choosing mechanical or facilities engineering. The client has expressed the importance of flexibility, hands-on experience, and alignment with career goals and has articulated concerns about long-term versus immediate benefits. Rapport has been established, and the client has been open in sharing their thoughts and feelings. It's appropriate to move to the Guiding phase to explore motivations and potential outcomes more deeply.

But I also think about the importance of having varied opportunities and maybe exploring other fields later, which mechanical engineering might provide. I'm just trying to figure out which aligns best with where I see myself in the future.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear understanding of the discrepancy between long-term flexibility offered by mechanical engineering and the immediate practical application of facilities engineering. Staying flexible and remembering why I'm doing this should keep me motivated.

concern:
title: Facilities Engineering or Mechanical engineering

So this semester (last semester of sophomore year) I have the option of switching between Mechanical Engineering or Facilities Engineering before I'd get behind if I decided to switch beyond this point. I'm very divided on what type of engineering I want to focus on and I know it's for me decide on what I really want to do. I just want to see what peoples thoughts are when they are stuck in this type of predicament and what I should weigh when deciding.

Background: I go to SUNY Maritime and instead of a minor I am trying to pursue a USCG 3rd engineers license. For those of you who have no idea what it is, it allows people to work and run a power plant (steam, diesel, diesel electric, nuclear if you get certified but not many civilian ships use nuke) on a ship along with HVAC, plumbing, fresh water generation, electrical work, etc. I plan on using this license to ship out for at-least 5 years after I graduate in hope to be able to sit for my chief engineers exam. I'm worried I'll fall behind the curve with a mechanical engineering degree as I won't have as polished skills when I leave compared to my peers who go immediately to land side jobs. With facilities engineering I feel like I would be building work experience with it. The thing I like about mechanical is the flexibility and broadness that comes with it. 

I am also happy to answer any questions you have about the program I am in :)

concern:
title: Quitting my masters?
This will require some context but I am interested in people’s opinions. 

I was hired for my current job about a year ago. The expectation was I would finish my master’s in August and start my job in October. I did not end up completing my thesis by then, but I kept the same timeline with my job. My company was extremely understanding and left it up to me if i wanted to start full time, part time, or delay my start until I finished my thesis. I started part time in october and after a month have not made any more thesis progress. I really really want to give up on my thesis and just work full time.

The thesis has always caused an immense amount of stress for me and it only gets worse with time. At this point I have to think that the mental and physical (namely sleep) benefits of quitting my thesis far outweigh the benefits of completing my degree. Is this something I can bring up to my boss or do you think I should stay silent on this?

title: Form to switch from thesis to non thesis

Last time, I sent her a proposal draft and she never got back to on that. Just like that, semester ended. After filling up a evaluation form, she now says that I should give up thesis. She sent me a bunch of comments saying I couldn't stick to the deadline and I am bad at communication as I never sent her a follow up email on the proposal draft. 

I sent her an email asking for her genuine guidance. My dilemma is I am an international student and am sustaining here because of the scholarship and stipend. If I change to thesis, I believe I will lose both. Now that the winter semester is starting, I don't know if should switch as she advised me or convince her to let me do my thesis. The way she is pressuring me to drop the thesis makes me feel like she just doesn't want me to be part of her project anymore.

concern:
title: college is making me feel super lonely
I started going to college this year and it started off really great but now I’m really lost. I got to college in august about 2 months after a really rough break up so i was already a little depressed but i ended up making a good group of friends on my dorm floor that i hung out with very frequently. i was rooming with a friend of mine from high school, but i moved out this second semester as he was the worst roommate ever and just a really shitty person and friend in general. all of my friends thankfully took my side in the situation, but now that ive moved i dont see my friends that often at all anymore. my friend group had like 8 or so people in it with 2 or 3 i felt i had a genuine connection with. now i live in a suite with 3 guys i get along with but never really talk to. i don’t really text so i really only get to see and talk to three of my friends from my old dorm like maybe once a week. there are some who i haven’t even seen since i moved out 2 months ago. i’ve honestly never been more lonely and depressed in my entire life. my mental health was already not the best going into college but my friends helped me forget about it. now i find myself alone almost every day with no motivation to do anything and all i can think about is how lonely i am. I was already struggling with my grades but managed to stay afloat my first semester but now it’s even harder to do my school work and go to class. i want to reconnect with my friends or even make new ones but at this point in the semester im so lost as to how i would even do that.

concern:
title: Research vs Project Dilemma
Apologies in advance for such a long post! 

I’m in a bit of a dilemma and thought I’d post here to get some feedback.  I’m in my last semester of a three-year MFA in design.  I’ve been developing my thesis since the first year (my program has you write the first few chapters during research classes) and solidified my committee spring of last year, which gave me a whole year to work on my thesis with them.  I sent my progress and documents over to my committee chair, who then didn’t get back to me for several months until I emailed him asking for an update.  Then we went back and forth with edits all last semester until I finally got a pre-proposal meeting at the end of the semester.  Then, despite my chair saying I was in a good spot, the rest of my committee didn’t like my idea or my methods and basically told me to start over.  

So now I’m in my final semester, with my funding running out.  There’s no way I can get though IRB review, conducting research, and revisions before the end of the semester and I need to start working full time this summer. I don’t want to have to be in thesis mode while starting a new job and I just feel really stuck (and stressed).  I knew I needed to be done at a certain point which is why I tried so hard to stay ahead of things.  

I understand that setbacks like this are part of grad school and part of the research process, but it just doesn’t feel worth it for an MFA, especially because most MFA’s have final projects, not research-based theses.  I’m thinking about asking if I can switch to a final project I already have something partially developed that I think would actually be really great, but I have to convince them to let me do it and I’m not sure they will.  

I just don’t really know what to do…. I really was interested in my research topic but if I’m going to be dragged through years of it I’d rather it be in a doctoral program.  I’m only 24 and I don’t want to push off my career for thesis that just keeps getting delayed.  But I might regret it if I pursue more research or a doctorate later too so I’m just kinda stuck and could use some insight if you have it.  Thank you.
