concern:
title: Is it wrong to put on my roommate-find form for college that I'm not okay with people with neopronouns/neogenders?
TL; DR: Title. As a binary trans person not active in the LGBTQ community it makes me uncomfortable. Would I be canceled/hated by the people in my college if I did so?

Sorry if this isn't the right subreddit for this but I couldn't find a better one. I am going to a school in NY(which I hear is a generally pretty progressive state) and I am from the south.

I am trans/gay, but I really don't like talking about it that much. I mean I'll talk about relationships and hot people/characters I like but the subject of my conversations will never really revolve around how prideful I am in my sexuality/gender. Maybe it's because I'm from the south--and I'm fine with LGBTQ people--I just don't really like the people super active in the LGBTQ community because they make me uncomfortable. Especially the neopronouns/neogenders crowd. I was made fun of for being trans by other kids and called an "it" or asked if I identified as a cat/dog and how that meant it was okay to sh//t me. And it really dehumanized me--it's a part of my life I don't particularly want shoved in my face every day even if I'm okay speaking up for myself or talking about only occasionally.

I try to be an accepting person. And I do not hate the neopronouns/neogenders crowd, but being around them makes me uncomfortable so I tend to steer clear. Although I firmly believe you should I what makes you happy I do not think these things are rooted in a medically necessary basis the same way gender dysphoria is. And I worry they would hate me for that belief even if I were to accept/respect them as people regardless of what I think.

If I put it out there that I didn't really wanna room with people like that would everyone get mad at me for being exclusionary? My school isn't that large and I don't want to have a tough time with the few people I get the opportunity to make friends with.

title: Help with Mental Health and Health Overall During College

I have no motivation to keep on going because of all of this. I want to do good, and I know I can do good, but I feel so weighed down in my mind that I can't. 

How can I remedy this? How can I get a clearer mind and feel better so that I can do better?

title: Any Red Flags I Missed?
Hi all, 

I'm in a thesis STEM MS where the professors/PIs largely choose students instead of having students rotate in labs or reach out to potential PIs. This was never mentioned to me, and I happened to find out when an undergrad and I were talking. For various reasons, any and all projects I was supposed to use for my thesis are either disjointed, have been delayed, or will no longer happen (it's been an entire semester and I've done no work on anything). Turns out my advisor merely "consults" on 1 of them and failed to mention she is not a PI on any project right now, is powerless to move them along, and seems to care a little less every day. This is slowly becoming more of an issue that could possibly keep me from graduating on time. 

Is any of this unusual, or is it just how it goes in academia sometimes? Is having an advisor who is not my PI problematic?

concern:
title: Help me decide on a lab!
So I have two labs, A and B. Our program (bio) makes us rotate prior to choosing our thesis lab. 
I’m really, really passionate about A’s research. A is a really good lab, PI has tons of funding, great connections, great facility, awards, etc. I rotated with A, told me to go rotate with C as well since they collaborate on the project I want to join. A is also really competitive to get into, so I agreed to rotate with C in a few weeks, even though it’s an engineering lab which I’m not into at ALL, but thought maybe it’ll help me understand A’s research better. Now I learn that if I join I might need to do a comentoring situation with both A and C which I’m really not into since I don’t want to get into biomedical engineering. Theoretically I could ask to stay solely in A if I don’t end up liking C when I rotate, but I’m not sure if that’ll seem odd since I agreed to rotating with C and if it will lower my chances of getting into A. Also, I’m not really a fan of the lab environment in A, it hasn’t been super welcoming from the other grad students, but the PI is a good mentor. I won’t get a lot of guidance since she wants independence, but I feel like it will be hard but make me a “better scientist.” Also, the PI will be retiring when the grant that I’m joining will finish, so theoretically we would be leaving at the same time, which I’m not sure if that’s a problem. 

On the other hand, B is a good lab, has a great lab culture, I enjoy the methods used, really sweet PI that I feel comfortable asking questions to. BUT I’m not into the overall research topic at all, and really don’t want to be stuck in that field, and when I think about research I’m SO much more into A’s research. 

TLDR: Which lab should I join? The lab that checks all the boxes but I don’t like the research, or the one I really like the research, but has a lot of other problems

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?
Hey, thanks for listening. I've just been feeling really lonely since I started college. It's been hard not having any friends around.
Starting college can be a big adjustment, and it's understandable to feel lonely without familiar faces around. What has your experience been like trying to make connections so far?

client: It's been tough. I guess I expected it to be like high school, where friendships just kind of happened naturally. But here, it feels like everyone already has their own group, and I'm just on the outside.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit isolated and it's hard when it seems like others have already formed their circles. What sort of activities or opportunities have you come across in college that could help in meeting new people?
Honestly, there haven't been many activities or opportunities at my college. There are no clubs or events, so it's been really hard to find ways to meet people outside of class.

statement.reasoning: The essence of the client's story has been effectively elicited, revealing feelings of loneliness and isolation after starting college, compounded by a lack of opportunities to meet new people. Empathy and rapport have been established, and the client has shared detailed context and feelings. There is a mutual understanding of the client's sense of being 'on the outside' and their desire to make connections. Transitioning to the Guiding phase is appropriate to begin exploring motivations and potential strategies for change. OARS feedback: The reflections and open questions allowed the client to share their story openly, demonstrating a deep understanding of their situation. We will continue to affirm their resilience as we explore motivations for change.

dialogue.statement: It must be challenging navigating this new environment with limited opportunities to connect. Imagine if the situation were different, with more social events or clubs; how do you think that might change your college experience?

client(guiding): I think it would make a huge difference. Having more events or clubs would give me a chance to meet people who have similar interests, and it would be easier to strike up conversations and build friendships. It would make college feel a lot less lonely for sure.

That's a valuable insight, recognizing how different opportunities could positively impact your experience. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding alternative ways to create those connections and friendships, even with the current limitations?
client(guiding): I guess I'm around a 4. It's hard to feel confident when there aren't many options, but I'm willing to try and figure something out.

Your willingness to try and find ways to connect, even in a challenging situation, shows a lot of resilience. What small steps do you think you might take to increase that confidence from a 4 to a little higher, perhaps?

client(guiding): Maybe I could start by reaching out to those two classmates who are around my age. They seem shy, but maybe they're in the same boat as me. I could also try to find some online groups or communities related to my interests to connect with people outside of campus.

statement.reasoning: The client has engaged in change talk by recognizing potential actions to improve their social situation, such as reaching out to classmates and exploring online communities. However, their confidence is currently low (rated at 4), and while they have identified small steps, they haven't committed to a specific change goal with a clear next step. There's a need to further explore and enhance their confidence and solidify a more detailed plan. Therefore, continuing in the Guiding phase is appropriate to strengthen the client's motivation and develop a more actionable strategy.

dialogue.statement: therapist(guiding): Those sound like great ideas and proactive steps towards building connections. Reaching out to classmates and exploring online communities could open new doors for you. How do you feel about taking these steps, and what might help you get started?

client(reflecting): I feel a bit nervous about reaching out, but I think it could be worth it. Maybe just starting small, like saying hi or asking them about class stuff, could be a good way to break the ice. As for online groups, I could spend some time researching ones that align with my interests and see where it goes from there.

statement.reasoning: The client has shown some initial Change Talk by identifying small steps to increase social connections, such as reaching out to classmates and exploring online groups. However, confidence is still low, rated at 4, and there's a significant presence of ambivalence with lingering concerns about loneliness and the lack of college activities. More focus on increasing confidence and reducing ambivalence is needed. Continued exploration of potential strategies and bolstering self-efficacy is essential before collaboratively developing specific action plans.

dialogue.statement: Your plans to start small and gradually reach out sound thoughtful and manageable. Taking those initial steps with your classmates and exploring online groups could indeed be rewarding. What personal values or goals do you think these actions might help you move closer to?

client(reflecting): I think these actions align with my value of building meaningful relationships. I really want to create a sense of belonging and community here, and even though it's a bit scary, I know it'll help me feel more connected and happier in the long run.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed Change Talk, identifying steps to connect with classmates and online communities. They've moved from a confidence level of 4 towards taking action, indicating increased motivation. They've explored life with potential changes and how it aligns with their values of building relationships and creating a sense of belonging. Given these indicators, it's appropriate to start developing specific action plans. OARS feedback: The reflections helped the client clarify the importance of values, while affirming their resilience boosted confidence. Moving forward, ensure continued focus on supporting specific action planning.

dialogue.statement: Those are wonderful values and goals to guide you, and it's great that you're planning steps aligned with them. As we move into making specific plans, what would you like to focus on first—connecting with classmates or exploring online groups? Based on your preferences, we can brainstorm strategies and consider any barriers that might arise.

client(reflecting): I think I'd like to start with connecting with my classmates first. It feels more immediate and tangible, and being able to talk to someone in person could really help with feeling less isolated on campus. Plus, once I get the hang of it, it'll probably give me more courage to explore online groups later.

Focusing on connecting with your classmates sounds like a solid starting point. Since you mentioned starting small is your approach, perhaps you could consider inviting them to join you for a study session or a casual coffee chat after class. What do you think might help you feel more at ease as you take these steps, and are there any potential obstacles you anticipate?

To feel more at ease, I might need to remind myself that they might be feeling just as awkward or shy about reaching out. One obstacle could be if they're not interested or too busy, but I guess the worst case is I just try again another time or with someone else.

Offering to suggest a study session is a thoughtful approach, and reminding yourself that others might share your feelings can definitely help ease nerves. If they happen to be busy or uninterested, that's okay—it's all part of the process, and you're keeping your options open. How about we set a goal to reach out to them in the next week? We can also discuss how you'll monitor your progress and feelings as you navigate this new experience.

client(reflecting): Setting a goal to reach out to them in the next week sounds doable. I think I'll try to approach one of them after class and casually bring up the idea of a study session. I'll keep track of how it goes and how I'm feeling about the whole thing, so I can share it with you next time and see if there's anything I need to adjust.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear goal to connect with classmates and a concrete action plan to initiate a study session within the next week. They have identified potential barriers and ways to self-monitor their progress and feelings. The client shows readiness through their commitment to take steps and self-reflect on the process. They are confident in beginning this change, as evidenced by their proactive planning and willingness to adjust if needed. Move to Terminating to evaluate these initial steps and provide support as they refine their approach.

dialogue.statement: That sounds like a wonderful plan. Reaching out after class with a casual suggestion is a great way to build a connection naturally. Keeping track of your experiences and feelings will give us valuable insights the next time we meet. Remember, each step is progress, and celebrating your efforts is important. I'm here to support you in this journey towards building meaningful relationships and creating that sense of community you value so much.

client(terminating): Thanks! I appreciate the support and encouragement. I'll give it a shot and see how it goes, and I'll let you know what happens. Having a plan makes it feel a bit more manageable.

statement.reasoning: The client has clear goals and a plan for reaching out to classmates, aligning with their values for connection and community. They've set a manageable timeframe and will monitor progress, showing readiness to engage in the process. Moving forward, focusing on reinforcing the client's confidence and adaptability worked well.

concern:
title: Having no friends
I started college a couple of months ago, and I moved from a different country so i had to leave all my friends that i had. I've never had any issues with making friends, I think at the beginning of starting a new school I've always been worried about making friends but it just... happened. But after a few days i realized that i hadn't made any, there are not many people in my class ( around 10) , and a lot of them aren't even around my age, i'd say there are about 2 kids my age, but they are shy and have never spoken to me. There was no introduction day so I never got introduced to anyone, and im worried sick i won't make any friends. I've started to become really lonely, at break times i just go out and sit alone. I honestly was just not expecting college to be that much different from highschool, but it seems everyone has already made their friends and im srewed. My college isn't very good either, no clubs, no events, really just nothing. I feel like im wasting some really important years of my life sitting at home doing nothing when i should be out with friends. im not sure what to do.

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and understand more about what's on your mind. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, I've just been thinking a lot about how college seems more like a business than anything else. It's kind of frustrating to feel like it's not really set up in our best interests, you know?
You’re feeling frustrated because it seems like college prioritizes business interests over what's genuinely beneficial for students. What experiences have led you to feel this way?

client: Well, it's just that everything about college seems to focus on money—tuition, fees, even textbooks. And then, there's this pressure to pick a major you love, but that doesn't always align with job prospects. It feels like we're not being guided the right way.

It sounds like you're grappling with the tension between pursuing something you love and facing economic pressures and job uncertainties. Can you share more about how this has impacted your decisions or feelings about your education?

Yeah, it's made me rethink what I'm studying. Like, I started out following my passion, but now I'm more worried about how it'll translate into a job. It's stressful trying to balance what I enjoy with what's practical for my future.

statement.reasoning: The client has conveyed their frustrations and concerns about college being more business-oriented, and how this affects their decisions and feelings about education. The exploration has effectively elicited the essence of the client's story, including their thoughts, context, and emotions. The conversation has also facilitated empathy and rapport. It's appropriate to transition to Guiding to strengthen motivation and evoke Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: Choosing between passion and practicality seems to be causing some stress. If you imagine your future, what do you think life might look like if you continue on your current path versus making a change?

I guess if I stick with what I'm studying now, I might end up in a job that's not really stable or well-paying. But if I switch to something more practical, I worry I won't enjoy my work as much. It's hard to picture exactly how each path would turn out, and that uncertainty is pretty overwhelming.

Imagining those different futures brings up a lot of uncertainty and overwhelm. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about navigating these choices and finding a balance that works for you?
client(guiding): Honestly, I'd say maybe a 4 or 5. I'm trying to figure things out, but it's tough to feel confident when there's so much at stake and not a lot of clear guidance.

Finding that balance feels challenging right now, especially with so much at stake. It's great that you're acknowledging these feelings and exploring your options. What values or priorities do you think might help guide you toward a decision that feels right for you?

client(guiding): I think stability is really important to me, but I also value doing something that doesn't make me miserable every day. It would be nice to find a way to have both, but I’m not sure how to prioritize them in a way that makes sense.

statement.reasoning: The client has explored the discrepancy between their values of stability and job satisfaction and the financial and practical pressures of college. However, change talk is minimal, confidence is rated below 6, and ambivalence remains high, as the client struggles to prioritize values. Continuing in the Guiding phase will help further explore and strengthen motivation for change, aiming to enhance confidence and reduce ambivalence before moving to action planning in the Choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: Balancing stability with job satisfaction is important to you. What would it mean for you to find a path that respects both of these values, even if it's not a perfect solution?

client(guiding): I guess it would mean feeling secure enough financially to not constantly stress about money, but also waking up and not dreading my work. Maybe it doesn't have to be perfect, but something that doesn't make me regret my choices every day.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear discrepancy between their passion and the pressures of practical job prospects, and explored the implications of their current path versus change. Although they express some ambivalence, they have not yet developed a specific change goal or step. Their confidence remains at 4 or 5, indicating a need for further strengthening of motivation and clarity on values before moving to action planning. client(guiding): That could definitely help. Talking to people who are actually working in the fields I'm considering might give me a better idea of what to expect. I think it would be useful to get a realistic view of what different jobs are like day-to-day and see if they line up with what I want. Also, exploring options could open up paths I hadn't considered before.

client(exploring): I feel like it's a good idea, but it's kind of intimidating too. I'm not really sure where to start or who to talk to. It seems like a lot to manage on top of everything else, but I know it could be really helpful in making a more informed decision.

They have explored the implications of change and considered seeking advice from professionals in their fields of interest. Although their confidence level is around a 4 or 5, there is a specific action step identified: exploring careers by reaching out to professionals, indicating readiness for planning. Change Talk has increased, and ambivalence has decreased. Moving to the Choosing phase can facilitate developing concrete plans. Attending a virtual panel seems less intimidating, so maybe I could begin with that and see how it goes from there. I'll need to carve out some time to actually look into these events or find people to contact, but it feels like a step in the right direction.

I could keep a simple journal or notes on my phone to jot down any useful information or thoughts I have. It might help me see patterns or new ideas I hadn't considered before.

Using a journal or notes on your phone to capture insights and reflections can be incredibly helpful in seeing new patterns. client(choosing): Sharing my progress with someone could definitely be helpful. It might be a good way to stay motivated and not feel so alone in figuring all this out. I think having someone to bounce ideas off of would be nice, especially if I'm feeling stuck or unsure.

statement.reasoning: The client has established a clear goal of exploring career options, and there's a concrete action plan involving attending virtual panels and setting weekly research times. Potential barriers, like feeling overwhelmed by the process, have been addressed with strategies such as breaking tasks into smaller steps and using a journal for insights. The client has agreed to self-monitor progress and suggested sharing with a friend for accountability. The client shows confidence in these steps and is prepared to act. The Choosing phase has successfully facilitated a comprehensive plan, and it's appropriate to move to the Terminating phase. dialogue.statement: Having a supportive friend or mentor to share your journey with sounds like a wonderful way to stay encouraged and inspired. It's great to hear you're open to creating this kind of support system. As you move forward, remember that this process is about discovery and growth, and it's okay to take it one step at a time. From attending virtual panels to reaching out and reflecting in your journal, you're building a path toward finding a fulfilling career. You’re making thoughtful decisions, and that’s truly empowering. Whenever you need encouragement, remember that you're not alone. Looking forward to hearing about what you discover!
Thanks, I appreciate the support and guidance. I’ll definitely try to take it one step at a time and see how it goes.

concern:
title: Do not forget: College is a business.
Always remember that college is a business and it does not have your best interest in mind. 

Most people go to college to study something they like and then they try to find a job. THIS IS THE WRONG APPROACH!!…

The right approach is to find a job that u would like to do in the future and then decide which is the path of least resistance that can get u there. 

Remember: Going to college is a financial decision before anything else. 

Bonus Advice: Advisor are not reliable, free online PDF books exist and most employers do not care about the school u when.

dialogue.statement: Hello! What would you like to talk about today? I'm here to listen and understand your story.

Hey, thanks for being here. I've been really stressed about my summer math class and trying to figure out if I should stick with it or drop out. It's just been a lot to handle with everything else going on.
Managing all those commitments sounds overwhelming. What about the math class is most stressful for you right now?
client: Honestly, it's just that math is really tough for me, especially online. I can't seem to get the hang of it through videos, and it's making me anxious.

Navigating online learning can definitely bring its own challenges, especially when the subject feels tough. You might be feeling anxious because the mode of learning isn't aligning with how you learn best. How has this stress been affecting you day-to-day?
client: It's been taking a toll on my focus and motivation. I find myself getting easily frustrated and it's hard to concentrate on anything else when I'm worried about falling behind.

dialogue.statement: I hear that this situation is affecting both your concentration and motivation. It's understandable to feel frustrated when you're worried about keeping up. client: Honestly, I'd say around a 4 or 5. I feel pretty torn and it's hard to see how I can manage both without sacrificing something important.

concern:
title: Should I drop out of my Summer class?
I (20f) only have to do one more math class to get my general 2 year degree, however all the summer classes at my community college are only online for summer quarter. Math is my worst subject so this is very alarming, but I signed up for one online however I'm finding it extremely difficult to grasp the concepts through videos, and typing my answers is extremely stressful. There are a lot of really good in person classes for the fall, but my parents are really looking forward to me graduating by the end of Summer.

My goal is to be hired and go to the police academy by fall and be graduated by August. I don't need a degree to be hired, but it would look better on my application and possibly give me a small pay boost if I'm hired. I really don't want to disappoint my family, but at the same time I'm very concerned and don't want to end up failing. I also need to build muscle for the physical test, but I haven't had the time due to work and classes. I've never been good at online classes (my grades were the worst during the pandemic) and the tutors at my college seem very busy when I go there. What's the right thing to do?

Edit: Thank you all so much. I'm going to try and power through it. :)

dialogue.statement: Hello! It’s nice to meet you. How can I support you today?
Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I've just been feeling pretty lost and unsure about the direction of my studies and future career, you know?
It must be really overwhelming to feel lost about such important aspects of your life. What's been on your mind when you think about your studies and career?

client: Yeah, it's definitely overwhelming. I've been having a lot of doubts about whether I'm on the right path with this non-clinical psychology program and what kind of job prospects I'll even have when it's all over. It feels like I’m stuck in a loop of uncertainty.

concern:
title: Job prospects for a non-clinical masters or PhD in psychology?
Originally I did not want to go to school for non-clinical degree but after much discussion with advisors i ended up in a non-clinical psychology phd.  I have regular doubts about if this was the right choice.  

Currently have almost completed the masters portion of my program.  

It honestly feels like the longer i am here the more I doubt my decision to come here.  I feel like I had a lot of passion prior to coming here that school has now squashed.  

I was always encouraged to just pursue my area of interest and I think the general area of research i am interested in but it i feel like I was deceived about the nature of the program and the research I would be allowed to do.

Its never been clear exactly what job prospects exist and anytime i talk to someone I get told wildly different things and I dont really know what to believe anymore.

Anyways any thoughts are much appreciated.  Thank you for your time.

I guess it's mostly the pressure of trying to pick a major and feeling like I need to have a clear path. Everyone seems so focused and determined, and I just feel like I'm floating around without a direction.

It's understandable to feel that way when there's so much pressure to decide your future. It can feel like you're being pulled in different directions. What thoughts or experiences have been influencing your feelings about choosing a major?

I think it's the fear of making the wrong choice and ending up unhappy or wasting my time. There's also this expectation to find something I'm passionate about, but I don't feel particularly drawn to anything specific.

concern:
title: Feeling lost
Just started my first semester of college this spring because I felt lost and left behind in the fall, now that I’m here I am realizing that I have no plan for anything going forward. It feels like Everyone around me very meticulously plotting their next step while I am jumping before thinking. I am leaning towards majoring in business or history but I’m sure that’s not what I really want to do. I feel lost and confused and like this is the hardest part of my life. I don’t know where to go or where to turn. Everyone who I try to talk to this about is unable to help in any way other than telling me it’s okay. I just don’t know what I am doing or where I am going and don’t want to feel like I have wasted time and money I’ll never get back. I’m so unsure about what I want to do that it’s scary and effecting my mental health.

dialogue.statement: Hello there! What would you like to talk about today?
Hey! I've been feeling kind of lost and directionless this summer. It's like I have all this time and no idea what to do with it.
That sounds really challenging, having all this time but feeling unsure about how to spend it. What do you think has contributed to this feeling of being directionless?

client(exploring): I think it's because I'm used to having a set schedule with school, and without it, I feel like I'm not making progress. Plus, the pressure to figure out my career path is kind of overwhelming.

Adjusting from a structured school schedule to a more open summer can definitely leave you feeling unanchored. The extra pressure of needing to decide on a career path adds another layer of complexity. How have you tried to manage these feelings so far?
I've mostly been trying to keep myself busy with small tasks and hobbies, but it doesn't feel like enough. I sometimes just end up overthinking everything, which isn't super helpful.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a comprehensive view of her struggles, including feelings of aimlessness, pressure to define a career path, and the impact of structural changes. She has expressed fears about transitioning from academia to practical applications of her skills and highlighted her anxiety over an unfamiliar environment. Rapport has been built through understanding her context. Moving to the Guiding phase is appropriate to strengthen motivation for change and evoke Change Talk. The exploration phase has effectively addressed her experiences and feelings, laying a solid foundation for deeper engagement. OARS feedback: The reflections and affirmations were effective in fostering a comfortable space for the client to share her feelings.

dialogue.statement: Staying busy with small tasks and hobbies shows you're trying to cope, which is a great step. When you think about making a change, what would you like to see different in your life or how you feel?

client(guiding): I guess I'd like to feel more secure in my choices and be more okay with not having everything figured out right now. It'd be nice to find a balance where I'm not constantly stressing about the future.
Finding that sense of security and balance sounds valuable. What might it look like for you to feel more at ease with not having everything figured out just yet?

client(guiding): I think it would mean being more present and accepting things as they come, rather than trying to plan every detail. Allowing myself to enjoy the now without the constant urge to plan ahead might help too.

Embracing the present and letting go of the need to plan every detail sounds quite freeing. How confident do you feel, on a scale from 0 to 10, about gradually adopting this mindset and allowing yourself to enjoy the moment more?
client(reflecting): Hmm, I'd say maybe a 5 or 6. I know it's something I want to do, but actually letting go of that control and worry is easier said than done.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a specific desire to feel more secure in their choices and to find balance, which indicates a readiness for change. They have identified wanting to be more present and reduce anxiety, showing insight into their desired change. client(reflecting): Maybe setting small goals or practicing mindfulness could help. I think if I see progress in little steps, it might make it easier to trust the process and feel less anxious about the future.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire for change, with a specific goal of adopting a more present and relaxed mindset. statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire to feel more secure and balanced, and has identified specific strategies such as setting small goals and practicing mindfulness to address their anxiety about the future. concern:
title: Is anyone else struggling with feeling aimless during summer?
Hi there, 20F here
Just wondering how you all fare during the summer. My last final was three weeks ago, and I just finished junior year. I work very hard and do well in school, but once it ends and I go from a rigid structure to nothing I feel disoriented and directionless.

Part of it is that I feel the need to be constantly making progress. Another part is that I am pressuring myself to be figuring out my career path, because I hate not knowing exactly what I want to do. I'm good at school, but I'm also afraid that I won't be good at working and applying my skills to practical situations.

Some of these fears are irrational--I've worked before, I've done great and I've discovered some aspects of my career that I like and dislike. I want to explore the medical field but I'm not sure if I could be hired for only 3-4 months as an entry level worker and then leave to go back to school.

Basically summer gives me lots of generalized anxiety about my life and future that I don't have time to stew on during the school year. I know the obvious solution is to make arrangements for summer plans ahead of time so I don't run into this, but I had a short term change in my living situation and so I'm in a new place away from my university and feeling like everything is unfamiliar.

So much empty time and I'm not sure what to do with it.

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's good to meet you. Feel free to share what's been on your mind lately or any challenges you might be facing. I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can.
Hey! Thanks for meeting with me. Lately, I've been thinking about whether I should go back to college or not. I dropped out before, and I'm worried about failing again and disappointing everyone.

It's understandable to feel concerned about the possibility of disappointment, especially when it's something important to you. What was your experience like when you were in college before, and what led you to decide to leave?

client(exploring): It was pretty tough, to be honest. I was studying psychology, and I felt really overwhelmed with the workload. I guess I just didn't handle it well and ended up leaving because I couldn't keep up.

That sounds really challenging, feeling overwhelmed with the workload can be quite difficult to manage. What aspects of the workload did you find most overwhelming, and how did that impact your decision to leave at the time?

It felt like everything was piling up too fast, like the reading and assignments. I started falling behind and then just felt like I couldn't catch up, which made me panic and doubt if I could even do it.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared significant details about their past college experience, including feelings of being overwhelmed and concerns about disappointing others. There's a deep understanding of their previous challenges and current apprehensions. Empathy and rapport have been established with the client, and there is a clear goal to explore the possibility of returning to college. Moving to the Guiding phase is appropriate to begin strengthening the client's motivation for change and evoking change talk. The exploration phase's use of reflective listening was effective in understanding the client's story and concerns.

dialogue.statement: It must have been tough to feel like you were constantly trying to keep up and still falling behind. When you think about the possibility of going back now, what parts of going back to college excite you, and what might be your biggest concerns?

The idea of learning about something I'm interested in and potentially getting my degree excites me. But I'm really worried about the workload again and the fear of not being able to handle it, even if I try harder this time.

Balancing excitement with concerns is a normal part of considering such a significant decision. What strengths do you think you have now that could help you manage the workload differently if you choose to return to college?
I think I've become a bit more self-aware about how I learn and manage my time. Plus, I know I can ask for help if I need it now, which I didn't really do before.

Recognizing your growth in self-awareness and knowing when to seek help are valuable strengths. How might these insights shape your approach to managing the workload if you decide to go back to college?

I guess I'd try to be more proactive about asking for help when things start to get overwhelming, instead of waiting until it's too late. I could also try to set up a better schedule for studying and assignments so I don't fall behind like last time.

client(choosing): I guess I could reach out to the school and set up a meeting with an advisor in the next couple of weeks. It'd be good to gather all the info before making a decision about reapplying, so maybe aiming for sometime this semester sounds doable.

client(choosing): I could set reminders on my phone to keep me on track and maybe check in with a friend or family member about my progress. Having someone to talk to about it might help keep me motivated and accountable.

dialogue.statement: Setting phone reminders and involving a friend or family member to check in are great ways to maintain motivation and accountability. concern:
title: Tips for potentially going back to college?
I dropped out in my second year of psychology coz it was quite hard. Looking back I think while yes it was hard I definitely didn’t put in as much effort as I could have. Oops. I’m wanting to potentially go back and try again but I’m worried it will in fact be too hard even if I try really hard this time. I don’t think I could deal with everyone’s disappointment in me for a second time. Should I reapply for next year? Or does anyone have any degree suggestions similar to psych that may not be “as intense”? 
Cheers!

title: Should I change my major? Need Help!

concern:
title: So I’ve started college but I want a change
I’m a first year student who’s recently finished summer school and overall I’ve enjoyed my time at university, but I honestly don’t think it’s for me. That’s not to say that I want to drop out, but I was hoping to get a full time job and take classes online instead. Also, I don’t have a car or any other sort of transportation besides walking or being driven around by a relative’s vehicle, so honestly, I don’t have reliable transportation when I’m at school. This is why I’d rather stay at home. 

Anyway, if that doesn’t work, I was thinking about just going back to cc (which was supposed to happen in the first place), but my family is pretty against me doing that and believe that I would be selling myself short by doing so. I’ve also considered dropping out as well because the major that I have chosen doesn’t seem to be a proper choice and it may not help me in the long run (elementary education). I’d rather not waste anyone’s time and money, you know? 

Then also there are some things in my personal life that I haven’t shared with my family and I’m unsure that if it ever comes up in conversation or I decide to tell them, then they’ll stop helping me pay for school. That’s why I wanted to get a job just in case something were to happen and they decide not to help anymore. 

Not sure what to do anymore :(

concern:
title: How To Manage My Classes?
Hello, I’m currently taking 2 online classes while I work full time at a community college. I’m excited that I’m going to college but it’s getting really hard to the point that I’m falling behind in both classes. I have an F and a D in both classes (Art and Math). I’m afraid that even if I pass these classes, I would have to cram all my work. Like I don’t want to my foundational thinking to be screwed or messed up in my future college classes.

I plan to transfer to a 4 year, the music class is a class necessary for the transfer while the math is not, but it is a prerequisite to the class that will transfer so I’m more worried about that. Should I drop the music class? Or am I just being overwhelmed by the such limited time I have to do assignments? I’m also assuming that since both classes are online, theres more of a workload since my professors are giving me everything all at once? I’m in my early 20’s and I’m having to do a bit of extra time and effort to make up what I’ve lost especially in my math class.

My goal is to pass with A’s but I feel that in order to do so, I would need to cram all the work in and not actually “learn” or “retain” the information for future classes. Has anyone had a rough start to college even if it’s online?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's nice to have you here. What's on your mind today?

client(guiding): I guess maybe starting with setting specific times for studying and breaks could help. Also, trying to prioritize tasks instead of attempting to tackle everything at once might make it feel less overwhelming. Maybe even just finding time for things I enjoy could help with the stress.

Having specific times for studying and taking breaks, along with prioritizing tasks, sounds like a great approach to easing some of the overwhelm. How do your values and goals align with taking these steps towards balance and stress management?

I really value doing well in school because I want to get into med school, but I also know that taking care of my mental health is crucial if I want to succeed in the long run. Finding that balance is important to me because I don’t want to burn out before even getting to my goal.

concern:
title: How do you get through college while dealing with mental illness?
Just looking for advice/tips/anything. 
I been struggling with depression and stuff since high school, and now since starting college I’ve had pretty bad anxiety, too. I also just have a couple other issues. 

It all really gets in the way of doing good in school, even though I’m on meds and found a therapist, I’m just constantly struggling. 

I want to go to med school so bad but I genuinely think I won’t be able to because it’s so hard for me to keep my grades up and do even decent in all my classes. I hate the thought of having to give up my dream because of this.

client(exploring): Honestly, I think it's the pressure to do well and not let anyone down. Plus, seeing other people manage just fine makes me feel like I'm failing somehow.

concern:
title: Nobody tells you how hard it is when you get into your dream school but can’t go because of finances
My family is in that area where we’re too rich for fafsa, but too poor to pay for college in its entirety. I know it’s a first world problem, but it still sucks.

Edit- should’ve clarified, but I want to transfer to my dream school for the last 2 years. I’m a sophomore rn at a public school which I don’t really like.

dialogue.statement: Hello! Feel free to share what's on your mind. I'm here to listen and help explore your thoughts and feelings.

Hey, thanks for being here. I've just been really stressed about choosing between going to a community college or a four-year university. It's tough because I want the full college experience, but I also feel guilty about the financial strain it might put on my family.

Choosing between those options seems to be weighing heavily on you. You're drawn to the full college experience, but you're also concerned about the financial implications for your family. Can you share more about what the full college experience means to you?

client: Yeah, I guess it's like, you know, living on campus, meeting new people, being part of something bigger. It's kinda like the adventure and independence I've been looking forward to. But at the same time, what if I'm being selfish for wanting that when it might cause problems at home?

It sounds like you're craving adventure, independence, and a sense of belonging that comes with being part of something bigger. At the same time, you're worried if seeking this could inadvertently create challenges for your family. What have you considered so far in terms of balancing these desires with your family's needs?

I've thought about maybe starting at a community college to save money and then transferring to a four-year university later. But then I think about missing out on the traditional college start, and it just feels like such a hard choice. I'm not sure what the right balance is.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared the core essence of their story, highlighting their desire for adventure and independence, balanced against financial concerns and familial responsibilities. The therapist effectively used open questions and reflections to elicit deeper exploration of these feelings and thoughts. The client has also begun to discuss potential solutions, indicating readiness to explore motivation for change. Thus, it is appropriate to move to the Guiding phase to further strengthen motivation and evoke change talk. Well, if I start at a community college, I imagine I'd be living at home longer and maybe not as involved in the campus life stuff at first. But later, when I transfer, maybe I could still get some of that experience then. On the other hand, starting at a university feels like jumping straight into everything I’ve been dreaming about.

It sounds like you're envisioning different paths with their own unique experiences and challenges. concern:
title: Community or 4 year University

I would love to go to any of those but after a conversation with my parents I’m starting to consider community as I also have 3 other siblings and my parents don’t know if they can pay for all of us. I’m so torn between it, I want to get the freshman experience and leave town but I don’t know if I’ll ever forgive myself for my parents being in debt or my siblings not being able to attend college. concern:
title: I don’t want to leave College yet.
I’ve been feeling really conflicted lately about graduating. I graduate in just a few weeks, but I have had such a blast this semester and made so many friends whom I feel actually care about me. I have depression but this is the happiest I’ve ever been. It may be silly and stupid to want to stay another semester to be with my friends, but I’m really afraid of growing apart from them especially since I live multiple states away from everyone. I’ve been wondering if I should take a minor in Graphic Design (Which is something I’ve been interested in for a while now) but I just don’t know if in the long run it would be worth it. Has anyone else been in this situation before and has some advice?

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you in exploring whatever is on your mind. What's been going on lately?

Hey, thanks for being here. I've just been feeling really overwhelmed with starting college and adjusting to everything new. It's like there's so much to handle and I'm worried I won't be able to keep up with it all.

Starting college is a big transition, and it's understandable to feel overwhelmed with all the changes and responsibilities. What are some specific aspects of this new experience that are weighing on you the most?

client: It's mostly the classes and the workload that's stressing me out. I've got Bio and Chem right off the bat, and I'm just scared it's going to be way too much. Plus, being away from my parents and everything familiar is really tough.

Balancing challenging classes like Bio and Chem right from the start can indeed feel daunting. Being away from your parents and familiar surroundings adds another layer to the stress. How are you finding ways to cope with these feelings and the workload so far?

client(exploring): Honestly, I'm not really sure how to cope yet. It's like I'm just trying to take it day by day, but it feels like there's always something new to worry about. I haven't quite figured out a routine or strategy that works for me yet.

concern:
title: Does anyone else feel overwhelmed with college?
It’s my 2nd day being a Freshman on campus just moving in and honestly I feel so overwhelmed. I’m overwhelmed with worrying about my classes and being in a new environment and missing my parents :( I got placed in both Bio and Chem and I’m scared it will be too much and I’m going to fail. I keep hearing all these stories of people barely keeping up and having to study late into the night. Also how my professors say for every hour of class, study for 2 outside of class, that will lead me to have to study for around 17 hours cause my labs are quite long (not even counting my 2 other classes). I’m worried I won’t have any free time or life outside of college to pursue my hobbies or just have a life in general. Does anyone have any words of advice of words of comfort, im straight up not having a good time right now :(

Thank you for reading this

I’m from Connecticut and used to a suburban lifestyle. I enjoy having the option of driving my car places. I thought the New York lifestyle would be something new and exciting for me because it’s something i’ve always dreamed of, however I just don’t seem to fit in. However, New York is an amazing place for opportunities, especially in the art field, and I’m wondering if i’m throwing away my dream/ chances at a good job by moving back to Connecticut to go to an art school there? I don’t know what jobs would be available for me in CT, and i’m worried i’ll fail and not make money if I move back there. concern:
title: afraid of no college experience at cc pls don’t hate
i start my freshmen year of community college this month and im looking forward to it but also not since i already know the bad that comes from it. for ex: 

•no social life 
•NO COLLEGE EXPERIENCE 
•possibility of having a full class with middle aged parents/ business workers that randomly wanted to be in school again
• watching all my friends and mutuals have fun at their university that i also wanna attend to etc.
•being stuck in my room doing nothing etc 

i personally want to go to community for just one year then transfer and i know it’s harder that way if you don’t get your full 60 credits and transfer as a junior but why would i want to waste all my time at cc and possibly only have 1.5 years to enjoy myself at a uni??? community isn’t best for me but im only doing it because my high school gpa would not have gotten me into a uni and i do regret it because i skipped a lot or had very very bad mental health days so now i have to deal with the consequences and so community is really my only route for right now. and it sucks knowing that I won’t have the experience i want I know you’re thinking “the experience isn’t the main important thing just transfer in 2 years it’s not big deal plUs yOuR SavIng moNey” yeah I’ve read other reddit threads of teens expressing their same feelings that i have and it’s a bunch of the middle aged adults saying the same thing. let’s be honest here im 18 and so are the other peers that feel this way that are around the ages of 17-23 ofc we want to live a little and are pissed about having to be at community while everyone else is having fun. also you may know this but for some people university is their only escape route from home/toxic homes/ or just tired of being in their city cause they’ve been their all they’re life. it’s hardening to see and also i don’t live close to my community at all so it’s gonna be HELL trying to get there and back, my parents don’t own a car and i don’t trust a uber either. i just know this is gonna be one hell of a first year. any advice on how to deal through this? how i can make friends easier? IF i do end up having to do 2 years how should i get through it? what did you do?

concern:
title: Weird professor. not sure what to do
i’m a 4th year student and i’m taking a class that’s required for graduation with a professor i took 2 summers ago for an online class. that summer i had a rough time and was going through some things, and my professor was very understanding and kind. he was quick to respond to emails and worked with giving me extensions and stuff, and after the class ended we periodically emailed about school and life and i always thought he was very kind and compassionate. he has great ratings on rate my professor and up until now i have never felt uncomfortable or creeped out by him. as time went on, the emails from him became more consistent and long. this man would write me novels and send random “how are you doing” at 12 and 1am. well, last spring he recommended me for a scholarship and to be in a mentor program and one day i was on campus and decided to stop by his class quickly to formally introduce myself in person and thank him for the opportunity. i then received and email almost immediately after and one of the BOLD captions was “Meeting you: please do not be offended” and he went on to talk about how beautiful i was on the inside and out and how my eyes were beautiful (all in the school email, and i was wearing a mask). fast forward to now, i have him in person on mondays and wednesdays and in class yesterday he was staring at my the entire lecture and he emailed me today and was talking about my looks and that he “loved” seeing me in class. sometimes if i take too long to reply to the emails he will say something like “i miss our emails” like bro is down bad and also married with 4 kids. the biggest downfall is that i have had many opportunities open up because of his recommendations and i plan on going to law school and could really use him for that but i also have an entire semester of class with him and i feel like he’s undressing me with his eyes every time i see him so i don’t know what to do 🥴

concern:
title: what are good coping skills for college when your personal life is affecting you emotionally and mentally causing poor academic performance?
I didn't do so well during this semester due to my personal life issues. It affected me mentally and emotionally causing me to do poorly in school. What are good coping skills for college when feeling this way? I want to improve my mentally health for next semester

dialogue.statement: Hi there! Feel free to share anything that's on your mind. I'm here to listen and support you.

Hey! Thanks for listening. I've been feeling kinda stuck and overwhelmed lately, like I'm running out of time in college to do everything I want to do, even though I know there's still a lot of time left. It's just a weird mix of emotions, I guess.

Balancing your goals in college with the feeling of time slipping away can indeed feel overwhelming. You’re experiencing this blend of eagerness to achieve and concern about running out of time. What are some of the things you're hoping to accomplish?

client(exploring): I want to make more friends and get out of my comfort zone a bit more. I also feel like I should be more focused on my career path and maybe get some internships or research experience, but it's tough to balance everything.

Wanting to expand your social circle while also focusing on your career path sounds like a lot to juggle. You're feeling this pull between stepping out for new experiences and ensuring you're on track with your career. How have you been managing these different goals so far?

client(exploring): I've been trying to join clubs and meet people through mutual interests, but I haven't really gone all in, you know? I've also been looking into internships and part-time jobs, but it's hard to commit when I'm still figuring out what I want. It's a bit of trial and error right now.

statement.reasoning: The client's narrative around feeling stuck and overwhelmed in college has been effectively explored, highlighting their internal conflict between socializing and career focus. Empathy is evident through reflections on their feelings and goals, while open questions encouraged elaboration. However, there's a need to deepen understanding of their coping mechanisms and potential barriers before advancing. Continuing in the Exploring phase could further clarify these aspects and strengthen the foundation for change.

client(exploring): I enjoy meeting people who share similar interests because it makes starting conversations easier, and I like learning about different career paths when I look into internships. But I find it challenging to fully commit because I'm scared of making the wrong choice and wasting time.

statement.reasoning: The client's story has been well-elicited, covering thoughts and feelings about their mid-college crisis, time management concerns, and balancing social and career goals. Empathy has been shown, and rapport is demonstrated through understanding their eagerness and concerns. The client has clearly articulated their goals and dilemmas, making it appropriate to move to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation and evoke Change Talk about exploring new activities or career paths.

dialogue.statement: It’s great that you enjoy connecting with others and exploring different career paths. It seems the fear of making the wrong decision may be holding you back a bit. If you imagine having more clarity or confidence in your choices, how might that change things for you?

Visualizing yourself with greater confidence and openness to new experiences sounds liberating. Taking more risks might lead to exciting opportunities and growth. What small step could you take that aligns with this vision, and how might it impact your journey?

Your plan to attend more club events and connect with new people, along with applying for internships, is a thoughtful step toward feeling more empowered. How do you feel about taking this approach, and what difference might it make in your sense of control and progress?

client(guiding): I feel pretty good about it, actually. Taking small steps seems manageable and less overwhelming. It might help me break out of this feeling of being stuck and give me a sense of direction and progress, even if it's just a little at a time.

concern:
title: Mid-college crisis?
Hi. I hope I can explain this correctly. I just have this weird feeling and I'm wondering if anyone is experiencing the same. 

I'm a sophomore. It's my second semester (as I'm sure it is for most). I did my first freshman semester at an online community college, then transferred to university. I'm at a weird "mid-college" crisis, I guess? It feels like time has just flashed by; I'm already almost a junior. But, at the same time, I'm only almost a junior, if that makes sense. It feels like I don't have much time left in my college career, but also, I know that realistically, I have at least two years (especially since I'm considering grad school) left. I'm literally only 19, and I also know that I have a lot of time after college to experience life before I decide to settle down, but I also feel like I've not taken advantage of the time I've had before. 

It's weird. I'm in a weird spot with my credits, and have been relentlessly pushing myself to fix the situation, so it feels like I haven't really experienced the less-academically-important-but-equally-mentally-important (in my opinion) aspect of socialization as much as I should have. I don't have many friends, but recently, for whatever reason, I've been really trying to get out of my shell and explore new things and make new friends. I don't know what came over me to do this, and I kinda wish I did this sooner. I guess I always thought it would happen naturally. I dunno. In high school, as a sophomore, I couldn't wait to graduate and be done. But now, as a sophomore in college, I feel the same, but I also simultaneously feel the opposite. I don't really want to join a frat or anything, and I've met people from mutual hobbies and clubs (as well as recently meeting up with some people from my university Discord server), but I dunno. I feel like I should've done more, and now that I'm approaching upper division college, I'll need to focus more on career and professional stuff. 

Is this weird? Does anyone feel the same or have had similar experiences?

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? I'm here to listen and understand more about what's been going on for you.

That sounds incredibly challenging, especially when you expected things to go smoothly. What's been happening with your PhD advisor and the lab switch that makes you feel like it's all falling apart?

It's like my current advisor is actively trying to sabotage my efforts. I thought I had the chance to move to another lab, but something went wrong after they talked to my current advisor, and now I'm back to square one.

Having that sense of relief and freedom seems important for your well-being and success. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding that support and making the lab switch happen?
client(guiding): Right now, I'd say maybe a 3 or 4. I don't feel super confident because of what just happened, but I'm hoping there's still a chance to turn things around with the right help.

concern:
title: Advice - PI Preventing Me From Changing Labs
Hi all! So I've been trying to change labs for a bit now. My relationship with my advisor has gone from bad to worse and the relationship can no longer be salvaged. For the past few months, my PI has repeated refused to support any accomplishment or research venture I had. The PI doesn't even fund any part of my PhD as I am a fellow in a dry lab with no resource costs. Even my conferences, poster printing, and publications I've had to pay for out of pocket. 

Recently, I began speaking to a new PI in my department about changing to their lab. They were initially supportive of it but just wanted to make sure things were cool with my current PI before I changed. I let my current PI know I was planning on changing labs and made the commitments to finish up all the pending work on a paper I was working on with them as a corresponding before leaving the lab. The current PI said they understood and supported the move. This was surprising but didn't think anything else of it. A few days past and now the new PI has pulled back their support after speaking to my current PI. I spoke to my current PI today and they sounded pleased with themselves regarding me not being able to leave. They gave me an ultimatum which drastically limits my dissertation if I wanted to stay in their lab after all of this. I'm sure the current PI (who is know for being petty and spiteful) meddled and prevented my change from going through. 

The lab I was hoping to change into is the closest to what I'd like to do for my PhD at my school. My current PI has essentially put me being a rock and a hard place, making me chose between either continuing under them with major re-shifting of my dissertation, or leaving the program entirely. I don't know how I can possibly salvage the relationship with the other PI I wanted to change to in the hopes of changing to them still. It feels like I'm a prisoner of my PI. Any advice?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It seems like you might have something on your mind. Would you like to share a bit about what's going on with you today?
Hey, yeah, I've been feeling kinda stuck about picking a major for uni. My parents and I have different ideas about what I should study, and it's stressing me out.
Choosing a major can be overwhelming, especially when you feel caught between your own interests and your parents' expectations. What are some of the ideas you and your parents have been discussing?

client(exploring): Well, I'm really interested in engineering, especially mechatronics, but my parents think it might be too hard for me and want me to study English instead. They think it would be an easier option for me.

It sounds like you're passionate about engineering and mechatronics, but there's also concern from your parents about the difficulty. What draws you to mechatronics, and how do you feel about their suggestion of studying English?

I've always been fascinated by how things work and the idea of building and creating through engineering really excites me. As for studying English, I think it's interesting too, and I am good at it, but it feels like more of a safe choice rather than what I'm truly passionate about.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their struggle with choosing a major, balancing personal interests, parental expectations, and financial concerns. There is a clear understanding of the client's thoughts and feelings, including their passion for engineering and concerns about financial burden. Empathy and rapport have been established, with mutual goals emerging around finding a path that aligns with the client's interests and circumstances. Moving to the Guiding phase can help strengthen motivation and evoke Change Talk to explore options further.

dialogue.statement: It's clear that engineering sparks a real excitement in you, and it's understandable to feel that English might be more of a comfort zone. How do you envision your life differently if you were to pursue mechatronics versus English?

If I went with mechatronics, I see myself really diving into projects, maybe even working on something innovative and being proud of what I create. On the other hand, with English, I think I'd end up in a stable job, maybe teaching, but it might not feel as fulfilling or exciting to me.

It's wonderful to hear how vividly you imagine yourself thriving in mechatronics, with projects that could bring you a sense of achievement. Comparing that to a stable yet perhaps less fulfilling path in English, what does this tell you about what you truly value in your career and life?

client(guiding): I guess it shows that I value creativity and innovation, and I want to feel proud and excited about the work I'm doing. Stability is important too, but I don't want to settle for something that feels like just going through the motions.

Your desire for creativity and innovation really shines through, and it's great to see how much importance you place on feeling proud of your work. Considering these values, how might they influence your decision-making when choosing between a path of excitement versus one of stability?

client(guiding): I think these values push me more towards choosing the exciting path with mechatronics, even if it seems challenging. I want to take a chance on something that could be really fulfilling for me, rather than just playing it safe.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear discrepancy between their passion for mechatronics and the stability of studying English, highlighting the importance of creativity and innovation over mere stability. Change Talk is present, as the client is leaning towards the more challenging path of mechatronics despite parental concerns. The client also acknowledges the influence of family expectations and financial considerations, showing a nuanced understanding of their situation. Given these insights and the client's expressed willingness to pursue a fulfilling path, it's appropriate to move to the Choosing phase to develop actionable plans.

dialogue.statement: Choosing a major is such a significant step, and it's inspiring to hear your commitment to pursuing something fulfilling. Considering your passion for mechatronics, how would you like to proceed in setting a goal or action plan for exploring this path further? Perhaps researching programs or speaking with professionals in the field might be options to consider.

client(choosing): Yeah, I think researching programs would be a good start, maybe seeing what courses would be like and what kind of projects I could work on. Talking to someone already in the field sounds useful too, to get a real sense of what it's like and maybe advice on how to prepare for it.

Exploring programs and connecting with professionals both sound like excellent steps. Which one would you like to start with, or do you have other ideas in mind? Identifying potential challenges, like time management or finding resources, and how you'll address them can help along the way.

I think I'll start with researching programs, getting a sense of what the coursework and projects entail. After that, I can try reaching out to someone in the field. As for challenges, I know I need to work on my time management, so maybe setting a study schedule or finding a mentor could help me stay on track.

Setting a study schedule and finding a mentor are great strategies to support your journey. How will you go about researching the programs, and what steps might you take to find a potential mentor? If any barriers come to mind, we can brainstorm ways to overcome them.

concern:
title: how did you guys choose your major?
so apparently, I finished my exams and got 84%. in my country, applying to universities depends on the mark you get. apparently I really don't know what should I do. I don't like med school so we leave this option behind. I'm interested in engineering, literally any engineering field but specifically rn I have mechatronics engineering in mind. my parents on the other hand don't really support my decision about engineering. universities are completely free, except for the private universities of course. my parents want to get me into a private university but tbh my family is not that financially stable and my parents already have plans of moving out of our apartment, get a house and a new car. I really don't want to trouble them with my uni fees especially that they've spent 7000$ on my tuitions and school stuff. my boyfriend is saying that this is an opportunity that I shouldn't miss but he doesn't get it, his family is rich and they plan on sending him to study medicine in another country so he doesn't understand why I feel so guilty. my mom said I should study English and since I'm already good at it I won't have much trouble. to me, I'm flexible, I don't mind studying anything but it's still a hard decision to make

edit: I really didn't think anyone would notice this post but I need to thank you all. I read every single comment and they're all so helpful. the reason I don't have a major in my mind is because I'm good at any subject in hand and maybe, just maybe because my parents always decided everything on my behalf lol. My parents are against engineering is because they believe I'm a lazy one and won't be able to put up with how hard it is all because of my high school grades (apparently i have adhd and depression but im off meds which affected my grades). I know there's nothing like an easy major and that's what I've been trying to tell them but yeah. my mother only suggested studying English so I could be an English teacher. i mentioned that in my country we can apply to universities depending on our marks, the less you get the less options you have. also studying in another country or in another city in my country is not an option lol. again, thanks a lot for your help

concern:
title: Stressing out over inconsistent grading
I did really well as an undergrad. If I put the effort in and listened to feedback, I'd get a good grade. If I tried to wing it, I'd get a bad grade. I got a top mark on my dissertation that year and felt good going into my masters.

I'm at a new uni this year and my grades are always either very high or very low. I was just given feedback on a presentation I did, and one of the comments left for me was that I should be more thoughtful as a grad student, with no further context. I was also marked down for following the outline provided to us and not adding additional slides, which we weren't asked to do. This was one of 3 assignments we were given over Christmas, during which time staff were on leave and not answering emails. I'm losing respect for my instructors, and I am kind of dreading beginning my dissertation. This presentation was a proposal for my dissertation, and based on the grading, my advisor and the instructor who grades the papers are not on the same page.

I don't know if I'm just being a baby over this, but I feel like I can't anticipate what my instructors are looking for and I'm worried about my dissertation. I have a few friends in the class who are getting similar marks and I know they're putting huge efforts into their assignments. At this point, I just want to pass and get my degree.

concern:
title: Engineering —> Psychology
I’m starting university this Fall, in Mechanical Engineering. I chose it because I liked woodworking and metalworking in high school, and thought it’d be a stable career.  

However, I have pretty split interests. Before I settled on an Engineering start, I was also considering English, Political Science, or Psychology. Thinking practically, for my situation I’ve ruled out English and Poli Sci as degree prospects, but am still curious about Psychology.

Only thing is, I’m aware that I might like it in theory, but that it might not be a feasible career. My plan is to explore it as a minor after talking to my advisor, but I’m not sure how close to the actual major that would be. Plus, I’ve had college students tell me that minors in a different field than your major can often deviate your focus.

So Psychology majors, do you think it’s worth such a big switch? Pros and cons of the major?

—

EDIT: Thanks so much everyone for the insight! I see now that a degree in Psychology, while versatile, is most effective with a PhD or some sort of further study behind it, but on its own can be difficult to hold down a career with. I’ll stick with Engineering, but will continue to explore Psych as a minor/hobby, and will look into human psychology aspects of Engineering/A.I. going down the line as well. 

Thanks again, I’m excited to see what comes of this!!

dialogue.statement: Seeing others constantly busy can certainly add pressure to your own expectations. What would it look like if you were able to relax a bit more, and how might that fit with your goals for yourself?

client(guiding): I’d say maybe a 5? I mean, I want to be able to do it, but it’s hard to shake off the feeling that I’m slacking when I’m not working. I guess I just need to figure out a way to actually enjoy relaxing without all that guilt hanging over me.

Making relaxation truly enjoyable without guilt seems like an achievable goal. It's understandable that the feeling of slacking could be a barrier. What small steps might help increase your confidence from a 5 to a higher number?

client(guiding): Maybe starting with setting specific times for breaks could help, like having a planned time to unwind so it feels more like a part of my routine rather than a random decision. I think trying to remind myself that breaks are necessary might also make a difference.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a specific change goal of incorporating planned breaks into their routine to reduce stress and guilt associated with relaxation. They have identified the discrepancy between their behavior and the desire for balance and relaxation. Change Talk is present with a confidence level at 5, indicating room for growth but a clear motivation for change. The client has started exploring possible steps to overcome barriers. Moving to the Choosing phase is appropriate to develop concrete action plans. The reflections and open questions effectively guided the client towards identifying specific strategies.

A planner does seem like a practical way to visualize your schedule and maintain balance. Considering the habit of wanting to keep working, setting reminders could indeed be a gentle nudge to help you respect your break times. How would you like to monitor your progress in maintaining this balanced routine, and who can support you in staying accountable?

I think keeping a little log of how often I stick to the schedule might help me see how well I'm doing and what needs tweaking. Maybe I could also ask a friend to check in with me every now and then, just to make sure I'm actually following through and not falling back into old habits.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear goal of maintaining a balanced routine with dedicated study and relaxation times. They have also developed concrete action steps, such as using a planner and setting reminders. Potential barriers, like the habit of wanting to continue working, have been anticipated, and a strategy for self-monitoring through a log and having a friend's support has been agreed upon. The client shows readiness to take steps towards their goal and confidence in following through, suggesting they are prepared for the next phase.

dialogue.statement: Keeping a log is a wonderful way to track your progress and make any necessary adjustments. It shows your commitment to this new balanced routine. dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today?
