concern:
title: Feeling depressed because I feel burnt out and didn't do as well as I wanted to this semester
I basically just coasted the entire time... I got a 3.0 G.P.A but that isn't good enough for what I want to do... I'm disappointed in myself.

I was going to school fulltime and working full time so I always felt like I had no time for myself and halfway through the semester I got burnt out.

My girlfriend also broke up with me and the break up and my relationships were giving me un needed stress.... I felt like I didn't learn anything at all.

My counselors have said I need to get As in the classes, not Bs... and here I am getting Bs and I feel so dissapointed... I need to do better next time

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?
Hey, thanks for talking with me. I've just been feeling really stuck with my studies this semester. It's like no matter how much I study, nothing seems to stick, and it's getting really frustrating.
It sounds like you're feeling frustrated because you're putting in a lot of effort, but not seeing the results you expect. What's been happening in your life that might be affecting your studies?

client(exploring): Yeah, it's a mix of things, I guess. There's just a lot going on, like trying to balance classes, work, and some personal stuff. I just feel overwhelmed, and it's hard to focus on any one thing.

client(exploring): Honestly, I've been just trying to push through, but it's like running on empty. I'm not sure if it's the best way to handle things, but I don't really know what else to do.

concern:
title: Major Advice
I thought this was a good place to ask for advice on this topic, so here we go. I'm headed into my second year of college at a state school in PA. I am currently in their english department and planned on going into education. I have since changed my mind and I am thinking of going into Pharmacy. However, the school won't let me do the pre-pharmacy program because it was "Designed for freshman". The Pre-Pharmacy program is accelerated and takes a few years off your degree. I told them I was only really interested in pre-pharmacy and they said the best they could do was switch me to chemistry and then I could apply to pharmacy school and hope to get in. Should I keep trying? Am I wrong to think I should be allowed into the program since I've been a student for two years?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It’s nice to meet you. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, nice to meet you too. I've been wrestling with a decision about whether to take this summer internship or just enjoy my summer. I feel like I really need a break after this tough year.
Deciding between an internship and taking a break sounds like a big choice. What are some thoughts or feelings that have been coming up for you as you consider your options?

I'm feeling pretty torn, honestly. On one hand, the internship is a great opportunity and could really help me in the future, but on the other hand, I just crave some downtime and the chance to do things I've been looking forward to. It feels like whatever I choose, I'm giving up something important.

Balancing future opportunities with present needs is indeed challenging. You’re feeling torn because the internship could significantly benefit your career, yet you yearn for a well-deserved break and the freedom to enjoy activities that refresh you. client(exploring): For the internship, it's the experience and the boost it could give my career. But for taking the break, it's more about getting to recharge, spend time with friends, and do things that make me happy right now. Both have their own pull.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a comprehensive view of their dilemma, including the significance of the internship for their career and the need for personal time to recharge. concern:
title: Grad school or Gap Year Abroad?
My main question is pretty obvious from the title, but I’ll give a little more context here. 

I’m about to graduate from undergrad with a BSE in English. I’m also completing a senior thesis and getting certified to teach middle through high school English. Right now I’m looking through graduate schools, prepping for the GRE, and working on thesis, but the more I look into the programs I’m interested in, the more I’m realizing I will likely not be accepted. 

The biggest reason is the language requirement. Most of the programs require fluency in another language upon entry. However, others require it by the end of the first year, meaning you’ll have to start at an intermediate level upon entry. I was originally minoring in Spanish, but for many reasons I won’t go into, I had to drop it. I picked up a Writing Studies minor instead, but now looking at Graduate programs in Comparative Literature/Cultural Studies/etc. that I’m interested in, I know I should’ve gotten that minor in Spanish. However, I don’t have space in my schedule to make up all those credits in my last year. I also can’t afford summer classes. For the few programs that don’t require you to come in fluent, I’d technically only need one other Spanish class to meet their requirements. 

However to top it all off, I’d actually prefer to learn a different language. I would still love to learn Spanish at some point, but my undergrad thesis is focused on Chinese American literature. I’d prefer to focus the rest of my graduate studies on that field. My university only offers French and Spanish, so I’m out of luck there. 

This brings me to my question. Should I apply for graduate programs, cramming in some beginning Chinese program during the summer through CIEE or something similar through my university’s study abroad to bring me to the bare minimum intermediate level? Or should I take a gap year studying abroad to gain a much higher level of fluency, take a break, and give myself more time to consider all my options? I’m afraid of what Graduate admissions will think if I take a year off, and there’s always the possibility that I won’t be accepted or be able to afford a year studying abroad. It could end up being thousands of dollars in debt wasted when I should’ve just gone straight into grad school. 

Any advice is welcome. Even if you think I should suck it up and just take the Spanish course!

dialogue.statement: Hello! What brings you in today? How can I assist you on your journey?

Well, with computer science, I feel like there's a clear job path and financial security, which is super tempting. But with the liberal arts degrees, I feel like they align more with my current interests and might be more enjoyable, but I'm scared about job prospects.

Feeling torn between stability and passion is quite a common struggle. You value the security that comes with computer science because of the clear job path, while the liberal arts resonate with your interests and bring you enjoyment. Could you share more about what specifically excites you about each subject?

With computer science, the idea of building things and solving problems is exciting, plus the tech industry seems pretty dynamic. As for liberal arts, I love understanding different perspectives and exploring topics like culture and identity, it's just really enriching.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed their dilemma between pursuing computer science or liberal arts, highlighting the allure of job security versus personal interest. There's an understanding of the client's context, concerns, and values. The therapist has built rapport and empathy, grasping the essence of the client's story. To move forward, the focus should be on strengthening motivation and evoking Change Talk by exploring the client's deeper values, aspirations, and potential outcomes of each path.

concern:
title: Take an extra semester/year and study computer science, or finish faster and study communications, or black studies + gender/sexualities studies
Hi! I am currently in cc and I will be getting my associates in communications this spring. Should I continue in cc for an extra semester and take some computer science prereqs (specifically for CSUMB or CSUDH), or should I just stick with my communications degree and go somewhere like csulb for communications? I also applied to csueb for black studies (online) and would double concentrate with gender + sexuality studies if I choose to go there. An online degree would be preferable to me since I work full time and don’t drive yet. I think the csulb communications program can be completed online (it says “approved for distance education” so idk what that means). I’d love to finish my degree as soon as possible. I just don’t know what I would do with one of these liberal arts degrees. CS would guarantee me a job. I’m interested in it enough to where I think I can handle the degree, but I don’t know anything more that html and css, so I have no idea how I feel about the more intense stuff. Does anyone have some uplifting success stories for a liberal arts major? Or should I just double down on CS? Literally the only thing I’m worried about with a liberal arts degree is job opportunities. Idk what I can even do with a communications degree!!!!

Please help I’m so stuck and have had a lot of doubt in my current major career wise. I just want some info or reassurance on getting a liberal arts degree, or even reasons I should take more time in school for CS.

TLDR: can either take an extra semester to a year to study comp sci, or finish faster for a liberal arts degree (comm or “identity” studies). What should I choose? Interested enough in both routes. just feeling stuck. Career options?

title: Tips on overcoming burnout + anxiety over previous semester results

On top of that, my ADHD and depression have given me severe memory loss, so i don’t remember much that i did learn. I’m horrible at simple math, i still have to count on my fingers, and i have trouble spelling and sounding words out. I’m just really scared i’m going to look like a dumbass and it makes me not want to go. I was picked on in middle school for having learning troubles and i’m worried it’s going to be the same. That my professors or the students will think i’m stupid. What if they call on me during lecture and i don’t know the answer then everyone thinks i’m dumb lol. Please help, my anxiety is so bad i want to skip my first day.

dialogue.statement: Hello! Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's on your mind or what you would like to talk about today. I'm here to listen and support you.

Hey, thanks. I've been feeling a bit pressured about not having done research during my time in college and wondering if I should try to get into a lab in my last semester or just let it go. It's just been weighing on me, you know?

It sounds like you're caught between the pressure of making the most of your college experience and the option of letting go. What has led you to feel this pressure about not doing research, and how does it affect you?

client: I guess it's because I see so many of my peers getting involved in research and it feels like I'm missing out or falling behind. It makes me doubt if I'm doing enough to prepare for grad school.

You feel uncertain about your future because you notice others participating in research, which leads to concerns about your readiness for grad school. What has your experience in college been like outside of research, and how do you feel about those experiences?

client: I've had a pretty solid experience overall. I've done well in my classes, joined some clubs, and had internships that I've enjoyed. But there's always that little nagging feeling that I'm not measuring up in the research department.

statement.reasoning: The client's story, thoughts, and feelings about research during college have been effectively elicited. Their concerns about feeling left out, self-perceived inadequacies, and achievements outside research have been explored, building empathy and rapport. The client has also shared future plans and hesitations, revealing a comprehensive context. This sets a strong foundation to move to the Guiding phase, where motivation and potential change can be explored further. Adjusting slightly by maintaining this empathetic and affirming approach will be beneficial.

dialogue.statement: You've achieved a lot with your classes, clubs, and internships, which is commendable. It sounds like you're grappling with how research fits into your broader goals for grad school. How do you envision your future if you choose to pursue research now versus focusing on what you've already accomplished?

client(guiding): If I try to get into a lab now, it might give me some peace of mind about not having missed out, but it could also add more stress when I'm already busy. If I focus on what I've done, I'd probably feel more confident with the experience I've gathered, but there’s still that worry about not being on par with others who did research.

Both paths seem to have their own set of advantages and challenges for you. Pursuing a lab position might ease some of those nagging doubts, yet it could also increase your current workload. Conversely, leaning into your existing accomplishments could bolster your confidence, though the concern about research remains. What values or long-term goals do you feel most aligned with, and how might they guide you in choosing the path that feels right for you?

client(guiding): I value learning and gaining experience, but I also want to maintain my mental health and not overload myself. Long-term, I want to go to grad school and have a meaningful career, so I guess I'd want to choose the path that best sets me up for that without sacrificing my well-being.

Your focus on learning and maintaining your mental health is really insightful. Balancing those priorities with your grad school and career goals seems important. How do you see each option contributing to both your personal well-being and your professional journey in the long run?

client(guiding): If I get into a lab now, it might look good on applications and give me some extra research experience, which could definitely help with grad school. But on the flip side, it might be too much to handle on top of everything else and could mess with my stress levels. Sticking with what I've done already gives me a solid foundation, and I think I can still build on that after graduation without wearing myself out now.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear discrepancy between their values of maintaining mental health and gaining experience, and the pressure to engage in research as their peers do. The conversation has explored the implications of both pursuing research now or relying on past accomplishments. The client has expressed a specific change goal of aligning actions with their well-being and future professional aspirations. The client’s confidence appears to be aligning with their existing accomplishments, reflecting a readiness to move forward. Given the presence of Change Talk and decreased ambivalence, it is appropriate to advance to the Choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: Considering both options, you're weighing the potential benefits of lab experience against the importance of your well-being. Would setting a goal around maintaining your current balance while exploring lab opportunities that fit into your schedule feel aligned with what you hope to achieve? Alternatively, focusing on enhancing your existing strengths and planning how to build research experience after graduation could be another path. How do these options resonate with you in terms of setting a specific and manageable goal?

client(choosing): Yeah, I think aiming to keep my balance while being open to any lab opportunities that don't overwhelm me sounds like a good approach. If something fits into my schedule without adding too much stress, I could consider it. At the same time, I feel like building on what I've already accomplished and planning for research after graduation is a solid plan too. It feels like a practical way to move forward without overloading myself.

Both of these plans seem like thoughtful ways to stay true to your values and priorities. As you consider your next steps, how might you develop an action plan to explore lab opportunities that fit your current schedule, while also identifying ways to continue building on your existing strengths? What strategies could you use to monitor stress levels and ensure you're maintaining the balance that's important to you?

client(choosing): I think I could start by reaching out to a few professors again but with a clearer idea of what my time constraints are. I’d be upfront about my availability and only consider positions that seem manageable. To keep track of my stress, maybe I could set regular check-ins with myself or journaling to see how I'm feeling. That way, I can adjust if things start getting overwhelming.

Your plan to clarify your availability with professors and only consider manageable opportunities sounds proactive. Journaling or regular check-ins with yourself to monitor stress levels also seems like a wise strategy to ensure you’re maintaining balance. How do you feel about setting specific times each week to assess your stress and progress towards your goals, and what might be some indicators you'll look out for to help you decide if adjustments are needed?

client(choosing): Setting specific times each week for a check-in sounds like a solid idea. I think I could look out for signs like feeling constantly tired, having trouble focusing, or losing interest in other activities I enjoy. If those start popping up, it might be a cue for me to reassess my workload and priorities.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan to explore manageable lab opportunities and continue building on existing strengths. They've also agreed to self-monitor stress levels with regular check-ins and journaling, indicating readiness to maintain balance. They demonstrate commitment to their chosen path by planning to proactively reach out to professors with clear availability. The client's acceptance of the action plan and strategies for barrier management suggest they are ready for the Terminating phase. OARS feedback: Engaging the client's values and emphasizing self-monitoring strategies helped clarify their goals and boosted their confidence in their choices.

dialogue.statement: Recognizing signs like fatigue, difficulty focusing, or loss of interest as indicators for reassessment is really insightful. Scheduling regular weekly check-ins will help you stay in tune with your stress levels and overall balance. It seems like you're setting yourself up with a supportive framework as you explore lab opportunities that fit your schedule. Remember, it's okay to adjust your plans to protect your well-being. You've already accomplished so much, and this careful approach will only add to your success. Keep trusting yourself and your instincts. You've got this!
Thanks, I really appreciate your support and guidance on this. I'll definitely keep those weekly check-ins in mind and try to stay flexible with my plans. It's good to know I'm on the right track.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a specific plan that aligns with their values and goals, focusing on maintaining balance while exploring lab opportunities. Termination goals have been met, as strategies and next steps are clearly defined.

concern:
title: Do I bother trying to find research my final semester of college?
I’m a dual degree student graduating in May. Due to COVID (yes, we’ve all heard it before) and overcoming some personal struggles, I have yet to work in a campus research lab. I did email some professors over the years, but they either didn’t respond or couldn’t take me on. Now that I’m in my last semester, do I bother trying to get into a research lab or let the subject go? 

I did complete a research internship this past summer and have a research assistant position in the same lab lined up for after graduation in order to prepare for graduate school in a couple years. Many professors won’t take on seniors because they can’t commit long to a project. To be honest, I’m not sure I want to put myself through the stress of finding a lab again, but I feel like a failure for not having participated in research at my school like many of my peers. Any advice?

dialogue.statement: Hello! What brings you in today?
Hey, I've been feeling pretty down lately because I got rejected from the only college I applied to, and I'm not sure what my next steps should be.

That sounds really tough, facing rejection from the only college you applied to. It must feel overwhelming not knowing what to do next. Can you share more about what led you to apply to that particular college?
I really liked their engineering program, and I thought it would be a good fit for me. Plus, they have a high acceptance rate, so I thought I'd have a good chance of getting in.

Your interest in their engineering program shows how much you've thought about your future. It must be hard dealing with the unexpected outcome, especially when you felt the odds were in your favor. What other options or paths have you considered since finding out?
Well, I haven't really thought about any other options yet. I just feel kind of stuck and unsure about whether it’s too late to apply somewhere else or what I should do next.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their feelings of being down and stuck after being rejected from their preferred college, providing context about why they chose it and their concerns about next steps. Empathy and rapport are being built, with the therapist affirming the client’s careful decision-making process and exploring further options. However, the client has not yet expressed clear goals or deeper motivations for change beyond the immediate situation, and more exploration is needed to solidify mutual goals and understand the client's broader aspirations.

dialogue.statement: Feeling stuck and unsure is understandable, given how important this decision is for you. It's never too late to consider other possibilities. Have you thought about what aspects of the engineering program or the college appealed to you the most? Maybe we can explore those together and see if there are similar opportunities elsewhere.

I liked the hands-on approach they offered and the collaborative projects. I also liked the campus vibe and how supportive the community seemed from my visit. I guess I just connected with that place more than I expected to, and now I'm not sure where else to look for something similar.

statement.reasoning: The conversation effectively explored the client's feelings of disappointment and uncertainty after the college rejection. The client shared their interest in the specific engineering program and the appealing aspects of the rejected college. The therapist reflected and affirmed these feelings and strengths while suggesting exploring similar opportunities. Since rapport is strong and the client's story is well understood, it's appropriate to transition to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation for exploring new options.

dialogue.statement: It's understandable to feel a strong connection to a place that aligns with your values and goals. The hands-on learning and supportive environment are crucial to your decision-making. What do you think it might be like to explore other schools that offer similar hands-on and community-focused experiences? How would pursuing that change affect your sense of direction and confidence?

client(reflecting): I guess it might help me feel like I have more options and not just stuck with no direction. If I could find another school with a similar vibe, maybe I'd feel better about things and more hopeful about my future.

Exploring other schools with similar qualities could indeed open up new possibilities for you. Recognizing that you have options might boost your sense of direction and confidence. On a scale of 0 to 10, how confident are you about finding a program that aligns with what you value in an engineering education?

client(reflecting): I’d say maybe a 4 or 5 right now. I’m still not completely sure where to start or if there are schools out there that match what I’m looking for, but knowing there might be other options is a bit comforting.

therapist(guiding): It's great that you're at a 4 or 5—it shows there's some hope and openness to finding those options. What might help you move that confidence level up a notch or two? Are there specific steps or information you feel could support you in discovering schools with the qualities you value most?

client(guiding): I think doing a little research into schools with strong engineering programs and maybe talking to some advisors or current students could help. Also, making a list of the things that are important to me in a school might narrow down my options and make me feel more confident in choosing where to apply next.

statement.reasoning: The client has acknowledged the possibility of exploring alternative schools and feels a bit more hopeful, but their confidence level is only at a 4 or 5. Although there are indications of readiness, such as recognizing the importance of exploring options and identifying potential steps, the client is still in the early stages of building confidence and planning. More work in the Guiding phase could solidify their motivation and raise confidence levels before moving to the Choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: Researching schools and connecting with advisors or students sounds like a solid plan. Making a list of what you value most could really clarify things for you. How might taking those steps impact your confidence and overall feelings about this journey?

client(reflecting): Taking those steps could definitely help me feel more in control and positive about my situation. It might even boost my confidence to a 6 or 7 because I’d be actively searching for a place that fits me, instead of feeling like I’m just stuck with no options.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed important Change Talk regarding exploring new options and has outlined a specific plan to research schools, talk to advisors, and list valued aspects of a program. This indicates a shift from feeling stuck to being proactive. The client’s confidence has increased from a 4-5 to the potential 6-7 range with planned actions, which suggests readiness to develop specific action plans. OARS feedback: The use of open questions and reflections effectively helped the client clarify their values and increase their confidence.

dialogue.statement: Your plan to research and connect with advisors or students is a proactive way to regain control over your future. To help you move forward, would you like to set a specific goal for when you'd like to start this research or perhaps identify which advisors or students you might reach out to first? We can also anticipate any barriers you might face in this process and think about ways to overcome them. How does that sound?

client(choosing): Yeah, setting a goal sounds like a good idea. Maybe I can start the research this week and try to reach out to at least one advisor or student by next week. I think the hardest part might be just getting started and figuring out where to find people to talk to, but once I get going, I think it'll get easier.

That sounds like a solid plan. Starting your research this week and reaching out by next week gives you a concrete timeline to work with. To begin, perhaps you could focus on online resources, such as school websites or forums, to find potential contacts. Feeling hesitant about where to start is common, but as you mentioned, taking that first step can make it easier. How can you prepare for any initial challenges you might face in finding people to talk to? And how would you like to track your progress to ensure you're moving forward as you hope?

client(reflecting): I think preparing some questions or topics in advance might help me feel more confident when reaching out to people. I could also make a checklist to track who I've contacted and what steps I've taken. That way, I can see that I'm making progress, even if it feels slow at first.

Preparing questions in advance is a great strategy to boost your confidence in conversations. A checklist to track your contacts and progress will certainly help you stay organized and motivated. As you take these steps, how would you like to celebrate your achievements along the way, even the small ones? Recognizing your progress can keep you encouraged on this journey.

client(choosing): Celebrating sounds like a good idea, even if it's just small things. Maybe I can treat myself to my favorite snack or take a break to do something I enjoy, like watching a movie or going for a walk. That way, I can acknowledge the work I'm putting in and keep myself motivated to continue.

statement.reasoning: The client has set a clear goal to start research and make contacts within a specified timeline. They have considered potential barriers, such as initiating contact, and proposed strategies like preparing questions and creating a checklist to monitor progress. They have also identified ways to celebrate small achievements, indicating readiness to proceed. Given these factors, the client is demonstrating commitment and taking steps toward their goal, suggesting readiness to advance to the Terminating phase. The collaborative nature of developing this plan and addressing potential challenges effectively supports the client's confidence and motivation.

dialogue.statement: Those are wonderful ways to celebrate your progress and keep your spirits high. Treating yourself to a favorite snack or taking a break to enjoy activities you love are excellent ways to acknowledge your efforts. You've built a thoughtful plan with concrete steps and meaningful rewards, which will definitely support your journey. It's inspiring to see your commitment to finding a program that suits you best. Keep trusting in your efforts and adaptability, and remember, I'm here to support you as you move forward. Keep me updated on your progress, and take it one step at a time.
client(choosing): Thanks, I really appreciate your support and guidance. I'll definitely keep you posted on how things go. Here's to taking it one step at a time!

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a concrete plan with specific steps, a timeline, and strategies to overcome challenges. Celebratory steps are in place, showing readiness to implement their plan. The session can naturally conclude.

concern:
title: The only college that I applied to rejected me
I (19) got rejected after applying to an engineering school that I really wanted to go to. This school also has a high acceptance rate. I slowly got sick and tired of going to a community college and I finished and I want to transfer but I’m afraid that it’s too late to apply to other colleges. If this college (with its really high acceptance rate) openly rejects me, then it’s over when it comes to my hopes of going to college.

dialogue.statement: Hello! How can I support you today? Feel free to share what's on your mind.
Hey, I've been struggling with staying motivated in my classes and it's been stressing me out a lot. I feel like I'm in a rut and don't know how to get out of it.
It sounds like you're feeling stuck and stressed about your classes because motivation has been hard to maintain. Can you share more about what's been making it difficult to stay motivated right now?

client: I guess it's just overwhelming to juggle everything, and sometimes I feel like no matter how much I try, I'm not making any progress. It's like I'm in a cycle of procrastination and guilt, and it just feels exhausting.

That sounds really tough, feeling overwhelmed and caught in a cycle where progress seems out of reach. You're experiencing exhaustion from juggling everything and the guilt from procrastination. Would you be open to talking about what your days look like and what you feel contributes to this cycle?

client(exploring): Yeah, sure. My days usually start late because I struggle to get out of bed, then I end up missing classes or being late. When I finally sit down to study, I get distracted easily or feel like I'm not understanding anything, which just makes it worse.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared significant details about feeling overwhelmed and unmotivated in college, with a clear sense of feeling trapped in a cycle of procrastination and guilt. There's been valuable exploration of the client's daily routine and how it contributes to the issue. However, more exploration of the client's strengths and past successes could further build rapport and provide context for change. Further discussion is needed to ensure a deep understanding of the client's experiences and emotions before transitioning to strengthening motivation.

dialogue.statement: It seems like starting your day late and facing challenges with distractions and comprehension adds to the cycle you're experiencing. What do you think are some of the main distractions or feelings that come up when you try to study?

Honestly, I just find it hard to focus because my mind keeps wandering to all the stuff I haven't done yet. Sometimes I even feel overwhelmed by social media or just the stress of trying to balance everything, and it keeps pulling me away from studying.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared detailed insights into their struggles with motivation, feelings of being overwhelmed, and the cycle of procrastination and guilt. Empathy and understanding have been established, and the client has provided substantial context about their daily routine and distractions. The conversation is ready to transition into the Guiding phase, where the focus can shift to exploring motivations and evoking Change Talk. OARS feedback: Reflective listening helped deepen the client's exploration of their challenges, and future discussions can continue to build on this rapport.

dialogue.statement: Balancing so many demands and the pull of social media sounds incredibly challenging. It's understandable how this constant pull impacts your focus. If things were different and you found a way to manage these distractions, what would that look like for you?

If things were different, I'd probably have a more consistent routine where I get up earlier and actually make it to class on time. I'd like to figure out how to focus better without getting sidetracked by social media or stressing over everything I haven’t done yet.

Having a consistent routine and being on time for classes sounds like it could really support your focus and reduce stress. If you imagine yourself attending classes and managing distractions well, how might that align with your long-term goals or values?

If I managed my distractions and got to class consistently, I think I'd feel more in control and less anxious about my future. I'd probably feel more confident and capable, which is something I value a lot, and it would definitely help me stay on track with my long-term goals.

Feeling more in control and confident aligns closely with your values and long-term goals. It seems like these changes could reduce your anxiety about the future and increase your sense of capability. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about making these changes? What might help increase that confidence?

client(guiding): Honestly, I'd probably say I'm at around a 4 right now. I mean, I know what I need to do, but actually doing it feels like a whole different challenge. Maybe having some kind of plan or support system could help boost my confidence and keep me accountable.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire for change and identified specific goals, such as establishing a consistent routine and improving focus. However, their confidence level is currently at a 4, indicating significant ambivalence and a need for further exploration. Additionally, no specific change plan or next step has been collaboratively developed yet. Continuing in the Guiding phase will allow us to explore more strategies to enhance motivation and confidence, while addressing the client's feelings of overwhelm and guilt.

dialogue.statement: It's understandable that knowing what to do and putting it into practice can feel like separate challenges. You're already recognizing that a plan or support system might make a difference. What kind of support or resources do you think could help you move from a 4 to a higher level of confidence?

Having someone to check in with regularly, like a study buddy or a mentor, could be really helpful for me. Also, maybe using apps or tools to structure my time better, so I can keep track of what I need to do and stay on top of things.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire for change, highlighting specific goals such as establishing a consistent routine and reducing distractions. They identified potential solutions, like having a study buddy or using time management tools, indicating a thoughtful approach to overcoming their challenges. Although the confidence level is currently at 4, the client has provided ideas that could increase it, showing readiness to move forward. Change Talk is present, specifics about desired changes were discussed, and the client has shown insight into how change aligns with their values. Feedback: The exploration of values and goals was effective, but more focus on increasing confidence might be beneficial.

dialogue.statement: Creating a plan with regular check-ins and using tools to organize your time seems like a promising approach. Would you like to set a goal to have a study buddy or mentor and explore some apps that can help with time management? We can discuss potential barriers you might encounter and ways to overcome them.

client(choosing): Yeah, setting a goal to find a study buddy or mentor sounds good. I think having someone to keep me accountable and share the struggle with could make a big difference. As for apps, I’m definitely open to trying some out to help me stay organized. I guess my main worry is just sticking to it and not falling back into old habits.

It's great that you're open to finding a study buddy or mentor and exploring time management apps. Let's set a goal to connect with someone for accountability and try out a couple of apps to organize your study time. As you mentioned, sticking with it can be tough, so perhaps we could explore how to build this into your routine gradually. How does starting with small, consistent steps, like a short daily check-in with your study buddy or using a timer for focused study blocks, sound to you?

client(choosing): That actually sounds really doable. Starting small with daily check-ins and using a timer for study sessions sounds like a good way to ease into it without feeling overwhelmed. I think having that structure could help me form better habits over time.

Building small, consistent steps into your routine is a great way to form lasting habits without becoming overwhelmed. Focusing on short daily check-ins and timed study sessions can provide the structure you’re looking for. What specific action would you like to take first to get started on this new path, and how can I support you in this process?

I think the first step would be to reach out to classmates or people I know who might be interested in being study buddies, and also look into some time management apps. Maybe you could help me brainstorm some ways to approach them or suggest which apps might be a good fit for me to start with?

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear goal of finding a study buddy or mentor and exploring time management apps to improve motivation and accountability. They have expressed a willingness to start with manageable steps like daily check-ins and using a timer, addressing potential barriers and committing to actions. The client has developed a concrete action plan and agreed upon self-monitoring strategies. These demonstrate readiness to advance as they are showing commitment and confidence in their ability to initiate these changes. OARS feedback: The client’s openness to forming accountability partnerships and structured routines shows great insight and commitment. Continue to explore concrete ways to incorporate these into daily activities.

dialogue.statement: Reaching out to classmates for a potential study buddy and exploring time management apps are fantastic first steps. Let's brainstorm some friendly, open approaches for reaching out, like sending a casual message expressing your interest in studying together and the mutual benefits it could bring. As for apps, tools like Trello for organizing tasks or the Pomodoro Technique app for focused study blocks could be a good start. Remember, this is about creating a supportive network and structure to help you succeed. I'm here to support you, and you’re taking meaningful steps towards your goals. Keep up this positive momentum!
Thanks! I'll definitely try reaching out to some classmates soon and look into those apps. Having your support really makes me feel more hopeful about getting on track.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified concrete steps to address their lack of motivation, like connecting with a study buddy and using time management apps. We've established a supportive plan, addressing their primary concern.

concern:
title: i’ve been skipping classes and putting little to no effort into assignments and idk how to get outa the hole im in
i need advice 

i’m a college freshman in my second semester and i haven’t had any motivation to get any of my work done for my college courses. in highschool i was on top of my stuff all the time and looking back i don’t know how i managed to work part time and take 7 classes. I’m only taking 4 classes (16 credits) and i feel so unmotivated and overwhelmed.  my earliest class is at 11am and i can’t get myself up out of bed to go every morning. i don’t know what to do or how to get out of the funk i’m in. 

One of my college professors emailed me saying that I need to be more active and participate in class because my grade is low. The course material have the time is completely difficult for me to understand and I always attend office hours to try and get more help but I just can’t seem to graph the concept sometimes. it just makes me feel guilty and then when I do attend class I feel like I’m the only person that’s not understanding what’s being taught.  I had to drop one my labs the semester because I didn’t have the time and I stopped putting in the effort to try and get all of the work done. I was putting in about three hours of prep work for a class that I only had once a week, which I think is absolutely ridiculous. The lecture for that class takes about nine hours of work outside of the lectures. 

at this point I just have no idea what to do and how to get out of this hole that I’m in


TLDR , I’ve been procrastinating course work and have had little motivation when it comes to school and I don’t know what to do.

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? Is there anything specific you'd like to talk about or explore together?

Hey, I'm doing alright overall but I've been really stressed about my career path lately. I'm not sure if I should stick it out with social work or pivot to something in art, and the thought of more student debt is weighing on me.

Navigating career decisions can definitely bring a lot of stress. You're feeling uncertain about your path because both social work and art have their own appeals, but the financial aspect is a big consideration. What's been drawing you towards each option?

client(exploring): Well, social work was appealing because I wanted to help people, but the jobs I've had haven't really felt right for me. Art, on the other hand, just feels like where I belong, especially since I've been really enjoying teaching it lately.

It sounds like you're torn between your passion for art and your initial drive to help people through social work. Teaching art seems to resonate with you and give a sense of belonging. Can you tell me more about what you've enjoyed most about teaching art?

I really love seeing the creativity and excitement in my students when they’re working on projects. It's like I’m helping them express themselves and that feels rewarding. Plus, it’s fun and doesn't feel as stressful as my experiences in social work.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their main concerns regarding their career path, including financial burdens, job satisfaction, and mental health considerations. The client appears to be more aligned with teaching art, which they find rewarding and less stressful compared to social work. The therapist effectively elicited the client's feelings and thoughts, building empathy and rapport. This understanding sets the stage for moving to the Guiding phase to explore motivations and potential changes further. OARS feedback: The therapist effectively used reflections and open questions to draw out the client's story, but could aim to deepen the exploration of the client's values related to art and social work.

dialogue.statement: That sense of reward and enjoyment you get from teaching art seems to bring a lot of positivity and fulfillment. It appears this role allows you to help others in a meaningful way, too. How does this sense of fulfillment and reduced stress compare to your current experiences in social work?

In social work, I've been feeling pretty drained and overwhelmed, like I'm not making the impact I hoped to. With art teaching, it's lighter and more uplifting, and I don't dread going to work, which is a big difference.

The difference in how you feel about each role is quite significant. Teaching art seems to offer you a sense of impact and joy, making your workday something you look forward to. Considering this contrast, what do you imagine your life could be like if you pursued a career more aligned with teaching art?

If I pursued a career in teaching art full-time, I imagine I'd feel more fulfilled and happier on a day-to-day basis. I think the challenge would be figuring out how to make it sustainable financially and managing the job stability concerns that come with it.

Therapist (Guiding): Imagining a more fulfilling and happier day-to-day life sounds really appealing. Balancing that with financial sustainability and job stability is important. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about your ability to explore and navigate this transition towards art teaching?

client(guiding): Honestly, I'd say maybe a 5. I feel somewhat confident because I've already got some experience, but the financial side of things and managing my mental health make it hard to feel more certain about making this jump.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear desire to pursue a career in art teaching, highlighting increased fulfillment and joy compared to social work. They've identified specific barriers, such as financial sustainability and job stability, and have a moderate confidence level (5 out of 10) about transitioning. However, the client still appears ambivalent due to financial concerns and mental health, as evident in their ongoing worries and self-assessed confidence. concern:
title: Teaching Art?
Hey everyone. So I fucked up and went to school for social work and I have $50,000 in student loans. I’m having trouble holding down a job in this field and I think part of that is that it’s not really the field for me.

I’m considering going back to school to become an art teacher because I have been doing a part time art teaching job right now and I’m enjoying it a lot. I want more opportunities in this field because art is my true passion. I have two big worries though. One thing I worry about is taking on even more debt since I have so much and the other thing I worry about is the fact that it’s entirely possible that I could end up still struggling to hold down a job due to mental health stuff.

I’d love to hear some input from you guys about what I should do since it’s a big decision.

concern:
title: Repercussions to quitting internship early
I’m currently doing a remote international internship with a startup company (i’m a rising junior). My contract technically states I end on September 30th as I entered it in April, BUT my boss had made it clear she wanted me to work for 6 months via email (so around end of November as I actually started doing work in May).

I feel like I’m in way over my head and that I won’t have time to do an internship alongside my studies once college starts. I want to quit by September 30th but am scared as to what she would say/what would happen if I don’t stick it out for 6 months (I’ve been working for ~2 months now and quitting in September would make it a total of 4 months).

I’m debating talking to her about it but don’t know what to say. Will there be any repercussions if I end this internship on a bad note? Any tips or advice would be much appreciated!

concern:
title: after getting through school with increasingly worst habits, I have officially failed an entire semester.
I should've known it was coming. I am so stuck, and beyond knowing what to do. 

Since the second semester of 10th grade, I have been depressed. I had spent about a year and a half obsessed with overachieving, eager to perform well, terrified of not living up to my father's expectations - and it had led me to a bunch of self-destructive study habits, that I didn't realize was harmful because it worked. Because I was GOOD at school, I was great at drawing, I was great at essays, I was lazy, but still determined and managed to get around to getting what I wanted out of myself. This is starting to sound like a very typical 'gifted' kid situation. But I really was good at a lot of things.

I have this vivid memory of the first time I realized my body was *tired*. I had a deadline coming up for one of my classes, it was the night before, and I remember sitting in my chair, realizing that I wasn't stressed. That last-minute surge of energy I used to get hours before a deadline, that stress that I used to rely on, it didn't come. It was only after the deadline had passed, that my body sprang into action.

But I was lucky back then. The tenth grade and the years following. Granted countless extensions, had understanding and generous teachers - and at the end of the day, even if it was as if I had no stress or motivation left in my body, I would still get it done at some point. I didn't realize though, that even though I got through those assignments, it had made me insanely ashamed. I spent my eleventh grade suicidal because of how much I hated my brain for not working normally, for not being the way it used to be. I would have breakdowns every night before a deadline.

With every semester, it had gotten worse - I almost didn't graduate high school because I had waited till the day before the very last day of an online class to do an entire course's work.

Then when I got to university, I barely scraped by. My first year had earned me a warning about my gpa. And I'd been so determined to do better. So determined to change - I've always been. The pandemic had torn my mental health apart - but it was okay, because now my classes were going to be in person, there was no excuse to not do well.

For the first time, this year, during the first semester of my second year of university, I failed every single class I attended.

37 minutes ago was my final extended deadline to hand in a term paper. I am majoring in something I love, in something I'm privileged to be able to study.

But I stood there in front of a blank screen and did everything I could to distract myself from working. Going on my phone, scrolling through Twitter, playing games, apartment hunting, daydreaming while I listen to music, getting up to make food. Anything to keep myself from feeling any dread, and that would enable me to stay comfortable in my little bubble of self-hate and procrastination.

It's as if my brain cannot fathom putting in effort into *anything* anymore. I'd like to take a moment that this burnout has impacted all areas of my life. I don't draw. I don't write. I can hardly muster up the strength to write emails. I want so much for myself but it's as if this parasite in my brain manages to manipulate me into doing absolutely nothing. And now I've thrown away four months of dragging my feet through courses for nothing.

I don't know how to change. I love studying literature, and I love the idea of school, but what's the point if I barely put effort into it? If I'm wracking up student debt just to fail? Just to throw it all away.

I don't even know what to do. I'm afraid to tell my mother. She'll be so devastated, and she'll just blame herself. 

I don't even know the point of living if I'm just going to be on autopilot my whole life. If I'm just going to dream about reaching my goals, and never actually put the work to it.

I wasn't even spoiled growing up. I was raised by a strong single mother that did everything to make sure I could have a life that I flourish in - but all I do is disappoint her. And my father. 

I'm sorry this was really long, but I can't talk to anyone about it and needed to just get it out there.

My current plan is getting an AA in Fine Art. I know, it's basically a joke degree but I'm an artist at a fairly respectable community college. (SPSCC if anyone cares.)

Anyway, my issue is that I struggled for years to be a freelance artist but now I have mental health fixed, I'm wondering if I should try something more rigorous or dependable for a degree. I've been told I should try for an occupational therapist career because I've seen what they do now in person and it seems like a good job where I can actually help people. 

I really want my skills to be useful and helpful, because I am so unconfident in my ability to start a business and market myself. concern:
title: Anyone using Aleks math? What are your thoughts on it? (Story)
The concept makes sense, but it is repetitive. All three of my math professors have used aleks due to blended classes. So students Aleks are different from each other. This professor was more annoying due to her giving us so much damn work, I was doing more math than any of my other class work for other classes. My professor once thought it was a good idea to give us 74 topics once, but in a span of two weeks so there was sometime to it. I lost my mind and got up to 53. I ended up passing the class. 

The second one, I did fine in the first half and the topics were a lot less compared to the first class, but I started to be in a deep burnout state and even getting COVID that I gave up and failed the class due to constantly completing Aleks and just saying fuck all to any topics and assignments.

Now my third professor and I’m making up the class. I’ve somewhat came up with a better system to complete them: on average, it’s 24 topics due in a span of 3-4 days. Of those three days, I complete six topics a day. I’m still in that system. Slipped a bit because I have to put my attention to two other classes and somewhat procrastinated. But now I’ve realized I’ve put so much time in Aleks, I’m somewhat behind in other classes. And I wanted to try and enjoy my weekend whilst maintaining Aleks and I’m seeing a module that is due March 5 of next month that I haven’t touched due to me working on the current module (which I have 33 topics remaining out of 140 I think so I’ve been doing good). 

And I have to work this weekend, but it looks like I may have to call out both days to maintain Aleks and other class work. Which is already bad because I haven’t been working as much recently. 

So now I’m just frustrated and confused on my options because Aleks is taking up too much of my time). And I’m not kidding when I say I have had full on panic attacks due to trying to complete Aleks to pass the class with a C or above. Anyone else?

concern:
title: Did I waste my teen years?
I turn 20 tomorrow and I’ve been thinking back and reflecting on my life as a teenager and there really isn’t much there. I feel like I didn’t do the things that you’re supposed to do as a teenager. I’ve never been to a party, I don’t drink or smoke and never have, I’ve never been in a relationship or even been on a date. I spent most of my time in high school at home and same with the first year of college since it was online. I have a group of 6 close friends but now that we’re all in college we aren’t talking much. I just feel like I’ve missed out on some of the experiences people generally have growing up.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! How can I support you today? Feel free to share what's on your mind.

Hey, I'm just trying to figure out my college plans. I'm stuck between staying in-state for a good deal or going to Michigan Tech, which seems exciting but kinda risky. Any advice on how to weigh these options?
That sounds like a tough decision, involving a balance between excitement and practicality. What are some things that draw you to Michigan Tech, and what makes staying in-state appealing for you?

client: Well, Michigan Tech feels like an adventure, plus it has that connection with my dad's history there. But staying in-state is cheaper and probably less stressful. It's just hard to know what's more important for my future.

It sounds like you're torn between the adventure and family connection at Michigan Tech and the financial and emotional ease of staying in-state. What feelings come up when you think about each option in terms of your future goals?

client: Thinking about Michigan Tech, it feels exciting and like a fresh start, but there's this worry about the cost and being far from home. On the other hand, in-state feels safe and smart financially, but maybe a bit too familiar and not as adventurous.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared thoughts and feelings about choosing between Michigan Tech and staying in-state, but further exploration is needed to fully understand their values, goals, and specific concerns. The current phase has effectively built rapport and elicited initial thoughts, but more detailed exploration of how each option aligns with their future aspirations is necessary before moving to the Guiding phase.

dialogue.statement: Both options seem to have their own sets of emotions and priorities. When you think about what's most important for your future, like adventure or financial security, how do you see these feelings aligning with your long-term goals?

client: That's the tricky part. I want to have a solid career in computer science, and I know finances matter, but the idea of experiencing something new is really tempting. It's hard to say which will help me more in the long run.

statement.reasoning: The client has effectively articulated the dilemma between excitement and practicality, including emotional and financial considerations, and how these relate to his long-term goals in computer science. The mutual understanding and rapport are evident, and we have a clear picture of the client's values and thoughts. Moving to the Guiding phase will help evoke Change Talk and strengthen the client's motivation for making a decision. The exploration of current feelings and priorities has been insightful and supportive.

Staying in-state feels like a safer bet in terms of money and stability, which could also keep me grounded as I start out. It's tough to weigh the importance of adventure against the need for security.

Navigating the balance between adventure and security can be quite a challenge. client(guiding): I guess I'm realizing that both adventure and security are important to me, but it's hard to prioritize one over the other. A new experience could really shape my growth, but I don't want to end up regretting it if the financial strain is too much. Trying to figure out which one will lead to a more fulfilling path is the tricky part.

Balancing those priorities can indeed feel challenging. When you picture yourself a few years down the road, having either chosen adventure or security, what do you imagine feeling most fulfilled about, and how might that influence your decision today?

client(guiding): It's hard to say because both outcomes have their appeals. If I choose adventure, I might feel proud of taking a risk and gaining new experiences. But with security, I'd probably feel relieved and stable, knowing I'm not financially overextending myself. It's about weighing which feeling I value more in the long term.

But the relief from financial security could give me a solid foundation to build my career without the stress of debt. I guess it's about finding a balance, but that's the hard part.

Having those discussions could definitely make me feel more secure in making a decision.

concern:
title: Computer Science?
I live In Alabama and I want to major in computer science and later get into a field. I know that in state tuition is a big factor when choosing ,but I really like Michigan Tech. Michigan is a place I've always wanted to visit and live in, it is also when my dad grew up and recommends going there. My high school stats are considered above average but barely, luckily Michigan tech is not extremely competitive either. So should i either go to Michigan tech or University of Alabama Huntsville (maybe Auburn as well). I want to be creditable and go to a good school but I don't know which one is objectively better for internships and overall teaching.

dialogue.statement: Hello! What's on your mind today? Feel free to share whatever you're comfortable with.

Balancing work and school can definitely feel overwhelming. It seems like you're feeling anxious because it's been a while since you've had to manage both. How do you usually handle stress in situations like this?
Honestly, I usually hit the gym to blow off some steam, and that helps a lot. But this time, I'm worried it might not be enough since the workload feels like it's gonna be pretty intense.

It's great to hear that going to the gym has been a helpful stress-reliever for you in the past. You're concerned this time might be different due to the intense workload. What aspects of managing both commitments are you most concerned about?
I guess I'm mostly worried about staying on top of assignments and not falling behind. With work taking up most of my day, I'm concerned about finding enough time to really focus on schoolwork.

concern:
title: Is 10 quarter hours doable ?
I work full time in the Air Force. Roughly 7-3/4 each day and get home around 5/530 from the gym. I go to bed around 10pm each night. Will this be too much ? I've been out of school for 7 years and decided to go back. Going to be taking History102: US History 5 quarter hour credits and Bio 105-2: Anatomy & Physiology. 

The courses are 5 weeks in length but access to all coursework/books and such is granted online 1 week prior to class. Might be over thinking it but I wanna see how terrible or not terrible my life will be for 5/6 weeks.

client(exploring): Yeah, definitely. I remember when I got an A on a research paper last semester. It felt awesome because I worked so hard on it, and my professor said the analysis was really insightful. That's the kind of feedback that usually makes me feel on top of my game.

concern:
title: How do I stop stressing over a bad grade on a paper?
I made a stupid mistake. I had to miss 2 weeks of my English class because of a really terrible family issue. I stayed kept up on my work, and wrote what I thought was a very terrific paper. Unbeknownst to me, I didn’t fully read the rubric and I didn’t include some necessary information. I received a 50 on the paper, with my professor saying I had a fantastic prose but I was just missing content. I have the opportunity to COMPLETELY redo the paper at the end of the semester, yet seeing that F in the gradebook just makes my stomach turn. I’m stressed for absolutely no reason but I can’t stop. I keep worrying I’ll mess up the redo, or I’ll mess up my next papers. It makes me so scared because I’m normally a fantastic english student. I no longer feel confident in my work. How can I put myself in perspective here?

client: I guess I'd want friends who I can be myself around, people who are supportive and actually interested in getting to know me, not just surface-level stuff. It's hard to find those kinds of connections.

concern:

I feel incredibly lonely and realized that all the people I’ve met last semester aren’t actually people who I mesh well with/ aren’t amazing friends. Yeah, I’ve had similar feelings when picking my majors initially. It was hard to commit to both because I was so worried about closing doors, and I still kinda feel like that.

concern:
title: Advice on maybe switching out of design major?
To keep it as brief as possible, I’m currently double majoring in fashion design and environmental sciences. I’m heading into second semester junior year. I’ve been seriously considering switching out of my design major for something else (maybe comp sci? I’m a math nerd and have picked up some coding previously).

I’ve never felt so stuck on a decision before honestly. I love fashion to death, but I feel like I have too many reasons to leave and my passion is dwindling bc of college. My program isn’t teaching me the skills or getting me the connections I want/need, I feel like it’s ruining my college experience (extremely long labs, working almost constantly, and struggling to keep a social life on top of a job), and I have over a years worth of credits left in the major (~36) and most majors are 30-45 total anyways. My dream with fashion is to have some level of creative freedom or even start my own small brand/social media presence one day. I don’t even need a degree to do this, so maybe my time/money would be better spent on other things.

Does anyone have experience switching in/out (or not) of art/design? Am I being a baby and I should just finish the major? Any advice or experiences would be appreciated!

TLDR; I love fashion but am frustrated with the degree, thinking about keeping it as a hobby/side hustle and switching into another major

concern:
title: How do you get through a project that removes your will to live?
I've been working on the project my advisor assigned me for 3.5 years now. I'm finally at the point where I can get my masters from it, but my will to live is basically gone. It's not the work I came to grad school to do, it doesn't get at any of the things I wanted to study in grad school, and it's taken 70% of my grad school career that I can't get back, and I don't even make enough money to buy something that can distract me from how miserable I am. I have 1 month to get the thesis finished, and every time I open it I just start crying. I'm not even sure it's worth it anymore and I don't know what to do. I want something to show for my time in grad school but I just hate this work so much. I don't want to interpret the stats, I don't care about the results, just hearing the project topic makes me want to take my laptop and smash it into little tiny pieces.

dialogue.statement: Hello! What would you like to talk about today? I'm here to listen and support you.

Hey! I've been thinking a lot about what I want to major in at college. I'm having a hard time choosing between philosophy, sociology, and anthropology, and I just want to make sure I'm picking something that aligns with my interests and could lead to a stable career.
Choosing a major can definitely feel overwhelming with so many options. What draws you to philosophy, sociology, and anthropology, and how do you envision each of them fitting into your future?

Well, I really love digging into how people think and why they behave in certain ways, not just individually but as a group, so that's why sociology stands out to me. Philosophy intrigues me because it tackles deep questions about existence and human nature, and anthropology seems like a perfect blend of both, looking at cultures and histories. I just want to be sure whichever I choose can also support me in a career, maybe even in journalism or something similar.

You have such a deep curiosity about human behavior and thought processes, which is wonderful. Considering your interest in possibly pursuing journalism, how do you see each of these subjects enhancing your ability to explore and convey stories about people and cultures?

I think all three could really help me understand the nuances of what I write about, whether it's exploring cultural trends or philosophical concepts in society. Sociology might give me the tools to analyze social patterns, while philosophy can provide a framework for tackling big questions, and anthropology could help me dive into cultural contexts.

concern:
title: Should I major in Philosophy, sociology, or anthropology? will either three be a good career major?
TL;DR: I absolutely enjoy commentary and video analysis essyas that delve into the behavior of people, what they've done, and why it happened/the concerns of it. Not in a psychology way however. I'm unsure what degree best fits my desires in discussing these topics and interacting with others. However, the catch is that I also like discussions and analysis in things that aren't related to collective people, but maybe something about dreams for instance, unless it still connects to people. 



I have quite some time to pick a major as I'm in 11th grade, however I believe I mad some changes in what I degree I wanted to pursue. I originally wanted to major in communications and minor in journalism, but I noticed how I have a keen taste for commentary and analysis essays in regards to concerning phenomenons that take place omg societies. For example, I watched a video on collective trauma as a generation and how that plays out, and how the video mentioned the "spectacle" in which people are more focused on what could conform to it (such as wanting representation in the media more than being focused on what could help with agriculture in the world). The person in the video said this, but I started to realize how often this takes place now. (I'll love to go into more detail, but I get carried away with writing lol) Anyways, it made me begin to rethink what I want to pursue as a degree, and what could compliment me the most. I enjoy asking questions and socializing, however I love analysis and understanding topics in regards to how people function based on what the topic is. Carl Jung deeply interested me because of my favorite boy band implementing ideologies into their music. Which led to me question if his takes are sociology, or philosophy. I want to intergrate either one with communications, as I aspire to be a journalist; or something similar to one. I know what I'm seeking out in a degree, but not sure what degree has what I'm looking for in the future. I'm intrigued by Carl Jung's theories on dreams as well, but not sure if that's sociology or philosophy either. I like watching those videos, or see something online that could seek to be controversial or a touchy opinion, and begin to ask peers, family, or others online what their stance is on it and why. Why do people have the tendency to gravitate to someone harmful for them? Why is it hard to understand how dreams work? The relations in the subconscious and unconscious? How does this affect the functionality of people? Etc. I want to turn it into a career path, something to pursue. But I don't know what name to put to it. I mad an essay on why is it hard to be ethical online too. I can't just simply tell if sociology or philosophy is the name, or if they go hand in hand. Heck, if I can do both in college whole still minoring in communications. I'm unsure if either will be able to help me have a stable career future as well.

[What best explains the type of videos I watch](https://youtu.be/jlIBGl5-j_4)

concern:
title: Would starting therapy when I start grad school be a bad idea?
For context, I'm joining my top choice this Fall (in the US). For the last year or so, I've been really feeling that I need to go to therapy. I have an extremely low self esteem, social anxiety and I've just been stressed over the smallest of things which manifests itself as irritation and general unpleasantness. The reason I haven't gone yet is that I live at home and I share my room with a younger sibling. There's no way for me to get privacy without asking for it and I don't want my parents to know about this. My mom kinda understands but my dad doesn't really get it and has been very apprehensive. I know that if I insist, he won't stop me but I don't want to have to deal with the awkwardness considering that they would know everytime I go for a session since I'd have to kick my younger sibling out of the room. I'd rather do it privately and handle this on my own before involving my parents. 

I've been at home since the pandemic began and I've been itching to move out which is why I'm very grateful for grad school. I'd like to start therapy as soon as possible since I worry about my ability to function as an adult in a new setting when I'm struggling with every human interaction. My only concern is that I'm sure therapy will be taxing (mentally and emotionally) and grad school will be taxing in so many ways. Would it be a good idea to do start both at the same time or should I wait some more? Are my assumptions that therapy would be too distracting correct?

concern:
title: Is this normal?
I literally feel depressed and tired every single semester and wonder if I have chosen the wrong major....

The grade scale is curved at my community college so that an 88%+ = A, 76%+ = B, 64%+ = C, and so on for the other two grades. I currently have a 63% in the class. I was almost on my way to reaching a B, but FAILED the mid term three weeks ago, along with more than have the class. This is the second time I almost reached a B, only to get dropped back down to a 62%. 

I can not just drop out for so many reasons. I was just wondering if it is normal to feel like this ?

Does anyone have any experience with taking classes online vs in person? I just... I can't focus on my professor, he is so boring. Ugh...

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. What would you like to share with me today?
Hey, thanks for having me. I guess I'm just feeling kinda overwhelmed balancing work and school, and I'm worried about not doing well in my classes.

title: Studies

concern:
title: Debating About Getting My PhD?
I am 31 years old and graduated in 2020 with my Master's in Biochem and Molecular Bio. I've been working in the biotech industry for the past couple years. Like now, I also worked for a couple years in industry between my Bachelor's and Master's. However, I realized that in Biology you are very limited in pay, job opportunities, and growth with just a Bachelor's, which justified pursuing my master's. I do like learning and I think getting a PhD will make me a better Biologist overall, but I know I want to return to industry when finished. I also know if I went back to school it would be for cancer research or Epigenetics. However, unlike a masters program,  the 5+ years of school for a PhD vs the 5+ years of real life work experience is making this decision harder. In addition, the low stipends, PI stories (I've heard both good and bad), and when looking for jobs in the past, the experience potential and pay comparisons varies but not as much as I thought. What are your opinions on going back for a PhD? Do you feel like there are no more limitations with your PhD compared to just having a Master's? It would be great to hear both sides of the argument. Thank you!

concern:
title: How are you all able to manage everything you're doing? 😩
So for context, I'm not a grad student yet but I'm a senior undergrad who's taking 4 grad level courses, along with doing a research project and a TA-ship. Posting here because I think this is the same (probably still less) workload as most of you have and I genuinely don't know how to manage everything. And thinking about this is making me fearful of what's going to happen when I start grad school myself. 

Anyway, I'm a first time TA, and I started this out by being super energetic and responsive to students, and this is a class of 260 kids with 4 TA's in total for it. I'm the head TA, so along with dealing with student questions and grading and stuff, plus holding weekly office hours and practice sessions, I'm handling most of the managerial tasks along with it like maintaining data for everything along with organizing stuff and continuing to email the class about any and all updates about anything. Because of this, most students contact me when they have an issue, and obviously I'm going to respond to their emails, and I have to make sure they understand stuff, because this is a calc-1 class with a majority of non-stem students. I've even been setting up extra zoom meetings with some of them, which have ranged from anywhere between 30 minutes to 1.5 hours. 

The problem with this is. I can't find time to do anything else. I haven't been focusing on my courses at all, and I have a midterm in about 14 hours that I haven't even begun to study for. I have two more midterms in the next week, and again, no idea how I'm going to deal with them. The most I do is complete assignments, but some of them can easily take anywhere between 2 days, to a week (the latter for a very difficult pure math class). I also need to complete, or at least continue my senior year research project, but I haven't done anything with it for nearly a month now. I genuinely just can NOT find time for anything. And that's especially if I'm trying to make sure I have a good sleep schedule (nothing extreme, but at least 5-6 hours every night) along with maybe taking out an hour or two for myself in a day (which includes time taken to eat or nap mostly). 

I just genuinely need advice. How do you handle everything, alongside doing justice to each of your responsibilities and NOT overburdening yourself to the point of complete burnout? Do you set up schedules? I'm really sorry for posting here, but I have no idea where/who else to ask and I'm seriously going to end up completely incapable of doing anything if it continues like this.
