concern:
title: I had a miscarriage between two conferences (did not know I was pregnant until I was actively miscarrying) and have been on a mental and physical health roller-coaster the last 4 months. I feel so much better now, but want to be transparent, do I tell my PI what's going on?
First, it feels weird calling it a miscarriage because my husband and I are not trying to get pregnant, I have a hormonal arm implant (Nexplanon) and am in no way ready to start a family nor am sure that's something I will ever want.  I have told my mum, and a few close friends, but haven't really referred it as a miscarriage because that implies a loss.  I am so unbelievably relieved and can focus for the first time in over 3 months.  My doctor and my counselor are great allies and have been so supportive while pushing beyond me saying this is "just a normal grad school mental breakdown". I had an IUD before the arm implant and had not had a period in 5 years, so we never considered I could be pregnant and I assumed I had gained a little weight from stress eating.  Lo and behold, there is a 1/100 chance of getting pregnant with the Nexplanon arm implant, but most likely to be unviable and ectopic so there was a chance I needed a D&C which was very stressful and upsetting while busy with conference prep and international travel.  I am emotionally exhausted and did become heavily reliant on Zopiclone to sleep when I was having frequent anxiety attacks.  Now that I am feeling pretty emotionally good and weaning off the Zopiclone, I am not sleeping nearly as well without it, but on my way to feeling like myself again.  I'm still not 100%, and would want to acknowledge that something has been off about me if my PI does bring it up (which he has in the past when I've been noticeably down - I'm often described as an effervescent and vivacious person and have no poker face).  Also I am still mildly traumatized from seeing the...expelled tissue...and often can't shake the image from my head and that has not helped my sleeping situation.  When I write it all out, it sounds very dramatic and serious.  
   
On one hand, I am mentally at ease after months of uncontrollable crying, lack of focus, and intense, disruptive physical anxiety.  I was still able to do my project management job well but I had to make some big changes about my thesis and got kind of paralyzed in my own research. I don't want to diminish that my academic life is still really stressful: I work full-time as a project manager and my PI is also my MA supervisor so we see each other several times a week.  He knows me well. We have a good relationship and he is very supportive of me as a human, a researcher, and a professional in my field from before going back to school.  He is a very nurturing supervisor and has been supportive during other losses I have experienced in our time working closely together.  On the other hand, I don't know if it's better to leave it at "I've had an ongoing medical challenge but am feeling a lot better, looking forward to the holiday break and returning refreshed".  There is such a taboo about discussing women's reproductive health so it would be easier to talk about if it was strictly a mental health issue - it feels so heavy and complicated, especially with holiday parties and everyone asking "how are you?!?!?" when I'm not great.

Any advice or similar experiences would be greatly appreciated.  I know other women who struggle with the dichotomy of academia vs family and work-life balance.  I feel quite alone in this as many of my friends are starting to get baby fever or actively trying to get pregnant.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What brings you here today? I'm here to listen and explore what's on your mind.
Hey, I just feel so overwhelmed juggling everything with school and my kids. I’m struggling to figure out if I should keep going this semester or just take a step back.

Balancing school and family is challenging and it's natural to feel overwhelmed. You're considering either continuing or taking a break, which seems like a tough decision. Can you share more about what makes each option appealing or concerning for you?

client(exploring): Well, if I keep going, I feel like I'll be accomplishing something and not falling behind, but it's just so stressful. On the other hand, if I take a break, I feel like I'm letting myself down or wasting time.

You're caught between wanting to keep progressing with your studies and the stress it brings, while also feeling like taking a break might mean not living up to your own expectations. Both options have their own appeal and challenges. What has helped you manage stressful times like this in the past?

Usually, I try to break things down into smaller tasks and tackle them one at a time, but right now, everything just feels like too much. I’ve also relied on support from family, but even that feels shaky with everyone having their own stuff going on.

The client's openness about her challenges is a strength that can be leveraged in the next phase.

Honestly, I think maybe talking it through more and getting some perspective would help. It might also help to set some sort of deadline to make a choice, so I'm not in limbo forever.

Taking time to talk it through and setting a deadline for your decision seem like thoughtful steps to gain clarity and move forward. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about being able to make a decision that aligns with your values and current needs?
client(guiding): I’d say I'm probably at about a 4 right now. I feel pretty stuck, and it's hard to feel confident when I'm not sure what the right move is. But talking it through is helping a bit.

client(guiding): I really value education and want to set a good example for my kids by finishing my degree. At the same time, I know I need to be present for them and take care of myself, too. It's just hard to balance those priorities right now.

concern:
title: To withdraw or to not withdraw from the semester..
I just had my daughter 6 weeks ago. The week my classes started, I gave birth to my daughter. I thought i could handle taking 2 classes with a toddler & newborn, but god was I totally wrong. I emailed my professors & told them that I just gave birth & they told me & I can turn in my work whenever with no penalties. I’m so in between on if I should withdraw from this semester, or if I should continue with the classes. It’s just so fucking hard being a stay at home mom with a toddler & newborn + being a college student. I feel like a failure if I withdraw and I hate it. Any other moms who just had a baby & are still taking classes? How are you handling it?

dialogue.statement: Hello! What would you like to discuss today?
Hey, I'm just feeling really stuck with my major. I thought psychology was my thing, but now I'm not so sure. It's stressing me out, you know?
Choosing a major can feel overwhelming, especially when you're uncertain about your path. What is it about psychology that initially drew you in, and what's leading you to feel unsure now?

client(exploring): At first, I was all about helping people and figuring out how they think. But now, I just feel like I don't have the patience or interest for it anymore. It feels like I'm just going through the motions and I'm not sure if I really like it.

It's understandable to feel conflicted when your initial passion starts to wane. You were drawn to psychology because of your interest in helping people and understanding their thoughts, but now it feels like you're losing interest and patience. Can you share more about when you started feeling this way?

It started creeping in maybe a few months ago. Classes just got more intense, and I began questioning if I could really see myself doing this for the rest of my life. It feels like a big commitment, and I'm just not sure if it's what I want anymore.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their initial motivations for choosing psychology, the conflict they're experiencing now, and their emotional struggle with decision-making. However, more exploration is needed to fully understand their deeper feelings and beliefs related to their career choices and self-perception. Additional sessions could further uncover underlying emotions, values, and goals to facilitate a smoother transition to the guiding phase.

dialogue.statement: Questioning a long-term commitment can be daunting, especially when coursework becomes more intense. It sounds like you're feeling uncertain about dedicating your future to psychology. How has this uncertainty been affecting other areas of your life?

It's been messing with my mood a lot, honestly. I find myself stressed out more often, and it's hard to focus on other stuff. Even hanging out with friends feels different cause part of me is always thinking about this.

Having clarity could indeed bring more ease and enjoyment into your life. You're recognizing the potential relief and freedom that direction can bring. What do you imagine your life might look like if you were confident in your major choice?

If I was confident about my major, I think I'd feel more motivated and excited about my classes. I'd probably be more focused and less stressed overall, and I imagine I'd have more energy to enjoy things outside of school too. It'd be nice to just feel secure in my decision.

client(guiding): Honestly, I think talking to more people in the field could help, like professors or professionals who went through this. Maybe getting their insights might give me a better idea of what to expect. Also, trying out some related activities or internships might help me see if this is really what I want.

title: I'm a psychology major and I don't know if I want to do this anymore. I know I can but I just don't know if I'll be happy with it.
I hate people. Or I don't know. Sometimes I hate them, sometimes I want to help and I fought my parents hard to be able to get into psychology and I know I can become a therapist even if I will never be happy with it because school was never a problem and I have a scholarship so money doesn't even matter. The thing is, I can't think of anything else to do. Sometimes I think I'd rather die than be going through this. Choosing a lifelong career is so freaking hard and the stress is just too much sometimes. Anyone have advice for major problems?

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you doing today? What's been on your mind lately?
Hey, I've been feeling a bit down lately. I guess I've just been thinking a lot about what happened with grad school and trying to figure out my next steps.
That sounds tough, and it's understandable to feel down while figuring out your next steps after grad school. Can you share more about what happened and how it's been affecting you?

client: Well, I got rejected from the grad program I really wanted, and it was a shock. It's been a bit of a blow to my confidence because I wasn't expecting it, and now I'm just trying to figure out what I should do differently.

Facing rejection from a program you really wanted can be really challenging, especially when it was unexpected. It makes sense that your confidence would take a hit. What are some thoughts or options you've considered as you think about your next steps?

client: I've been thinking about reapplying and focusing on improving my application by working on my resume and gaining some more research experience. I've also considered maybe looking into other programs or even different fields altogether, but it's a bit overwhelming.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their story in detail, including their feelings of shock, rejection, and uncertainty after being denied entry into the grad program they desired. They've also identified possible next steps, like improving their resume and gaining more research experience. The client's thought process, emotions, and relevant context have been effectively explored, and there appears to be a foundation of empathy and rapport. This indicates readiness to transition to the Guiding phase to further explore and strengthen motivation for change.

dialogue.statement: Feeling overwhelmed with all these options is quite normal, especially when considering such big life decisions. As you think about improving your application or exploring different paths, what aspects of these choices align with your long-term goals or values?

client: I want to grow in my field, and going to grad school has always been a big part of that plan. Improving my application feels like the right step to keep moving forward, but I'm also open to exploring other paths if they can lead me to where I want to be long-term. It's just hard to figure out what aligns best with my goals right now.

It's great that you're considering both strengthening your application and exploring other paths. Reflecting on your long-term goals is a strong step in the right direction. What specific values or aspects of your career are most important to you as you navigate this decision?

client: I really value making a meaningful impact through my work and contributing to advancements in my field. I also crave continuous learning and growth, which is why grad school felt like a natural step. But I guess I'm still figuring out what path will let me do those things most effectively.

Thinking about making a meaningful impact and pursuing continuous learning shows how deeply you care about your career. As you consider your options, how do you see each potential path contributing to those values and aspirations?

client: I've been looking at the ways reapplying could help me dive deeper into my field and really hone the skills I need to make a bigger impact. On the other hand, exploring other programs or fields might open up new perspectives and opportunities that I hadn't considered before. It's just about finding where I can grow the most and align with those values.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear commitment to improve their application and explore other paths, demonstrating engagement in both Change Talk and a specific change goal. client(choosing): I think I could start by reaching out to professionals in my field for informational interviews to get some insights and advice. Also, maybe I could look into volunteering or part-time work to gain more research experience. That way, I can learn more about what's out there and what might suit me best.

concern:
title: Rejection from grad school
Hi thanks for taking the time to read this, I'll make it brief.

I just graduated college and I applied to graduate school for that same program. Well, I was denied. This came as a complete shock to me, as I have never really been rejected from anything in life. Not to say I always get want I want, but whenever I set out to do something, I get it. So this was big.

I emailed the MS program director as well as other professors in the program asking what I could do better. I got responses like "it's competitive" or "a higher gpa is usually the case" (even though I was above average) and things like people had more research experience in their undergrad. I want to apply again. I can't change my grades but I can change my resume, educational personal statement, my writing examples and my references.

I am trying to keep an open mind but I feel defeated. I was applying for the fall now I need to wait until the spring semester and even then, I don't know if ill be accepted. I really have come at a crossroads in my life but I am taking it as an opportunity to learn. I feel pretty sad and rejected and unsure about the immediate future. I am going to gun for this though and try for spring.

I want this so bad and I have told them this. Any advice?

dialogue.statement: Hello! Feel free to share whatever's on your mind today. What's been going on with you lately?
Hey, thanks for asking. I've just been feeling really anxious about starting college so young. It's like I pushed myself so hard to get here, and now I'm not sure I'm ready.

Starting college at a young age can be a big transition, and it's understandable to feel anxious about it. You're feeling this way because you've worked hard to reach this point, and now the uncertainty is weighing on you. What aspects of starting college are causing the most concern for you right now?

client: I think it's mostly not knowing how everything works, like managing classes and finances on my own. Plus, I'm worried about fitting in since I'll be younger than everyone else. It feels like I'm just in way over my head.

Navigating these new responsibilities and social dynamics can indeed feel overwhelming. You might be feeling this way because the shift to more independence and being in a different age group is a big change. What have you found helpful in managing new experiences in the past?

client: Honestly, I usually just try to plan ahead and break things down into smaller tasks. But this feels like a lot to handle all at once, and I'm not sure where to even start with all the college stuff.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively explored the client's anxiety about starting college early, covering her concerns about managing responsibilities and fitting in socially. Rapport has been built through empathetic understanding, and the client's strengths in planning and task management have been acknowledged. The goals and challenges are clear, and there is now a foundation to deepen motivation and evoke Change Talk about coping strategies.

dialogue.statement: It can definitely feel like a lot to manage at once. When you think about planning ahead and breaking tasks down, how might that approach support you in this new college environment?

client: I guess if I take it one step at a time, like focusing on one class or financial thing at a time, it might seem less overwhelming. I just worry that I might miss something important or mess up since this is all new to me.

Those worries are really understandable when you're stepping into something new. As you're considering breaking things down, what small steps do you feel most confident about taking first? And how might aligning these steps with your goals help ease some of those concerns?

client: Well, I think I could start by looking at the syllabi for my classes to get a sense of what's coming. Maybe I can also talk to the financial aid office to understand what I need to do. Taking those first steps might help me feel a bit more in control.

Taking those initial steps sounds like a great way to gain some clarity and control over the situation. By reaching out and gathering information, you're actively working towards reducing uncertainty. How do you feel this approach aligns with your long-term goals for college and beyond?

client: I think it aligns pretty well since being organized and informed is something I'd need in the long run anyway. It'll probably help me feel more settled and less like I'm just winging it. It's just a bit intimidating to think so far ahead when I'm feeling unsure about right now.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a discrepancy between their current feelings of anxiety about starting college and their long-term goal of being organized and informed. They have explored their life with and without change by considering how planning might ease their concerns. The client has identified specific change goals, such as reviewing class syllabi and consulting the financial aid office. This indicates readiness to develop specific action plans. Move to the Choosing phase to collaboratively develop these plans and address anticipated barriers. OARS feedback: Successfully using reflections and open questions helped the client identify actionable steps, fostering confidence for the next phase.

dialogue.statement: Creating a manageable plan can definitely help ease those feelings of uncertainty. As for barriers, I guess I just need to stay on top of deadlines and not let myself get too stressed out by things I don't know yet.

I think having some balance will make it easier to handle everything without feeling too burned out.

Maintaining that balance sounds like a great way to manage everything effectively. By using reminders and giving yourself time to relax, you're setting yourself up for success. statement.reasoning: The client has established a clear goal of attending a financial aid workshop and using reminders to manage stress, indicating a concrete action plan. They have considered barriers such as managing deadlines and stress, and have agreed to self-monitor through reminders and relaxation strategies. The client has also expressed commitment to the plan and confidence in overcoming barriers. Therefore, the client is ready to advance to the Terminating phase. dialogue.statement: It’s wonderful that you're open to reflecting and making adjustments as you go. statement.reasoning: The client has a clear plan with steps and coping strategies. A follow-up plan is agreed upon to reflect and adjust after the workshop, demonstrating readiness to transition. Great use of open questions and affirmations to build confidence.

concern:
title: I'm going to college at 17. And I'm scared af.
I know this sounds a little dramatic lol. I'm 16 (F) currently, and I pushed myself really hard to graduate early. Now I'm here and it just doesn't feel right.

I'll be going to college this fall semester (I'll turn 17 before) and I'm scared shitless. I almost regret moving so fast. It feels like I don't really relate to any of my friends or have any tbh.

I'm also putting myself through college and have almost no clue how this works at all.  Anyone else in the same boat?

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What brings you here today?
I've been feeling pretty lost about my degree and what I should be doing with my life. I've changed majors a couple of times and I'm still not sure if I've found the right fit.

I guess I'm just not excited about the career paths that seem to follow from it. They don't seem to align with what I really want to do, which is work on stuff that genuinely helps people.

client(exploring): I've been thinking that maybe engineering or software development could be a way to create solutions that have a real-world impact. But I'm not entirely sure since I don't have much experience there yet.

concern:
title: I've changed my degree twice now and have no idea if I should keep my current one!! Any advice is helpful 😭
I'm in my last semester of my Associates. I was a Music major which I quickly realized was a mistake I don't really like the formality and composition and you don't really need a degree to play stuff you enjoy. I decided Education would be good I've always loved Mathematics, but as I started to do it I realized I like playing with the formulas and solving the problems more than teaching the concepts to people, so I changed to just Mathematics. Now as I'm looking at possible careers when I (eventually) get my Master's , they just don't really interest me, they seem to deal with more financial things that primarily benefit the private company rather than people. I really want to be able to continuously work on stuff that helps people, I don't want my name on it or anything like that, but I just want to know what I'm doing is benefitting people. So I thought maybe an engineering degree, even software engineering, though I have no knowledge of how that works. Basically, should I stick with what I'm doing? Maybe minor in computer science to give myself an advantage trying to get into a software engineering program? What are my options? If anyone has any info anything is appreciated 🙏

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?
Hey, I'm hanging in there. Just been feeling pretty overwhelmed and burnt out with all the schoolwork. It's like I'm in this cycle every semester where I hit a wall and it's tough to keep going.
That sounds really challenging, feeling overwhelmed by the demands of school can be exhausting. What do you think contributes to this feeling of hitting a wall each semester?
client: I think it's just the constant pressure and workload that piles up. I start off strong, but as the semester goes on, it feels like I'm just drowning in assignments and exams.
It must be tough to feel like you're drowning under the pressure as the semester progresses. What has helped you manage or cope with this kind of stress in the past?

Honestly, taking breaks and trying to get some exercise usually helps a bit. But sometimes it feels like there's not enough time to do anything other than study, so that makes it hard to keep those habits up.

statement.reasoning: The client's story has been effectively elicited, revealing their feelings of burnout and the cycle of pressure each semester. They have shared coping strategies that helped in the past, showing insight into their challenges. Empathy and rapport are evident, and there's a mutual understanding of the client's concerns. It's appropriate to move to the Guiding phase to strengthen motivation for change and explore solutions.

dialogue.statement: Finding time for breaks and exercise seems important to you, yet it feels like a challenge to fit them in. How might your life look different if you were able to consistently incorporate these habits?

I think I'd feel less stressed and maybe even more productive. Like, if I could balance study and downtime better, I wouldn't feel on the edge all the time, and I might actually enjoy what I'm learning more.

Achieving that balance sounds like it could bring a lot of positive changes to your life. On a scale of 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding a way to incorporate more balance into your routine?
Maybe around a 5? I know it's possible, but it just seems hard to make it happen when everything feels so urgent all the time.

Feeling like it's possible, but challenging, is understandable given the urgency of your workload. Moving from a 5 on the confidence scale, what steps have you considered, if any, that could help tip the balance towards more integration of breaks and exercise into your routine?
client(guiding): I've thought about setting specific times for breaks or maybe even scheduling workouts like I do with classes. It just feels like something always comes up and throws me off, though.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear discrepancy between their current behavior and desired goals, and they have explored the potential benefits of change. Change Talk is present, with the client expressing a desire for better balance and considering specific strategies like scheduling breaks. Confidence is currently at a 5, indicating some belief in the possibility of change. Although ambivalence remains, the client is contemplating actionable steps towards change. Move to 'Choosing' to develop specific plans and address barriers. OARS feedback: The reflections and open questions helped the client articulate their concerns and imagine benefits of change. Continue building on specific strategies discussed.

concern:
title: How do you deal with the mid semester blues. I’m finding it harder and harder to study and I notice at this point in every semester this happens and I have failed classes in the past because of this.
I’m taking microbio, chem, stats, and college algebra. I have been keeping up really well and have good grades in all my classes, but I’m feeling really burnt out and don’t know how to reduce this.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What's been going on in your life lately? I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey! I've just been feeling a bit unsure about my PhD path. I don't have that burning passion for my research, and it makes me wonder if I'm on the right track.

It sounds like you're questioning your commitment to your current path because you're not feeling that passionate drive. Can you share more about what initially drew you to this field and how you're feeling about it now?

Well, I was initially drawn to the idea of tackling challenging problems and making a tangible impact. But now, I'm realizing that the pure research aspect isn't as fulfilling for me as I thought it might be.

You're realizing that the research itself isn't as fulfilling as you had hoped, even though you were excited about solving challenging problems and making an impact. What aspects of your work do you find most and least satisfying right now?

Honestly, I really enjoy the problem-solving part and learning new things, but I'm not as enthusiastic about projects that seem too theoretical or abstract. I guess I’m craving something more practical that I can see making a difference in the real world.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their initial motivations for pursuing a PhD and their current feelings of disconnection with the research work. They’ve expressed a desire for more practical application in their work and have clarified their career intentions post-PhD. This exploration has provided a clear understanding of the client's concerns and aspirations, which indicates readiness to guide them in exploring motivations for potential changes or adjustments in their path. Moving forward, reinforcing their strengths and focusing on their desire for impactful work could help in the next phase.

concern:
title: Does it matter that I'm not passionate about my research?
I decided to do a PhD because I wanted a job that would align with my desire to work on impactful, interesting, and challenging problems. 

But at the end of the day, that's about as far as it goes. I have no intention of making my work my life. I intend to go into industry after finishing. A PhD was what I thought was a necessary step to get me where I want to be. 

For reference, I'm in my first year. I enjoy the lab I joined but I've found that they largely work on basic science research whereas I'd prefer a nice balance between application and basic science with a heavier emphasis on application.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What would you like to talk about today?
Hey! I've just been feeling a bit out of place at college. It's like everyone has their group, and I haven't really found mine yet.
Finding a sense of belonging is really important, and it can be tough when it feels like others have already settled in. What has your experience been like so far with trying to connect with others?

client(exploring): I’ve been trying to get involved by joining clubs and going out with different people, but I still feel like I don’t have that close-knit group. It seems like everyone else already has their friendships figured out, and I’m just floating around.

It sounds like you've been making an effort to connect by getting involved in clubs and social activities, yet it still feels like you're on the outside looking in. What emotions come up for you when you think about this situation?

client(exploring): It's mostly a mix of frustration and loneliness. Like, I know I'm doing things to put myself out there, but it's hard not to feel left out when it seems like everyone else has already clicked with each other.

statement.reasoning: The exploring phase effectively elicited the client's story and feelings of frustration and loneliness due to not finding a close group of friends in college. The client has shared their proactive approach of joining clubs and social activities. Empathy and rapport have been established, and understanding of the client's context and emotions has been demonstrated. The goals of the exploring phase have been met, as the client's narrative and emotions are clear, allowing for a transition to the guiding phase to strengthen motivation and evoke Change Talk. Effective reflections and empathy were key strengths in this phase.

dialogue.statement: It seems like you're dealing with a lot of frustration and loneliness, even as you work hard to connect. How do you think having a close-knit group could change your experience at college?

client(guiding): I think it would make me feel more at home and supported here. Having people to rely on and share experiences with seems like it would make everything feel less daunting and more enjoyable.
Feeling at home and supported could really transform your college experience into something more fulfilling. What might be different for you if you found this sense of community you’re looking for?
I'd probably feel more comfortable and confident in my daily life. It would be nice to have that security of knowing there are people who have my back and who I can have fun with regularly.
Finding comfort and confidence through a supportive community sounds incredibly rewarding. What steps do you think you might want to take next to continue pursuing that sense of belonging?

I'm thinking about trying to be more proactive, like maybe reaching out to people more directly or suggesting plans. Maybe even trying new clubs or activities to meet different people and see where I vibe the best.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear desire for change and identified specific steps to pursue a sense of belonging, which indicates a readiness to move forward. The client has articulated the discrepancy between their current feelings of loneliness and their value of having a supportive community. Change Talk is present, specifically in their intention to reach out and try new activities. The focus on potential actions and the reduction in ambivalence suggest readiness to develop a concrete plan.

dialogue.statement: Considering your thoughts on being more proactive, possible options include reaching out more directly to people you’ve met or exploring new clubs that resonate with your interests. Which of these steps would you like to focus on first to help foster that sense of belonging?

client(choosing): I think I might start with reaching out more directly to people I’ve already met. It feels a bit less daunting than starting fresh with new clubs right now, and I’d like to see if I can build on the connections I’ve already made.
Building on your existing connections is a great step and feels manageable for now. How do you plan to reach out, and what might be some ways to make this feel comfortable for you?

client(choosing): I guess I could start by inviting people to grab coffee or study together. Keeping it casual might make it easier for both of us. I think focusing on shared interests or classes could help the conversation flow more naturally too.

That sounds like a thoughtful approach, inviting people for coffee or to study can indeed keep things casual and relaxed. What do you think might be some challenges or barriers you could face in reaching out, and how might you plan to address them?

Maybe I could remind myself that it's okay if not everyone clicks and that it's just part of the process. I’ll try to focus on the fact that reaching out is a step towards finding those meaningful connections I’m looking for.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear goal and action plan to reach out to existing connections, aiming to build a closer support network. They discussed potential barriers like fear of rejection and have strategies to manage these feelings. The client demonstrates commitment and readiness to take proactive steps towards change. We can move to Termination, emphasizing the client's initiative and resilience in facing social challenges while building meaningful connections.

concern:
title: When did everyone find their closest friends in college???
I’m a freshman, and my first semester is almost over but I feel like I still haven’t found “my people”. It feels like everyone I know and everyone around me has a group of close friends already that they do everything together with and I just don’t have that. I have lots of different friends form different groups but I don’t my own group per se. Is this normal??? I’ve joined a lot of clubs and even though I don’t go out every single weekend, I do go out every now and then with my roommate and some friends. It just sucks  everyone have their own group already while I haven’t experienced that whatsoever. Someone please tell me it gets better ahahaha.

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? Is there anything specific on your mind that you’d like to talk about?

Honestly, it's just the way the class is structured and the lack of support from the professor. I felt like I was making progress, but then the midterm hit me hard and I’ve been struggling to get back on track.

It can be really frustrating when the structure and support don't align with your learning needs, especially after feeling like you were making progress. What specific aspects of the class structure or support are impacting you the most right now?

I think it's the way the homework and exams are handled. We don't get any feedback or explanations on what we did wrong, and it feels like we're just expected to know everything without any guidance. Plus, the midterm was brutal, and now I feel stuck.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively explored the client's challenges with their physics class, including issues with class structure, lack of support, and feelings of being stuck after the midterm. concern:
title: Withdrawing vs. Failing Physics (Mechanics)
The grade scale is curved at my community college so that an 88%+ = A, 76%+ = B, 64%+ = C, and so on for the other two grades. I currently have a 63% in the class. I was almost on my way to reaching a B, but FAILED the mid term three weeks ago, along with more than have the class. This is the second time I almost reached a B, only to get dropped back down to a 62%.

I want to be an engineer, but this class is the most draining I have ever taken and my first physics course. I put in many hours of the week into other classes such as General Chemistry I (5 credits) and Calculus II (4 credits) (both which I have borderline Cs in). I dedicate mostly to physics (5 credits).

I’m sure to blame for the strenuous amount of work I attempted to do this semester, but I would like to (stereotypically) put some of it on the  professor. He assigns homework but no explanations are given when not answering the problems correctly, you lose points on your grade after a certain amount of attempts. Mid term was a disaster since we did not have enough time. He does not curve exams or quizzes.

Drop date is April 15th. Advice? Should I just stick with it and try to pull through? I just feel lost and down on myself now. Professor was pretty demeaning other day when he said if we don’t get a B or A in this course, we will really struggle in the next physics class (electricity and magnetism).

dialogue.statement: Hello there! What's on your mind today?
Hey, I've been thinking a lot about this job opportunity I came across. It's making me question if I should stay focused on my current path or explore something new.
That sounds like a significant decision weighing on you. What about this new opportunity is capturing your interest and making you question your current path?
client: Well, mostly it's the pay difference that's grabbing my attention. It's just so much more than I've ever been offered before, and it's making me think about my future and financial stability.

The prospect of better pay is understandably compelling, especially when thinking about your future and financial security. What other aspects of this opportunity or your current path are you considering as you weigh this decision?
I'm considering how much I enjoy teaching and the research I'm doing right now. Being a professor has always been my dream, but this job being remote also offers flexibility that I can't ignore.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has successfully elicited the essence of the client's story, involving the conflict between financial security and career passion. The client has shared thoughts and feelings about both the current role and the new opportunity. Empathy and rapport are evident, and the client has expressed clear considerations and goals related to the decision-making process. It's appropriate to move to the Guiding phase to explore motivations and evoke Change Talk around these options. The use of open questions, affirmations, and reflections has effectively deepened understanding and built a collaborative foundation.

dialogue.statement: Balancing your passion for teaching and research with the allure of better pay and flexibility is a complex decision. What would your life look like if you continued on your current path, and how might it change if you pursued this new opportunity?

If I continued on my current path, I'd probably spend the next few years deeply involved in academia, which is exciting but not particularly lucrative. If I took the new job, I imagine I'd have more financial freedom and flexibility, but I'm unsure how fulfilling it would be long-term without the teaching and research I love.
Imagining those two paths highlights the trade-offs between fulfillment and financial freedom. How do these possibilities align with your core values and goals for your life?

It's tough because my core values have always been centered around education and contributing to my field, which aligns with academia. But financial stability and freedom have become more important to me recently, so I'm feeling torn between my long-term goals and immediate needs.

Finding a balance between your values of education and contribution, and the increasing importance of financial stability can indeed be challenging. As you think about these options, what small steps could you take to explore how both your long-term goals and immediate needs might be met?

I guess I could start by reaching out to someone in the industry to get a better understanding of what the job might entail and whether it could offer any opportunities for teaching or research. Maybe I could also talk to professors who've made similar transitions to see how they managed their priorities.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear discrepancy between their academic values and financial needs, explored the potential outcomes of both career paths, and identified specific steps to gather more information. Change Talk is present with a focus on potential actions, and ambivalence appears to be decreasing. As the client has begun outlining tangible next steps, they seem ready to collaboratively develop a specific action plan. Moving to the Choosing phase will allow for the creation of a plan to manage anticipated barriers and further clarify their commitment.

How about we also consider how you'll monitor your progress? Maybe checking in with yourself at mid-week to see where you are with your goal could be helpful. Checking in mid-week seems like a solid idea. It’d give me a chance to see if I’m on track and adjust if needed. Plus, it might motivate me to keep making progress instead of leaving everything to the last minute.

concern:

I work in biology education research aimed specifically in higher education. The other day I was going through my email and saw a great job opportunity that was posted and that was a remote position. It will pay 10x more than what I am currently getting paid as a TA at my school. I just proposed my dissertation and am now a candidate. I ultimately want to become a professor and continue doing research.

Should I apply for the job?

dialogue.statement: Hello, how are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?
Hey, I'm feeling pretty stressed out. I've been really worried about this upcoming Python exam for my chemical engineering class. It's been tough, and I'm not sure how to prepare for it effectively.

It's understandable to feel stressed about an important exam. You might be feeling overwhelmed because it's challenging to balance studying and other responsibilities. What's been the hardest part for you?

client: Honestly, the hardest part is looking at a piece of code and figuring out what's wrong with it. It's like I just freeze up or can't see the mistakes, even when I think I should know it. Plus, the practice exams don't really help since they're so different from the real ones.

It sounds like you're experiencing some frustration with identifying errors in code, and it's adding to your stress. You might feel stuck because practice exams aren't matching up with what you encounter on the real ones. What strategies have you tried so far to tackle these challenges?

I've tried doing all the homework and going to office hours, but it just doesn't seem to click during the exams. I also make a cheat sheet, but I'm not sure if I'm including the right stuff on it. It's like I can't translate what I've been studying into the actual test.

We've built rapport and empathy, understanding the stress and frustration involved. The client has also expressed their motivation to succeed in the exam to graduate. Your vision of feeling confident and having everything flow during the exam is quite powerful. It's clear how much you want to demonstrate your knowledge effectively. concern:
title: I have an upcoming chemical engineering python exam and I am not sure how to prepare for it 
I am retaking the course as it was so difficult. I do the homework, visit office hours, but still have a hard time doing the exam. It’s an intro class for solving differential equations using Python with Spyder. The exams always consists of solving differential equations and the professor providing screenshots of a code and tells you that you need to find what is wrong with it. He sometimes gives hints in the exam by partially starting the code and letting you complete it. He also provides a practice exam but it is nowhere near similar to the real one, so I don’t get why he does that. I haven’t done code in a long while and I am very frustrated with this course. This is the only course I have left until I graduate but it seems I may fail again for the second time.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! It's nice to have you here. What's on your mind today?

Hey, thanks for seeing me. I'm just really overwhelmed with trying to choose a grad school and the deadline for one of them is tomorrow. It's been stressing me out, and I can't seem to make a decision.

Balancing all those factors sounds like quite a juggling act. You mentioned costs and funding, as well as having friends nearby and other practical considerations like housing and healthcare. Could you tell me more about which of these feels most important to you right now?

client(exploring): I think healthcare is really crucial because of my recent health issues. But I'm also thinking a lot about costs and finding a good support system, like having friends around. It's like they're all important in different ways, you know?

concern:
title: Can someone help me chose a grad school, the deadline for one of them is tomorrow
I’ve been fighting demons these past night trying to come to a decision. I got into these three schools for a masters in mechanical engineering with thesis option. None are offering any money or assistance, this makes sense though since  I’m coming into a spring semester. I would need to take out loans my first semester regardless of where I go and get a part time job. All locations have accommodations for a hobby I have but I would like a friend to be able to hang out with, I’m too lonely in undergrad lol.

Options and some notes: 
University of Florida- cheapest housing and some good possible opportunities for funding later down the line. Also has grad housing which is even cheaper if I manage to get one of those. I also have a chance at maybe getting a teaching position in the chem department as I teach chem at my current undergrad. Has cool labs and research in my concentration of controls and robotics.

University of central Florida- good school and a lot of jobs around the area that have benefits. I have a friend there so I’ll have someone to hangout with for about two semesters before they graduate. Cheapest tuition, housing can be as expensive as Manhattan although there can be plenty of options found.

City college of New York- very good school but they said they do not have a track record of offering assistantships for masters but almost all masters students come out nearly debt free. I’ll be able to live by my Aunty, which covers housing and food, on Long Island but the commute will be very long(~2.5 hour train ride or 1-1.5 hour drive during morning rush). I feel like the commute after working might take too much time from working on my thesis but I don’t really know how much time grad students actually have and I’m sure I’d adapt to it though. There are a lot of part time jobs in New York and CCNY federal work studies( I know other schools offer that as well).

Healthcare is also very very important since I have recently been diagnosed with a few illnesses and need insurance to afford the medicine. This makes getting a job with benefits important if I stay in Florida whereas New York i can apply for Medicaid.

I don’t know which one to choose, I like them all and each have their own cons. I also self toured all schools but it was kind of rushed since my parents was rushing to leave. 

I did apply to some scholarships and fellowships but they are for fall 23 school year. I would appreciate anyone’s help, I know it’s last minute but I just can’t make a set decision.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! It's great to have you here. What's been going on for you lately?
Hey, thanks for having me. Honestly, it's been a struggle doing college stuff. I enjoy my work way more, but college just feels overwhelming and makes me feel awful.
Balancing college and work does sound challenging. You're really enjoying your job, but college seems to be weighing you down. What's been overwhelming about the college experience for you?

client(exploring): It's like, the moment I even think about assignments or exams, my body just reacts negatively. I get this knot in my stomach and feel so drained. It's hard to focus ’cause the stress just takes over.

That sounds really difficult, feeling physically and mentally drained by the thought of assignments and exams. It seems like the stress is impacting your ability to concentrate. Can you share more about what you think might be contributing to this stress?

I've been trying to figure that out too. Maybe it's the pressure to do well after failing last year, or just the workload itself feels like too much. It feels like no matter how hard I try, I'm just stuck in this cycle of stress.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively elicited the client's story, highlighting the stress and physical symptoms associated with college, as well as the enjoyment found in work. The client has shared thoughts and feelings about the pressure to succeed and past failures, establishing relevant context. Empathy and rapport have been established, and mutual understanding of the client's challenges is evident. Thus, the goals of the Exploring phase are met, and it is appropriate to move to the Guiding phase. Utilizing reflections and open questions helped deepen the conversation and recognize the client's strengths. Moving forward, we can focus on strengthening motivation for change and evoking Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: It can be frustrating feeling caught in a cycle like that, especially with past experiences adding pressure. Holding onto the desire to break free from this stress shows a lot of resilience. What do you imagine life might look like if this stress were more manageable?

Honestly, if the stress was under control, I feel like I could actually enjoy learning again, maybe focus better and not feel sick. I'd be able to do my college work without feeling like it's this huge, impossible task hanging over me.
Imagining a future where learning feels enjoyable again and the work doesn't feel overwhelming sounds hopeful. What steps do you think could help you start heading toward that more manageable place?

I guess finding a better balance between work, college, and personal time might help. Maybe learning some stress management techniques or even changing my approach to studying could make a difference.

Finding a balance and exploring new approaches indeed seems like a positive direction. It's encouraging to hear you're considering stress management and study techniques. How confident do you feel, on a scale from 0 to 10, about making these changes to improve your situation?
I’d say I’m probably a 5 right now. I know what I need to do, but actually making those changes seems a bit daunting. It's hard to imagine things being different, but I’m open to trying.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a strong desire for change and is considering concrete strategies like balancing work, college, and personal time, as well as learning stress management techniques. The client has also imagined a future with less stress, indicating a discrepancy between their current state and desired goals. Although the confidence level is at 5, the client is open to trying new approaches. Change Talk is present, and the client has a specific direction in mind, suggesting readiness to move to the Choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: Thinking about the changes you're open to trying, it's great that you're at a 5 on the confidence scale. That’s a solid starting point. Given your thoughts, we could consider setting a goal around finding that balance or identifying stress management strategies. Some possible actions might include setting dedicated study times, exploring relaxation techniques, or scheduling breaks to recharge. What do you feel would be a good first step for you?

client(choosing): Maybe starting with setting dedicated study times could be a good first step. Creating a routine might help manage the workload better. I can also try out some relaxation techniques during breaks to see if that helps with the stress.

Creating a routine with dedicated study times sounds like a solid starting point. It can help in managing your workload and bringing some predictability. You also mentioned trying relaxation techniques during breaks, which could provide some relief from stress. As you set this goal, what potential barriers do you think you might face, and how can we plan to address them together?

Perhaps we could explore options like setting small, rewarding goals for completing study sessions, or finding a study buddy to keep each other on track. What do you think might work best for you in maintaining motivation and accountability?

client(choosing): Having small goals with rewards sounds like a good idea. I think having something to look forward to after study sessions might help me stay on track. A study buddy could also be helpful, as long as they're reliable. Maybe I could try both and see which works better for me.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear goal of managing stress through a structured routine and the use of relaxation techniques. Potential barriers, such as difficulty maintaining the routine due to fatigue, have been discussed, and strategies like setting small goals with rewards and finding a study buddy have been agreed upon to address these barriers. The client is committed to these steps and demonstrates confidence in their ability to implement the change. The goals and the plan are concrete and collaborative, meeting the criteria to move to the Terminating phase.

dialogue.statement: Trying both small rewards and a study buddy sounds like a really practical approach. It allows you to experiment and see what fits best with your needs. Having something to look forward to can be a great motivator, and a reliable study partner could add mutual support. You've set some thoughtful goals for finding balance, managing stress, and enhancing your study approach. As you work on implementing these changes, remember it's okay to adjust your strategy if needed. We'll continue to explore and refine your plan together to support your journey. Keep up your openness to trying new things, and take pride in every step forward you make. Looking forward to hearing how things go in our next session.
Thanks, I’ll try to keep that mindset. I’m hopeful about trying these new strategies, even if they might take some time to get used to. I guess I’ll see how it goes and adjust as needed.

statement.reasoning: The client has outlined steps for managing stress and improving study habits, including setting routines and using rewards or study partners. A next-step plan is discussed, meeting termination goals while maintaining openness to adjustment.

concern:
title: College makes me really unwell/sick
I did bad last year with college, I felt sick all the time and stressed 24/7. I failed the year and have to repeat 2 modules. 

I decided to work full time while doing college and I really enjoy the work, no stress, no sickness no depression

Even the thought of having to do any college work gives me stomach pain, headaches and extreme tiredness 

Any advice on what I can do?

dialogue.statement: Hello! What would you like to talk about today? I'm here to listen and explore anything that's on your mind.
Hey, I've just been feeling pretty down about this whole parents weekend thing. It's hard seeing them fight and I guess I just couldn't handle it anymore.
Parents weekend sounds like it's been really tough for you, especially witnessing your parents fight. What about the situation is most upsetting for you?
I guess it's just that it should be a time to enjoy and connect, but instead, it always feels tense and uncomfortable. I feel like I miss out on having them there because I can't handle the drama.

It sounds like you're missing out on the opportunity to enjoy time with your parents because the tension between them creates discomfort for you. What feelings come up for you when you're in those situations?
client(exploring): Mostly, I just feel anxious and stressed, like I'm always on edge waiting for the next argument to start. It’s like I’m caught in the middle, and that’s really overwhelming.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively explored the client's story, uncovering thoughts and feelings about the parents' weekend. The client has shared the context and their emotional experiences, such as anxiety and stress, demonstrating understanding and rapport. There appears to be a mutual understanding of the client’s struggle and their goal to find relief from stress, suggesting readiness to move to the Guiding phase.

dialogue.statement: Being caught in the middle like that sounds incredibly overwhelming and stressful. If things were different and you could enjoy a peaceful time with your parents, what would that experience look like for you?

I think it would feel more relaxed, like I could just enjoy their company without worrying about what's going to happen next. It would be nice to actually feel like we're all connecting and having fun together.
Imagining a more relaxed and enjoyable time with your parents sounds really appealing. What would it mean for you personally to have that kind of connection and fun with them?

It would mean a lot to me, honestly. I think it would make me feel more at ease and less like I have to walk on eggshells around them. Just being able to be present and enjoy the moment would be such a relief.

Having that sense of ease and presence with your parents sounds so valuable. Considering how important this connection is for you, what small steps do you think could help move towards that kind of experience?

Maybe starting by having separate, calmer visits with each of them and slowly seeing if we can all be together might help. I could also try talking to them about how their fights affect me, though that's still pretty intimidating.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire for change and has begun to identify specific steps, like having separate visits with parents and addressing their arguments. They have articulated how a peaceful experience with their parents aligns with their values of connection and ease, suggesting readiness to plan action steps. The discrepancy between their current situation and desired experience has been explored, and change talk is present. Moving to the Choosing phase is appropriate to develop a concrete plan and tackle anticipated barriers. Enhancing reflections helped deepen the exploration of values, while open questions encouraged the client to identify personal significance and potential steps.

dialogue.statement: Exploring separate, calmer visits as an initial step seems like a thoughtful approach, and talking to them about how you feel might be a courageous next step. Based on what you mentioned, possible options could include setting specific boundaries during visits or finding peaceful activities to share with each of them individually. What do you think could be a good starting point for you?

client(choosing): I think starting with setting some boundaries during visits might be a good way to go. It feels like a manageable step, and hopefully, it can help keep things more peaceful. Plus, choosing activities we all enjoy could make it easier to connect without any drama.

Setting boundaries during visits and choosing enjoyable activities sounds like a practical and positive start. How do you envision setting those boundaries, and what activities come to mind that you might all enjoy together?

client(choosing): I'd probably start by letting them know ahead of time what topics are off-limits, like anything that tends to spark arguments. I'm really interested in roles that involve water, like hydrogeology or hydraulic engineering. I want to work on projects related to water resources, because that's the part of geology that excites me the most.

concern:
title: Asking for perspective (BS with concentration vs just BS General, then go for masters)
Hey guys. I don't post on anything, but I kinda wanted to ask a large amount of people something so that I could get insight. 

First, to explain my situation.  I did not take schooling seriously at first, just sorta wasted time at the library since no one would question what I did there (eat junk food and binge youtube haha). But now I've shaped up, and found something I'm really interested in and passionate about, Geology. My favorite focus is water.

At my school, they offer a General Geology Degree that requires a minor(I've been going for a Creative Writing Minor and that's going perfectly). They also offer a Professional Geology Degree that can focus on Geology or Hydrogeology(what I like).

My main question is, is it worth it to pay more and spend more time in undergrad to get a BS with a concentration or just getting the BS without the concentration, and go for grad school?

I just started taking my schooling seriously and will have a sit down with a Geology advisor (since I haven't really used these services since I was dumb af) later, but wanted to get random strangers opinions just in case someone brings up something I didn't know.

Additionally, how will it look when I'm looking for a job? In Geology, most jobs require a masters, so getting a BS with concentration doesn't seem with it, and I should just go to grad school and pursue a masters in something like that(Hydrogeology, Hydraulic Engineering, etc. I like water a lot haha)

Group work can be really challenging, especially when you're concerned about who you'll be working with. It sounds like you're feeling anxious because you want to ensure everyone contributes equally. How do you usually handle these situations when they come up?

It must be frustrating to feel like you're carrying more of the load than you should. You try to connect with classmates you’re familiar with, but it doesn't always go as planned. How do you feel when you find yourself in that position?
client: It's really stressful, honestly. I feel like I'm stuck trying to keep things together while worrying about my own grades, and it just makes me dread group projects even more.

concern:
title: Professors who let students pick their own groups, why?
I hear that the purpose of group work is about learning to work with others but doesn't choosing your own groups go against it? In 2023 most students don't come to class that often bc you can easily work from home with all the materials on the internet/ recorded lectures/ slides. Most who "work" from home are "slackers", but a big amount of us have found that working from home mostly suits us better. I love my life both personal and academical rn. UNTIL CHOOSE YOUR OWN groups COME. Then I get anxious 4 a week trying to run to those I kinda was friends with but I usually end up in the same group as slackers who never show up at school nor do school from home until the day before or never. If professors chose our groups I feel like it will be evened out. So just wanna know the reason y some proffesors don't bother?

concern:
title: What should I do?
I’m a recent highschool graduate from the class of 22’ I always wanted to go to college and try to further my studies. I lost almost half my highschool education due to covid so getting back into school hasn’t been the easiest thing, in highschool I managed 90s in everything but I never had to pickup a book. I decided to try something different and study a 2 year 4 semester autocad degree, within the first 3 weeks i quickly realized i didn’t care for it so I switched my major to business. My actual major starts next semester and this current semester has 9 weeks left. I’m struggling at every corner even when I apply myself and try to study the material. It’s extremely demotivating when your first college semester is something that isn’t your major, I don’t care to learn any of this because I don’t want to do it. I want to drop out and continue my studies next semester or later on within business. But I don’t see a reason in sitting here learning material and putting in endless hours into something that provides me with almost nothing in return or the only good return being the discovery of something I hate. I go to a fairly cheap community college and financial aid eliminates about half of my overall 2 year tuition which is only 5,600 before aid. My parents keep telling me I’m just lazy, that I dont actually want to do anything except smoke weed and hang out with my girlfriend. Whenever i bring up the idea of a trade or anything else i’m immediately told i’m not cut out for it and that my best option is to sit here and suffer for the next 100 days. Every day is taking such a heavy toll on me just trying to manage to stay afloat everyday and getting through to the night is so difficult right now. I’m not even in classes that are that difficult, but they don’t affect my major and i’m so demotivated to be doing what i’m doing right now. What should I do?

concern:
title: Getting a Master’s Degree
Hi. I’m currently taking BS Interior Design. Halfway through it, I realized I had a passion for humanitarian work. I’m thinking maybe it’s too late to switch programs, and I can just study International Relations (or maybe Social Work) for my Masters. 

But I’m not sure if my undergraduate degree will be qualified for that kind of masters, since it is two very different fields. May I ask if your undergraduate degree matters when educational institutions look at your application for a Master’s Degree?

dialogue.statement: Hi there! What would you like to talk about today? I'm here to listen and support you.
Hey, I've been thinking about whether I should quit my club rugby team. It's been stressing me out because it's taking up so much of my time, and I just don't enjoy it like I used to.
Rugby seems to have been a significant part of your life, but it's currently bringing more stress than joy. What's been different lately, making you feel this way?

client(exploring): Well, this season just feels different. I'm not getting much playing time because there are new players who are better, and I don't really feel connected with the coach. Plus, I miss having time to hang out with friends or just hit the gym.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit sidelined and disconnected, both from your team and your coach, which is understandably tough. Having less time for friends and personal activities like the gym seems to be weighing heavily on you as well. How have you been managing these feelings so far?

client(exploring): Honestly, I've just been trying to push through it, but it's getting harder to stay motivated. I usually just vent to friends or distract myself with other things when I can, but it's not really solving anything.

statement.reasoning: The client's story has been thoroughly explored, revealing their feelings of stress, disconnection, and lack of enjoyment due to the demands of rugby. They expressed concerns about limited playing time, lack of connection with the coach, and their desire for more social and personal time. The client is managing these feelings by venting to friends and using distractions. Empathy and rapport have been established, and mutually agreed goals have emerged, making it appropriate to transition to guiding the client towards motivation for change. OARS feedback: The reflections and summaries helped clarify the client's concerns, and adjusting to include more affirmations could further strengthen confidence.

dialogue.statement: That sounds really challenging, trying to push through without finding a resolution. I hear you're doing your best to cope, but it's not quite helping with the motivation. How do you think your life might change if you decided to step away from rugby?

client(guiding): If I stepped away, I think I'd have a lot more free time to focus on things I actually enjoy, like going to the gym and spending time with friends. It'd probably take a weight off my shoulders, but I'm also worried about what others might think or if I'll regret leaving the team.

It's understandable to have some concerns about how others might perceive your decision and the possibility of regret. You're envisioning more time for activities you enjoy and feeling lighter without the current stress. What would life look like if you stayed with the team?

client(guiding): If I stayed, I'd probably keep feeling stressed and frustrated, trying to juggle everything with rugby taking such a big chunk of my time. I guess I'd be worried that I wouldn't be as happy or satisfied as I could be, and it might just get harder to manage.

It seems like staying on the team might continue to bring stress and frustration, impacting your happiness and satisfaction. On the other hand, leaving could open up time for things you love, even if there's some concern about others' opinions or potential regret. Given these two perspectives, what feels most important to you right now when you think about making this decision?

client(guiding): Right now, I think the most important thing is finding a balance that makes me feel more fulfilled and less stressed. I want to enjoy my college experience, and if quitting rugby helps with that, maybe it's worth considering, even if it's a tough decision.

statement.reasoning: The client has clearly identified a discrepancy between their current rugby commitments and their values of enjoying college life and reducing stress. We've explored life with and without rugby, and the client has articulated a preference for more balance and fulfillment, even acknowledging potential regrets. Confidence levels aren't explicitly stated, but the client is actively considering quitting as a viable option. Change Talk is present, focusing on balance and enjoyment. Given these factors, the client appears ready to move to the Choosing phase to develop specific action plans. OARS feedback: Summarizing and reflecting have helped clarify the client's priorities, but more explicit confidence assessment could strengthen future sessions.

dialogue.statement: Finding a balance that brings fulfillment and reduces stress seems crucial for you. Considering moving away from rugby could be a step towards enjoying your college experience more fully. How about we explore some specific steps you might take to make this decision? Possible options include discussing it with your coach or teammates, testing a reduced commitment, or setting a trial period for yourself. What might be most helpful for you to start with?

client(choosing): Talking to my coach or teammates could be a good start, but I'm not sure how to bring it up without feeling awkward. Maybe I could try cutting back on my commitment first and see how I feel with a bit more free time. A trial period sounds like a decent idea too, just to see if the change makes a difference.

Exploring the idea of reducing your commitment sounds like a thoughtful first step. It allows you to test the waters without making a permanent decision right away. Would setting a specific timeframe for this trial period, like a couple of weeks or a month, help you evaluate its impact? And perhaps planning how you'd approach the conversation with your coach or teammates could ease the awkwardness. What are your thoughts on trying these steps?

client(choosing): Yeah, setting a timeframe, like a month, seems like a smart way to see if cutting back makes a difference. As for talking to my coach or teammates, I guess if I think about what I want to say and just be honest about needing more balance, it might not be as weird. I just hope they understand where I'm coming from.

Therapist(choosing): Setting a month as a trial period sounds like a solid plan, giving you a clear timeframe to assess the impact. Being honest about your need for balance might help your coach and teammates understand your perspective. How do you feel about writing down your thoughts to prepare for that conversation? We can also discuss ways to monitor how you're feeling during this month. What would you find helpful for keeping track of your experiences and any changes in your stress levels?

client(choosing): Writing down my thoughts could definitely help me feel more prepared and less nervous about talking to them. Keeping a journal or just jotting down notes about how I'm feeling each day might be a good way to track any changes in my stress and happiness levels. It'd be nice to have something to look back on at the end of the month and see if things improved.

statement.reasoning: The client has clearly articulated a goal of reducing stress and increasing fulfillment by potentially stepping back from rugby, and has collaboratively developed an action plan. They plan to set a trial period of one month to reduce their rugby commitment, prepare a conversation with their coach, and maintain a journal for self-monitoring. The client has shown readiness by accepting the proposed actions and expressing confidence in executing them. Moving forward, it's important to affirm their proactive approach and support continued reflection on their experiences during the trial period.

dialogue.statement: Using a journal to capture your feelings and observations day by day sounds like a powerful way to reflect on your journey and assess the impact of cutting back on rugby. As you move through this trial period, remember it's okay to adjust your approach based on what you find works best for you. You're showing a lot of courage in prioritizing your well-being. Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll start with jotting down my thoughts and see how things go. I'll let you know if I need more guidance or support.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified and articulated clear coping strategies and a next-step plan, involving a trial period to reduce commitment and prepare for conversations with the coach. Courage and prioritization of well-being were affirmed.

concern:
title: Quitting a sport
I want to quit my club rugby team. I am a sophomore in college, and I am debating on if finishing out the season is worth it.
I played spring semester last year, and this year hasn’t been fun. There are lots of good rookies taking up playing time, and my play isn’t as good as theirs. The coach is also an issue, as I don’t think he’s fit to coach as many people as he does, almost on his own. He doesn’t even speak to me. I love lifting in the gym, and I have had to put that second to rugby, as well as my social life and my part time job. I can only go out once a week with friends, due to practice 4 times a week and work.
Is it a bad look to quit my team to open up more time for a social life and work?

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

Hey, thanks for being here. I'm just feeling really unmotivated with my schoolwork right now, especially since it's my last semester and all my friends are already done with school. It's hard to push through when I'm the only one left.
It sounds like you're feeling a bit isolated and overwhelmed as you navigate your final semester. What has this experience been like for you so far, and how are you coping with these feelings?

client: Yeah, it kinda sucks feeling like I'm the only one still in it, and it's making it hard to focus. I'm trying to get through by just taking things one day at a time, but it's tough when I just don't feel the drive.

It can be really challenging to stay motivated when you feel alone in the process. You're taking it one day at a time, which shows resilience. Can you share more about what's been the hardest part for you during this time?

The hardest part is probably the lack of motivation and not having my friends around for that extra push or support. It’s like, without them, I feel like I'm just dragging myself through each day without a clear reason why.

statement.reasoning: The conversation effectively explored the client's sense of isolation and lack of motivation in their final semester, revealing their struggle without the support of friends. Reflecting on this phase, the open questions and reflections helped build a comprehensive picture of the client's experience.

dialogue.statement: That lack of motivation and support from friends can be tough. You've recognized the importance of having a support system. How do you think finishing school aligns with your long-term goals or the life you envision for yourself?

Honestly, I know in the long run that having my degree will open up more opportunities for me, but right now it just feels so far away and hard to connect to that future. It’s difficult to see past the immediate struggle when I'm in the middle of it.

The immediate struggle can sometimes overshadow the bigger picture. You're acknowledging the future benefits of finishing school, which shows insight. What aspects of that future do you find most exciting or motivating when you picture having your degree?

client(guiding): I guess what excites me most is the idea of finally being able to work in a field I'm passionate about and having more freedom to make decisions about my life. It’s just hard to hold onto that excitement when right now it feels like I’m just trying to survive each day.

client(guiding): Maybe setting small, tangible goals could help, like rewarding myself for completing certain tasks or projects. Also, reminding myself of why I started this journey might keep me connected to that bigger picture.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively evoked a discrepancy between the client's current lack of motivation and their long-term goals of career passion and freedom. dialogue.statement: Setting small, tangible goals and rewarding yourself for accomplishments sounds like a practical way to stay motivated. Let's consider setting a specific goal.
