concern:
title: How the hell do you stay motivated to finish?
It’s my last semester of school and I have absolutely no motivation to finish. We’re only two days into the semester and if it’s already this bad, I can only imagine what it’s going to be like as the semester progresses. It doesn’t help that I am the only one of my friends in school this semester. How do I stay motivated and finish strong? Any advice is appreciated

dialogue.statement: Hello! It looks like you might have something on your mind. What's been going on for you lately?
Hey, yeah, I've just been really anxious ever since I got accepted to college. I've been second guessing if it's even the right choice for me and it's kind of freaking me out.
Starting college is a big step, and it's understandable that you’re feeling anxious and unsure about the decision. What about the situation has been making you second-guess your choice?
client(exploring): I guess it's the fear of the unknown, you know? Like, what if I end up hating it or feeling out of place? It's just a lot to think about.
The uncertainty of starting something new can be overwhelming, especially when there's a fear of not fitting in or not enjoying it. What aspects of college life are you most apprehensive about?

client(exploring): I think it's mainly the social aspect. I'm worried about making friends and fitting in, and then there's also the academic pressure. I'm scared I'll struggle with the workload and end up failing.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared the core of their anxiety regarding college, expressing fears about fitting in socially and managing academic pressures. The therapist has empathized and elicited the client's feelings and concerns, building rapport and understanding. While a mutual goal around addressing these fears is emerging, more exploration could deepen understanding of the client's strengths or past experiences with similar feelings before moving to the Guiding phase.

dialogue.statement: The thought of making new friends and managing academic pressure can indeed be daunting. It sounds like these are weighing heavily on your mind. What's been your experience with making friends or handling challenging situations in the past?

client(exploring): Well, I usually take a while to warm up to new people, so making friends has always been a slow process for me. As for challenging situations, I tend to overthink and stress out a lot, which isn't very helpful.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a comprehensive account of their anxiety about starting college, including fears about social integration and academic pressures. The therapeutic conversation has effectively delved into the client's emotions and previous experiences with similar challenges. Empathy and rapport have been established, and the client's underlying fears and concerns are clearly understood. This provides a solid foundation to begin strengthening motivation for change and evoking Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: It’s understandable that past experiences might influence how you feel about the future. Imagine a scenario where things go well in college—what might that look like for you?

Finding a supportive group of friends and feeling capable in your studies sounds like an ideal college experience. What strengths or past successes do you think might help you in creating this future?

client(guiding): Well, I guess I'm pretty persistent when it comes to things I care about. Once I get over the initial anxiety, I can be pretty driven. I've managed to push through tough spots before, so maybe that will help.

Your persistence and ability to push through tough situations are valuable strengths. How do you see these qualities playing a role in your college journey, especially in building friendships and managing academics?

client(guiding): I think once I get settled, I could use that drive to really put myself out there and meet new people, maybe join some clubs or activities that interest me. And academically, I could try to stay organized and seek help early if I start feeling overwhelmed.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear vision of success in college and has identified strengths like persistence and drive that can aid in achieving these goals. The client has begun to articulate specific strategies, such as joining clubs and seeking help academically, indicating a readiness to explore actionable steps. Change Talk is present, with decreased ambivalence. The phase's goals have been met, and it is appropriate to move to the Choosing phase to develop specific action plans. dialogue.statement: Your plan to engage in clubs and stay organized academically shows great initiative. As you consider your next steps, what specific goals would you like to set for making new friends and handling your coursework? Perhaps joining one club and setting a study schedule could be initial options. How do these sound to you?

client(choosing): Yeah, that sounds like a good plan. Maybe I'll look into clubs related to my major or hobbies to start with. For the study schedule, I could try setting aside specific times each week to keep up with the workload.

Your ideas of joining clubs related to your major or hobbies and establishing a weekly study schedule are excellent starting points. What do you foresee as potential challenges in pursuing these goals, and how might you prepare to address them?

client(choosing): client(choosing): I think the biggest challenge will be staying motivated, especially if I'm feeling anxious or out of place. I guess I could prepare by reminding myself why I chose these goals and maybe setting small, achievable tasks to keep the momentum going.

Staying motivated can indeed be challenging, especially in new environments. Your approach of reminding yourself of your reasons and setting small, achievable tasks is a great strategy. How would you like to track your progress and ensure you stay on course with your goals? Perhaps setting weekly reflections or finding a buddy in your club could be helpful. What are your thoughts on these or any other ideas you have?

Yeah, I think setting aside some time each week to reflect would be helpful, maybe jotting down what went well and what I could improve. Having a buddy from a club sounds great too; it could be motivating and make things feel less daunting.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan involving joining clubs and setting a study schedule. They have identified potential barriers, such as maintaining motivation, and proposed strategies like weekly reflections and finding a buddy. The client has demonstrated commitment to these goals and has accepted and refined action reflections, signaling confidence in their ability to manage the transition to college life. The Choosing phase objectives have been met, and the client appears ready to advance. OARS Feedback: The client's persistence and previous experiences were effectively affirmed, and open questions facilitated the creation of a realistic and personalized plan.

dialogue.statement: Reflecting weekly and noting both successes and areas for improvement will definitely help you stay on track. Connecting with someone from a club as a support buddy is a wonderful idea, making new experiences more enjoyable and less intimidating. As you prepare to start this new chapter, remember your persistence and past resilience. You're equipped with a solid plan and strategies to cope with potential challenges. Stay kind to yourself as you navigate this journey. I'm confident you’ll find those supportive friendships and achieve your academic goals. Remember, I'm here to support you every step of the way. Keep going, you're doing great!
Thank you, I really appreciate all your help and support. I’ll definitely try to keep these strategies in mind as I move forward.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified goals and coping strategies, and a next-step plan has been discussed. They have affirmed their strengths and set up strategies for monitoring progress. OARS feedback: The session effectively used affirmations and reflections to build confidence.

concern:
title: Just got my first acceptance, but now I'm second guessing even wanting to go and riddled with fear.
It all feels so real now. I'm a generally anxious person so I'm sure it may just be that but I'm not even sure I want to go now. I've put in all this hard work and time and now I'm so worried. What if i get through all of this and, by the time I'm there, I'm miserable? Has anyone else felt this way? How did you get over it if so?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It looks like you're here to chat. How can I support you today?
Hey! Thanks for reaching out. I've been having a tough time with test anxiety lately, and it's really starting to affect my performance and confidence.
That sounds really challenging, especially when it's impacting your confidence and performance. Can you share a bit more about what happens when you experience this test anxiety?

client(exploring): Yeah, so when a test is coming up, I start to feel really nervous and my mind just goes blank during the exam. It's like all the studying I did just vanishes from my head, and I can't focus at all.

It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of stress leading up to and during the exams, making it hard to recall what you’ve learned. What sort of thoughts or feelings usually come up for you before and during the test?

client(exploring): Before the test, I start worrying that I’ll forget everything or that I’ll fail, and then during the test, it's like I'm in a fog and just panic. It's like a cycle of negative thoughts that I can't shake off.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed thoughts and emotions around test anxiety and provided context about its origin. There is a clear understanding of the client’s experience, thoughts, and feelings related to their concern. Rapport is being built with empathetic reflections and open questions. The client seems ready to explore their motivation for change and consider potential strategies to overcome the anxiety. Moving to the Guiding phase would allow for eliciting Change Talk about overcoming test anxiety.

dialogue.statement: That cycle you're describing can feel overwhelming, especially with those recurring worries of forgetting or failing. Imagine for a moment if this anxiety wasn't as strong—how might that change your test experience or your confidence?

client(guiding): If the anxiety wasn't so overpowering, I'd probably be able to focus better and actually remember what I've studied. I think I'd feel more confident and maybe even a bit more relaxed going into tests, like I actually have a chance to show what I know.

Visualizing feeling more focused and confident during tests brings a sense of hope, doesn't it? What do you think it might be like to align your test experience with your goals and strengths, if anxiety were less of a barrier?

client(guiding): Yeah, it definitely feels hopeful thinking about it that way. If anxiety wasn't such a big deal, I think I'd be able to tackle tests feeling more prepared and like I had a fair shot at doing well, reflecting what I actually know.

Embracing that hopeful vision can be quite empowering. What aspects of your strengths or past experiences can you draw on to support this positive change in your confidence and preparedness for tests?

I've always been pretty good at organizing my study materials and managing my time, so I think I could use those skills to help me prepare better. Also, there were a few times when I surprised myself by doing well on tests I was really worried about, so maybe remembering those could boost my confidence.

statement.reasoning: The guiding phase has effectively evoked a discrepancy between the client's current experience with test anxiety and their ideal state of confidence and focus. The client has expressed change talk by visualizing improved test experiences and identifying specific strengths (e.g., organizing study materials) that could facilitate this change. There's a hopeful tone, and the client mentioned past successes as confidence boosters. As these elements align with the readiness signals for moving forward, it's appropriate to transition to the Choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: Those are valuable strengths and experiences to build upon. Considering your skills in organization and time management, along with the positive outcomes from past tests, a few possible options could be setting a structured study plan or practicing relaxation techniques before exams. How do you feel about exploring these or other strategies to help manage the anxiety and enhance your test performance?

client(choosing): I think setting up a structured study plan sounds like a great start, and maybe some relaxation techniques could help me calm down before the test. I'm open to trying out different strategies and seeing what works best for me.

Creating a structured study plan and incorporating relaxation techniques both sound like promising steps. How about we work together to set a specific goal for your study plan? Then we can discuss a few relaxation methods you might like to try, such as deep breathing or mindfulness. What do you think would be a manageable goal to start with, and are there any relaxation techniques that interest you?

client(choosing): Setting a manageable goal for my study plan sounds good. Maybe starting with dedicating an hour a day to focused study sessions could be realistic. As for relaxation techniques, I've heard about deep breathing and would like to try that, and maybe some mindfulness exercises too, like short meditations.

Dedicating an hour a day to focused study sessions is a practical goal to begin with, and trying deep breathing alongside mindfulness meditations can be calming techniques to explore. Let's outline an action plan: perhaps you could schedule your study hour at the same time each day to build a routine? For the relaxation methods, you could start with a few minutes of deep breathing before your study session and gradually incorporate short meditations. How does this plan sound to you, and are there any potential barriers you can foresee that we might plan for?

That plan sounds really doable, and I like the idea of having a set routine. I think the biggest barrier might be just sticking to it consistently, especially when I have other assignments or feel too tired. Maybe having a backup plan for those days could help.

statement.reasoning: The client has established a clear goal with a concrete action plan, dedicating an hour a day to focused study sessions and trying relaxation techniques like deep breathing and mindfulness. They also identified potential barriers, such as consistency, and considered having a backup plan. The client showed readiness by accepting the action reflections and expressing commitment to the plan, indicating confidence in executing the strategy. This progress suggests readiness to advance to the Terminating phase, where the focus can be on maintaining and evaluating the action plan's effectiveness. OARS Feedback: The collaborative approach in setting a realistic study routine and exploring relaxation techniques worked well, reinforcing the client's involvement and ownership in their change process.

dialogue.statement: It's great that you're already thinking about staying consistent and having a backup plan for those tougher days. We can definitely incorporate some flexibility into your schedule to accommodate for those times. Perhaps on busier days, even a shorter study session could be just as effective, and maybe a quick two-minute deep breathing exercise could help you stay on track. Remember, it's about progress, not perfection. You're taking important steps towards managing your anxiety and enhancing your performance. I'll be here to support you as you try these strategies, and we can adjust the plan as needed. Let's touch base soon to see how things are going and discuss any adjustments. Keep up the great work!
Thanks, I appreciate your support and help with making these plans. I'll give it a shot and see how it goes, and we'll definitely chat about how it's working out.

statement.reasoning: The session effectively summarized goals and coping strategies, with a clear next-step plan for study habits and relaxation techniques. Client expressed readiness to implement the plan and check in for adjustments. Affirmation and encouragement were well integrated.

dialogue.statement: Hello there! What brings you in today? Feel free to share whatever's on your mind.

concern:
title: Is it normal to be UNDERwhelmed first semester?
Freshman here majoring in Computer Networking. I’m finding that majoring in networking is like comp sci without the majority of programming, or cybersecurity without a lot of the math requirements that major usually requires. 

I’m afraid that i’m not spending enough time in my classes/on assignments. I’m taking 16 credits right now (four classes with two labs) and I’m underwhelmed by the workload. 

My comp sci and math classes are the only classes I really put decent time into. My english class is a composition course, and I only have essays as my grade.

I’m also taking a networking course, but I took this same course last year so I’m familiar with the material. 

Am I not spending enough time? Did I just get lucky this semester? I was told all my life that the college workload was crazy, and being done with all my weekly work by Wednesday makes me feel like I’m doing something wrong

dialogue.statement: Hello! What brings you here today?
Hey, I've just been feeling really overwhelmed with balancing work and school. It feels like I have no time or energy for anything else, and I'm just struggling to keep up with everything.
That sounds really tough, juggling both work and school can be demanding. What has that been like for you day-to-day?

client(exploring): Honestly, it's just exhausting. I feel like I'm constantly running on empty, and by the end of the day, I have nothing left in the tank for homework or even just taking care of myself.

It seems like you're experiencing a lot of fatigue from managing so many responsibilities. You feel drained because balancing work and school leaves you with little energy for anything else. How does this exhaustion affect other areas of your life?
It affects pretty much everything. I'm too tired to hang out with friends or do anything fun, and even simple self-care stuff feels like a chore. It’s like I barely have time to just breathe.

statement.reasoning: The client has provided a comprehensive view of their struggle to balance work and school, detailing how it affects their daily life and energy levels. Their thoughts and feelings about exhaustion and lack of motivation are clearly articulated, and the impact on their personal life is evident. Empathy and rapport have been established, and the client's goals have become clear. Moving to the next phase would allow for strengthening motivation and evoking change talk by exploring potential solutions and supports.

Honestly, it'd be amazing. I'd have energy to meet up with friends, actually enjoy my classes, and not dread every assignment. I'd feel more like myself again instead of just dragging through each day.
The idea of having more energy and feeling more like yourself seems really appealing. What do you think it would take for you to start moving towards that less overwhelmed version of your life?

I think it would help if I could find a way to manage my time better or maybe reduce my workload somehow. But honestly, I don’t even know where to start with that because everything feels like a priority right now.

Finding a way to manage your time or reduce your workload could be a meaningful step. It's understandable that it feels overwhelming when everything seems like a priority. What small changes do you think might make it feel a bit more manageable?

client(guiding): Maybe setting some boundaries with work or finding a way to schedule breaks during the day could help. I think even carving out a little time for myself might make a difference, but I’m not sure how to actually make that happen.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire for change and identified potential strategies, such as setting boundaries and scheduling breaks. While ambivalence remains about implementing these changes, there are clear indicators of readiness, including Change Talk and exploring life without exhaustion. The client has a specific change goal to manage time better, but confidence in taking action is still developing. Moving to the Choosing phase may help in creating concrete plans to overcome barriers. OARS feedback: The exploration effectively identified the client's values and desires, but further confidence building may be needed.

concern:
title: College isn't conducive to those who work full time
I work four days a week, which is full time in my state, and I go to college two days a week (two out of three of my days off). During the week, I still have homework to do, but I work all day and then come home absolutely exhausted. I have no motivation or energy to do said homework and usually wait until the day before to do everything. Taking three classes (a full time schedule) is what is needed to keep my financial aid, and while that's all well and good, I don't know how other people who work even more than I do can do this. I am at work for 8-9hrs each day, and at school for about 5.5hrs each of my two days, plus an online class. I have such a hard time doing school after work because I am so mentally checked out by that point that even getting myself to take a shower can be a struggle. And I have a hard time doing homework after I get home from school because I just spent all day at school. I'm just so over everything. I wanna go back to being five again.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! How are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?
Hey, I'm doing alright. I've just been thinking a lot about graduation and feeling weird about the whole regalia thing for myself, like it makes me uncomfortable or something.

client(exploring): It's just like, I don't really enjoy being the center of attention, and wearing all that stuff feels like I'm putting a spotlight on myself. Plus, it feels kind of unnecessary to spend money on something I won't really use again.
Graduation brings many emotions, and it seems like being in the spotlight and the cost are weighing on you. What other thoughts or feelings come up when you consider the ceremony?
It's a mix of excitement and anxiety, I guess. I'm proud to have reached this point, but the idea of everyone looking at me and making a big deal about it feels overwhelming.

concern:
title: Does anyone else not like the idea of graduation regalia for themselves?
Maybe it's just me, but I don't see the point in spending money on a stole, cords, medallion, or a special tassel just to show off academic accomplishments. I feel embarrassed when they're pointed out, anyway, so I can't imagine willingly wearing that stuff to draw attention to myself.

The weird thing is, I only feel this way when it comes to myself. Seeing other people in their regalia makes me happy and proud of them, so why can't I feel that way for myself?

concern:
title: Paranoid and Concerned Low Income Student
Okay so I’m a low income student and I’ve recently been admitted to an Ivy on a really big scholarship (basically full ride) and I’ve been having concern about my academic performance. My school is a pretty non-competitive school and most of the curriculum we’re taught is pretty much dumbed down to ensure everyone passes and graduates. I’m scared that I won’t be able to handle the curriculum thrown at me at an Ivy because I didn’t have a good foundation from my high school compared to other students. So my questions are: 

1. Are remedial courses included in my scholarship? If I have to take a remedial math course but I can’t afford then what 🥲🥲😳😳😳
2. Are there free college courses anywhere I can take over the summer to supplement my learning? I was thinking about my local community college but I don’t to spend too much since I’m kinda broke😅

Pls help

title: Years and years of school feels like a waste of my youth
I’m 24 year old female. I took a while to do 75 credits of college plus did a 9 month “lds” mission (ew) and took a year off. 

as a philosophy major I’ll graduate and do more schooling. I knew that when I was younger going into it. Now? … I feel like my most reproductive, pretty years of my life will go to finding a way to support myself financially. 

It just kinda feels like a waste of my youth

dialogue.statement: Hi there! I'm glad you're here. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, thanks. I'm just really stressed about this whole college situation. I dropped out and haven't told my family yet, and it's eating me up inside.
That sounds really tough, feeling stressed about how to share this news with your family. What led you to make the decision to drop out?

I just felt like college wasn't for me, you know? I wasn't happy there, and I really want to focus on pursuing an artistic career, which doesn't need a degree anyway. It was a tough call, but in my gut, it felt right.

Pursuing what feels right in your gut can be a powerful motivator. It sounds like you're drawn to your passion for art and the freedom it promises. How do you feel about this new direction, apart from the stress about your family?

Honestly, I'm excited about it. I finally feel like I'm heading towards something I really want to do, but there's still this weight of guilt and worry about my family's reaction. It's like a mix of relief and anxiety.

statement.reasoning: The exploration phase successfully elicited the client's main concerns: stress about revealing their college dropout to family and their goal of pursuing an artistic career, which aligns with their passion. The client has shared significant emotional context and background, and rapport seems established. Moving to the Guiding phase could help explore motivations and barriers around communicating with their family, and develop Change Talk focused on their artistic goals. Continued reflections and affirmations will reinforce the client's confidence and reduce anxiety about future steps.

dialogue.statement: Balancing excitement for your art with concern about your family's reaction is quite a challenging emotional space. What do you envision your life looking like if you embraced this path, staying true to your passion, and moved beyond the current stress?

I picture having a job to support myself while diving into my art, maybe even getting some of my work out there eventually. It feels like a more genuine and fulfilling path, but the fear of disappointing my family keeps bringing me down.

Imagining a fulfilling path where you support yourself and pursue art sounds inspiring. What aspects of this future excite you the most, and how might overcoming the fear of disappointing your family enhance this journey?

client(guiding): I think the idea of actually getting my art out there and having people see it is really exciting. It would feel like I'm living authentically, doing something I truly love. If I could move past the fear of their disappointment, I feel like I'd be able to focus more on growing and enjoying the process without that constant worry hanging over me.

therapist(guiding): Sharing your art and living authentically sounds truly rewarding. How does the thought of focusing on your personal growth and passion, without that lingering worry, align with your long-term life goals?

Honestly, it aligns perfectly. I want my life to be about doing what I love and being true to myself, not just following a path because it's expected of me. Pushing past the worry would let me fully embrace that vision, but it's just hard to let go of the fear of letting my family down.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear discrepancy between their values and current behavior, focusing on pursuing art as a true passion. Change Talk is evident, with specific goals about pursuing art and personal growth despite familial concerns. The client has shown decreased ambivalence, clearly aligning this change with their life goals, although challenged by fear of their family's reaction. Confidence in pursuing this path seems high, inferred from excitement about future possibilities. Given these indicators, it's appropriate to move to the Choosing phase to develop specific action strategies and address barriers like family reactions.

dialogue.statement: Thinking about aligning your life with your true passions and values is powerful. Let's consider how you might move towards this vision. Possible options include setting small steps to share your decision with your family or finding ways to ensure financial stability while pursuing art. What feels like a good first step for you, and how might you handle any challenges that arise?

I guess the first step would be to have an honest conversation with my family about my decision, even though it sounds daunting. It might help to come up with a plan, like showing them how I intend to support myself financially and still pursue my art. Handling their reaction will be tough, but maybe if I'm prepared, it won't feel as overwhelming.

Having an honest conversation with your family seems like a fundamental step. Preparing a plan to show your financial support strategy while pursuing art could help address some of their concerns. How do you envision this conversation unfolding, and what resources or preparations might assist you in feeling more confident during it?

I'm thinking it might be helpful to write down exactly what I want to say, just so I don't lose track or panic in the moment. I could gather some info on potential job opportunities and maybe even some examples of people who've successfully pursued art without a degree. Having that kind of backup might give me more confidence when I talk to them.

Creating a clear outline of what you want to say sounds like a solid plan. Gathering information about job opportunities and examples of others who have succeeded can definitely strengthen your position. How do you feel about setting a timeline for when you want to have this conversation, and would practicing with someone you trust help boost your confidence?

client(choosing): Setting a timeline is probably a good idea, so I don't keep putting it off. Maybe aiming to have the conversation before Christmas could work, to get it out of the way and start fresh in the new year. Practicing with a friend who understands my side of things could definitely help calm my nerves.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan: have an honest conversation with the family, prepare a financial support strategy, and practice with a trusted friend. Barriers such as fear of disappointment and financial dependency have been acknowledged and strategies to manage these concerns are in place. The client exhibits readiness by setting a timeline and acknowledging the importance of practicing for confidence. Confidence in the plan is shown through commitment to a timeline and taking steps to prepare. It is appropriate to move to Terminating to support the client's execution of this plan. OARS feedback: You've shown courage by taking practical steps towards a difficult conversation. Keep leveraging your strengths and supports as you proceed.

dialogue.statement:
That sounds like a thoughtful approach, aiming to have the conversation before Christmas and practicing with a supportive friend. It's wonderful to see you taking proactive steps towards living authentically, aligning with your true passions. As you prepare, remember that your desire to communicate openly with your family shows great courage and respect for both your dreams and their perspectives. 

Consider using visualization techniques to imagine the conversation going positively, and remind yourself of your strengths and resilience. By setting this timeline and preparing thoroughly, you're building a strong foundation for moving forward confidently. You're making progress, and that's worth celebrating.

Feel encouraged to reach out if you need more support or resources as you prepare. You're on a meaningful path, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Thanks, I really appreciate your help and support as I take these steps. I'll definitely try to visualize things going well and lean on those strengths. I'll keep you updated on how things go and reach out if I need more guidance.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear plan and timeline for addressing their family, with strategies to ease the conversation, showing readiness to move forward. They're prepared and have supportive resources in place.

concern:
title: Tell my family now or let them find out I dropped out
I went to college for a month, then dropped out because I didn't like it at all and I wasn't feeling good in there at all. I decided to pursue an artistic career (not requiring a degree) in parallel of a job. It's what I always wanted to do and I tried to tell them so many times, but they wouldn't understand. So I decided to not ask them this time and I just dropped out. Now it's the end of semester and soon they'll find out, it could even be before christmas, but should I tell them anyways before Christmas though ? I just don't feel like keep lying to them and receive all of my gifts for my "hard work" that I didn't even do. The problem is also that they were paying for my rent and helping me financially, so without their help I'm in a complicated situation although I can still find a job easily, since I have some experience.

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? What's on your mind?
Hey, I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed, honestly. I've been wrestling with the idea of switching majors, and it's been stressing me out.
Switching majors is such a significant decision, and it's natural to feel overwhelmed. What has been contributing to this stress for you?
client: It's just this huge uncertainty about my future. I thought I wanted medicine, but now I'm not so sure. I'm worried about falling behind if I switch to something like computer science.

The uncertainty about your future seems to be weighing heavily on you, especially with such a big decision at hand. What are some of the things that drew you to medicine initially, and what attracts you to computer science now?

I was really drawn to medicine because I liked the idea of helping people and making a difference in their lives. But now, with computer science, it feels like there's this whole world of possibilities and new skills to learn, which is exciting but also daunting.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively explored the client's feelings of overwhelm and uncertainty about their major change. The client has shared their initial motivations for choosing medicine and their current interest in computer science, providing context to their dilemma. Empathy and rapport have been established, with the therapist reflecting the client's concerns and inviting further elaboration. Goals have been mutually acknowledged, setting the stage to delve deeper into their motivations and concerns about the potential switch. What worked: The reflections helped to clarify the client's feelings and the open questions encouraged exploration.

dialogue.statement: The desire to help others in medicine and the excitement about new possibilities in computer science both offer unique opportunities. How do you see these paths aligning with your long-term goals and values?

That's part of the problem—I don't have a clear idea of my long-term goals right now. I know I value helping others and learning new things, but figuring out how that fits into a career feels really confusing.

Balancing your values of helping others and learning new things in a career can indeed feel complex. If you imagine your future self in 5 or 10 years, what kind of life and career do you hope to create for yourself?

client(guiding): Honestly, I see myself doing something meaningful, where I feel fulfilled and like I'm making a positive impact. I'd hope to be in a career where I'm continually learning and growing. But it's tough to visualize how that looks exactly.

Imagining a future filled with meaning, fulfillment, and growth is such an inspiring vision. What small steps or experiences might help you explore what fulfills you and allows you to make a positive impact, while also continuing to learn and grow?

client(guiding): Maybe I could try out some introductory coding classes or join clubs related to both fields. Talking to people in both medicine and computer science might give me a better sense of what each path looks like in reality.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a desire for a meaningful and fulfilling career and has identified small steps they can take to explore both fields, such as trying introductory classes and talking to professionals. There is a clear discrepancy between their current path and their values of learning and making an impact. Although they are still unsure about their long-term goals, they are showing motivation to explore options, and their confidence in taking these steps appears to be growing. This indicates readiness to move to the Choosing phase to develop specific action plans. Summarizing worked well, helping to clarify thoughts and progress toward decision-making.

dialogue.statement: Exploring those avenues sounds like a practical approach to gaining clarity. Based on what you've shared, options could include enrolling in a coding class or joining clubs to experience both fields firsthand. Connecting with professionals could also provide valuable insights. How do you feel about setting a short-term goal to explore these steps?

client(choosing): Yeah, I think setting a short-term goal sounds good. I like the idea of taking small steps to see what really clicks for me. Maybe starting with a coding class would give me a feel for computer science, and I can go from there.

Enrolling in a coding class seems like a wonderful start to see how computer science resonates with you. To build on this, how about setting a goal to reach out to one or two professionals in each field for informational interviews? This could complement your experience in the class. What do you think might be the best way to monitor your progress and feelings as you take these steps?

client(choosing): Keeping a journal or note-taking on my thoughts and experiences as I try these things out could be helpful. It'd give me a place to reflect on what I'm learning and how I'm feeling about each path. Plus, it might help me notice any patterns or preferences over time.

That sounds like a fantastic idea—keeping a journal will allow you to track your experiences and insights. By reflecting on your impressions, you might discover patterns that help clarify your direction. Based on what you've mentioned, options include setting aside a few minutes each day or after significant experiences to jot down your thoughts. How does that approach resonate with you, and are there any specific barriers you anticipate in maintaining this habit?

client(choosing): I think that approach sounds pretty doable, and I can definitely see it being helpful. The only barrier might be finding time, especially with schoolwork and other commitments, but I'll try to make it a priority. Maybe setting a specific time each week to write could help me stay consistent.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan to explore both potential career paths and has discussed ways to monitor and reflect on their experiences. They also identified a potential barrier and considered strategies to overcome it. The client shows readiness with commitment to take steps like enrolling in a coding class and setting up informational interviews. The confidence in their ability to manage this process is evident. Moving forward, continue incorporating specific affirmations on the client’s commitment. Overall, the clear plan and insight into potential barriers suggest readiness to move to the terminating phase.

dialogue.statement: Scheduling a regular time each week to reflect and write is a practical strategy to ensure consistency. It's understandable that finding time can be challenging, yet prioritizing this reflection can be quite beneficial in your journey. By making it a part of your routine, you might find it becomes a rewarding habit. As you take these steps, remember that it's okay to adjust your approach as needed. You're doing great work by actively exploring and reflecting on your path. Keep nurturing this curiosity and openness as you move forward. Reach out anytime for support or to share your progress!
Thanks so much! I'll definitely try to squeeze it in and see how it goes. I'll reach out if I need any more guidance.

statement.reasoning: The client has set practical steps, like enrolling in a coding class and journaling, to explore their interests. They have a plan to maintain these habits while balancing commitments. Progress and coping strategies have been well-discussed.

concern:
title: I cannot decide if I truly want to change majors, and feel like it maybe too late.
I just finished my freshman year as a Biology major on Premed track, but part of me dors not really know if I want to continue pursuing medicine. I am considering switching to Computer science, but am unsure if it is too late. I also do not have much experience with coding, and am not the best in the world at math.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! How are you feeling today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
Hey, I'm feeling pretty overwhelmed right now. There's just a lot going on with finishing up school and thinking about what to do over the summer.
It sounds like there's a lot on your plate with school and summer plans. What's been the most challenging part for you lately?
Honestly, it's the constant pressure to keep going and not let myself take a break. I feel like I'm supposed to be doing something productive, even when I'm exhausted.

It must be really tough to feel like you can't pause and catch your breath. You feel pressured because there's an expectation to always be productive, even when you're worn out. What usually helps you cope when you start feeling this way?
client(coping): I usually try to take small breaks like going for a walk or watching something light, but lately, even those feel like I'm just procrastinating on something more important.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has effectively captured the essence of the client's story, including the pressure to be productive and the guilt associated with taking a break. The therapist has successfully built rapport and empathy by acknowledging the client's feelings of exhaustion and stress. The client has shared detailed context about their current situation, including the specifics of their academic workload, job responsibilities, and the dilemma about taking a break. This foundation sets the stage for strengthening motivation for change. OARS feedback: The therapist's reflections and open-ended questions have helped in understanding the client's internal conflict and pressures, which will aid in guiding the conversation towards motivation for change.

dialogue.statement: It seems like you're feeling guilty about needing breaks, even though they’re important for recharging. How do you envision your life if you allowed yourself more room to rest and recharge without the guilt?
client(reflecting): I guess I imagine feeling a lot lighter and less stressed. Maybe I'd be able to enjoy things more and not constantly worry about what I'm supposed to be doing next.
Imagining a life with less stress and more enjoyment sounds appealing. What are some values or goals that might support you in creating more space for relaxation and joy in your daily life?
I think placing more value on my well-being and mental health could really help. I want to remember that taking care of myself is just as important as achieving things.

Recognizing the importance of your well-being and mental health is a powerful step. How might this understanding of self-care influence your choices moving forward, especially in balancing productivity and rest?

I think it would encourage me to give myself permission to not be productive all the time and take breaks when I need them. It might help me make decisions that prioritize my mental health rather than just my accomplishments.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear desire to prioritize mental health and self-care, envisioning a less stressed life with more enjoyment. They recognized the importance of balancing productivity and rest, indicating a shift in values. Change Talk is evident with the client identifying specific goals, such as taking breaks and prioritizing mental health. Although confidence rulers were not explicitly used, the client's statements suggest a reasonable confidence level. The conversation has effectively explored the discrepancy between current behavior and desired values, and the client is motivated to pursue these changes. Moving to the Choosing phase will allow for the development of specific action plans and strategies. Well done in affirming and reflecting the client's values and goals.

dialogue.statement: Embracing the importance of mental health and granting yourself permission to rest is a meaningful goal. What specific steps could you take to integrate more self-care into your routine? Perhaps setting aside time each day for relaxation or identifying activities that truly help you recharge.

client(choosing): Maybe I could set a specific time each day where I step away from work and just do something I enjoy, like reading or drawing. And identifying a few activities that genuinely help me unwind would probably be helpful too.

That sounds like a thoughtful approach. Setting a daily time for enjoyment and identifying activities that help you unwind can be great ways to prioritize self-care. What might be some potential challenges in sticking to this plan, and how could you address them if they arise?

client(choosing): I think the biggest challenge might be the feeling that I'm wasting time when I could be doing something more "productive." If that happens, maybe I could remind myself of the benefits of taking these breaks and how they ultimately support my overall productivity and well-being.

That's a great strategy, reminding yourself of the long-term benefits to counter those feelings of guilt. It shows a lot of insight and commitment to your well-being. How would you like to track your progress and ensure these moments of self-care become a consistent part of your routine?
I might try journaling each day, just jotting down what I did for self-care and how it made me feel. It could help me see the positive impact over time, plus it'll keep me accountable to myself.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a concrete action plan that includes setting aside specific time for self-care activities and journaling to track progress. They have also identified a potential barrier—feeling guilty about not being productive—and devised a strategy to counter it by focusing on the benefits of self-care. The client demonstrates commitment and insight, and their plan aligns with their values of well-being and mental health. The readiness signals such as commitment and confidence are evident. Moving forward, recognizing the progress made and continuing to refine strategies will be beneficial. Thus, it is appropriate to advance to the Terminating phase.

dialogue.statement: Journaling is a wonderful way to track your self-care journey and reflect on its benefits. It's encouraging to hear you’re considering this, as it can really highlight the positive changes and keep you motivated. By noting how you feel, you'll likely see the progress more clearly and remind yourself of the importance of these breaks. Moving forward, setting aside a few minutes each day to write about your experiences can serve as a gentle reminder of your commitment to self-care. Keep trusting in the process and give yourself grace along the way. Remember, each step you take is a step toward a healthier balance. If you ever feel like you need extra support, we can explore additional strategies together. You're doing great, keep up the good work!
Thanks, I appreciate the encouragement. I'll definitely try the journaling and see how it goes. I know there might be some bumps, but I'm hopeful it'll help.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified self-care goals and strategies, like journaling, to balance productivity and rest. A next-step plan is in place to track progress. Ending the session here would be natural. Great use of reflections and affirmations.

concern:
title: super burnt out, but i feel guilty about taking the summer off
hey guys, so i graduate next weekend from my undergrad and as I'm finishing up my finals I'm facing a huge dilemma. This year has been particularly difficult in terms of coursework as I've been writing my thesis, but I've also had a lot going on with my campus job (i work in an office) as someone else quit and left me and one other person with their huge list of responsibilities that has taken up a lot of my time. I feel so miserably burnt out trying to get through the rest of this semester and the idea of applying and interviewing to get a temporary summer job before I start grad school in August sounds like a nightmare. I would love to use this summer as a break before my rigorous grad program that runs all year long for about 3 years, but I also feel guilty about the idea of not having a summer job (I'd get an internship but jfc there are none in my area that will allow anyone who isn't already a grad student in, plus my program will put me into an intership position anyways). My family keeps telling me that they're glad I'll finally have a break but I'm worried about being dead weight, have any of you been in this position before? Am I being overdramatic in one way or another? This might just be the finals stress rotting my brain but I really can't stop worrying about it. Any advice is appreciated :)

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to see you here today. What's on your mind? I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can.
Hey! Thanks for meeting with me. I'm just feeling overwhelmed with school and the credits I still need to pass. It's been tough adjusting, and I don't want to fall behind.
It sounds like school is really weighing on you right now, and it's understandable that adjusting can be challenging. What do you think is contributing most to the feeling of being overwhelmed?
client: I think it's a mix of not knowing the language well and being so far from home. Plus, I just can't seem to shake off this procrastination habit, which makes everything pile up.

Managing school stress while adapting to a new environment and language sounds like a lot to handle, especially when procrastination adds to your plate. How have you managed similar situations in the past?

client(exploring): Honestly, back home, I would usually just power through with support from friends and family. But here, it's like everything is on me, and I don't have the same support system to rely on.

statement.reasoning: The conversation effectively elicited the client's story, revealing their struggle with school due to language barriers, distance from family, and procrastination. The client's feelings and context are well understood. Mutual rapport and empathy have been established. It's appropriate to move to the Guiding phase to evoke Change Talk and strengthen motivation for change. The rapport-building in Exploring was effective, particularly in affirming the client's past reliance on support systems and reflecting their current challenges.

dialogue.statement: It sounds like you're missing the support network you had back home, which helped you manage stress in the past. What would life look like if you found a way to build a new support system here or reduce procrastination?

client(reflecting): I imagine I'd feel a lot more at ease and probably get more done if I had some friends or a group to lean on. Even just having a study buddy might help me stay on track and keep me accountable.

Finding a study buddy or a group to connect with could bring a sense of ease and accountability. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about taking steps to build that support or reduce procrastination?
client(reflecting): I'd say maybe a 5? It feels like a big step, but I know it's probably necessary. It's just a bit daunting to put myself out there and change my habits.

Taking that step to reach out and change habits does seem daunting, yet you're recognizing its importance. What one small step could increase your confidence, even just a little, to move toward building that support system or addressing procrastination?

client(reflecting): Maybe starting by attending a campus event or joining a club could be a good first step. It might help me meet new people and slowly build that support network without too much pressure.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a clear understanding of the discrepancy between their current behavior and desired goals, recognizing the need for a support system and accountability to reduce procrastination. They've identified a specific next step—attending a campus event or joining a club—and demonstrated moderate confidence (rated 5) in taking action. Change Talk is present, and sustain talk has decreased, indicating readiness to move forward. The next phase should focus on developing an action plan to overcome these barriers. Reflecting on what worked, the use of confidence rulers facilitated the identification of small, manageable steps, which appears effective.

dialogue.statement: Attending a campus event or joining a club sounds like a positive and manageable first step toward building connections. As you consider this idea, what specific action could you take in the next week to begin reaching out, and how might you overcome any initial hurdles?

client(choosing): I think I could start by checking out the campus event calendar and picking one event to attend this week. If I feel nervous, maybe I'll bring a classmate or just remind myself that everyone else is probably a bit nervous too when meeting new people.

That's a thoughtful approach, and it's great that you're considering bringing a classmate along or using positive self-talk. As you plan to attend an event, what other strategies might help you keep this momentum going, and how would you like to track your progress or reflect on your experiences?

client(choosing): client(choosing): Maybe I could keep a journal and jot down how I feel after each event or club meeting. That might help me see any progress I'm making and adjust if things aren't working. Plus, I could set small, weekly goals to keep pushing myself forward.

Journaling sounds like a valuable way to reflect on your experiences and observe your progress. Setting small, weekly goals can also help maintain your momentum. Would you like to brainstorm some specific goals for the upcoming weeks, and consider how you’d handle any potential barriers that might arise?

client(choosing): Yeah, that sounds helpful. I think a good goal for the first week could be to attend at least one event and maybe introduce myself to two new people. For potential barriers, I might worry about not knowing what to say, so I could prepare a few conversation starters ahead of time or remind myself that it's okay to be a bit awkward.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear action plan, including attending events and using strategies like bringing a classmate or conversation starters to overcome barriers. They also plan to self-monitor progress through journaling and setting weekly goals. The client exhibits commitment and confidence by proactively addressing potential barriers and taking actionable steps to build a support network. This aligns with the phase goals, suggesting readiness to move to Terminating. OARS feedback: The way you thoughtfully considered potential barriers and designed a reflective journaling practice is impressive. This structured approach will likely support your ongoing progress. Keep leveraging your openness to new experiences, and adjust your strategies as needed.

dialogue.statement: That's a well-thought-out goal, and preparing conversation starters can certainly help ease any initial awkwardness. Introducing yourself to two new people sounds like a practical and achievable target for the first week. It's great that you're ready to embrace a bit of awkwardness as part of the process. As you move forward, remember it's all about progress, not perfection. Keep reflecting on your experiences and adjusting your approach as needed. You're taking meaningful steps toward building that support network, and it's exciting to see you setting these intentions. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need any support or encouragement along the way. Looking forward to hearing about your journey next time!
Thanks, I appreciate the guidance. I'll definitely give these steps a try and see how it goes. I'll let you know how it turns out the next time we talk!

statement.reasoning: The client has identified actionable steps, strategies to overcome potential barriers, and a plan for tracking progress, meeting the goals for termination. The session effectively facilitated self-reflection and empowered the client to take initiative.

concern:
title: How bad is my situation?
Hello everyone,

I am a 1st year master  student (will be 24 yo in 2 months). My 1st year is 60 credits and I only passed 18 credits (2 exams) due to various reasons : mental health, procrastination, being away from my family for the 1st time and in a country where I don't speak the language. How is

I really don't want to quit because I like what I am studying. Has anyone been in the same situation as me? How bad is this? What should I do?

Thank you in advance

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?

Hey, I've been feeling kinda torn. I've been thinking a lot about whether I should try to graduate from my community college this fall or take it slower and graduate in the spring. It's just been a tough decision.

Deciding on the right path can indeed feel challenging. You might be feeling torn because you want to balance moving forward with ensuring you’re ready. What's been influencing your thoughts on each option?

Yeah, it's like a mix of wanting to keep enjoying the college life I have right now and not wanting to rush things, but also feeling like I should be moving on and joining my friends who are already prepping for their next steps. Plus, NYC just sounds like an exciting next chapter.
You're weighing the value of enjoying your current college life against the excitement and pressure to move on to what's next. How do you feel about the idea of joining your friends in New York City?

client(exploring): Honestly, being in NYC sounds amazing and it's kinda motivating. It feels like it’s where I’m supposed to be for the next part of my journey, but it also feels like a big step and a bit intimidating.

statement.reasoning: The client's story has been clearly elicited, with detailed thoughts and context about their feelings toward graduating earlier or later. There's good rapport and understanding of the client's dilemma, particularly regarding the balance of current enjoyment versus future aspirations. The client has shared their motivations, concerns, and enthusiasm for potential changes, indicating readiness to explore motivation further. Moving to Guiding would allow a focus on deepening motivation and evoking change talk around these options.

dialogue.statement: Taking a big step like moving to NYC can bring both excitement and apprehension. On a scale from 0-10, how confident are you in your ability to manage such a transition if you decide to take it?
client(guiding): I'd say maybe a 6 or 7. I feel like I can handle the change, but there's still a part of me that's a bit nervous about everything that comes with it.

Feeling a 6 or 7 in confidence shows you have some belief in your ability to handle the transition, which is great. What aspects of this change do you feel most prepared for, and what parts make you feel a bit nervous?

I feel pretty ready for the excitement and opportunities that come with being in NYC, like making new connections and having different experiences. But I'm nervous about things like finding a place to live and adjusting to a faster-paced lifestyle.

Adjusting to a faster-paced lifestyle and finding a place to live can indeed feel daunting. It's wonderful that you're looking forward to the opportunities and connections NYC offers. How do these feelings align with your long-term goals?

I think being in NYC would really help with my career goals in Journalism or Communications because of all the networking and internship opportunities. But I also want to make sure I’m not burning out or missing out on enjoying the present. So, it aligns, but I want to be sure I'm ready for it.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed both motivation and apprehension about the decision to graduate in fall or spring, with specific thoughts on how each path aligns with their goals. There is a clear evocation of discrepancy between enjoying the present college experience and moving to NYC for career opportunities. Confidence is self-reported between 6-7, and specific concerns about housing and lifestyle have been identified. The client has articulated how the decision aligns with long-term goals. It's appropriate to move to the Choosing phase to collaboratively develop a specific action plan and address anticipated barriers.

dialogue.statement: Your desire to balance your career goals with enjoying the present is understandable and wise. Considering your thoughts and feelings, one option might be to focus on preparing for NYC by gradually building your confidence with smaller steps, while another could be to savor the current college experience and plan for a spring graduation. title: Should I withdraw from my classes?
Long story short... 

I am currently enrolled in a MSW program, but will not be pursuing it any longer. I'm starting an MPH program in the Spring at a different school.

My gut instinct is to just withdraw, but my first thought is not always my best. :) 

What would you do if you were me?

concern:
title: Overwhelmed
I (19TM) am currently in my sophomore year of college. I just started the fall semester and I'm drowning.

Last year I had a decent amount of homework but I never had trouble getting it turned in on time. And I had plenty of time to see my friends, relax, eat, and work on personal projects that interest me. This semester has been different. I have 3+ assignments due every single day, I'm in two art studios that are only worth three credits each, but you have to be in for six hours every week. I've had assignments I had to turn in incomplete because I ran out of time. And it's not for lack of trying, I'm doing homework literally every free second I get between class, meals, and sleep. I don't get enough sleep, I don't eat enough, and I have exactly zero time for personal creative endeavors.

I'm exhausted all the time, I have days where my anxiety gets so bad I burst into tears just from stress, and yet I haven't been able to slow down even a bit. It's this, or drop out. The only way out is through.

I'm writing this post as I wait for my computer to update so that I can finish a writing assignment and a quiz that are both due tonight, and I have some art project stuff that's due in class tomorrow, which means it needs to get done tonight. I'll probably be up late trying to finish it which means I won't get enough sleep again. Tomorrow evening I need to start working on an essay that's due Friday (it's currently Wednesday), and I also have a workbook page due that day. And it doesn't get any better after that. Every class has loaded me down with more assignments than is even remotely reasonable, and I'm only taking four classes because I had to drop one. I was originally taking five, but it quickly became apparent it literally was not going to be possible to complete all five of them and balance all the work. But I'm starting to get worried even four is going to be too much with the ungodly amount of work these professors assign. My dishes have piled high, my laundry has been sitting in my corner unfolded for days, I desperately need a shower, and I have online job training I need to complete at some point. I haven't had even a second to spare for any of it because every second has been dedicated to homework. If I do get a second to breath, I'm so desperate to finally relax and get even a moment to not be working that I cannot summon the will to do chores.

I know that the way I'm living right now is not healthy, but what's the alternative? Stop turning in assignments and fail my classes? Drop out of school? Neither of those are possible for me. As stressful as it is, I love school and one hard semester would never be enough to make me accept failure.

You might suggest I drop another class, but that's not an option either. If I go down to three classes I'll become a part-time student which means I would lose my scholarship. And I can't afford college without it.

There's really not much I can do other than tough it out, I just desperately needed to complain about my situation somewhere. It's been weighing on me for awhile. I would go to therapy, but I don't have time. I've had to postpone doctor's appointments of all kinds, I haven't been able to hangout with friends unless it's study session, and I haven't been able to work on my book that I'm writing or make any new art without sacrificing homework time that invariably ends up hitting my grade in that class. It's currently week 6 of 16 at my university, plus finals week. So I'm not even halfway done and I'm already crippled by how much work I have, and it's not going to slow down anytime soon.

This just really, truly sucks.

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. What's on your mind today?
Hey, thanks for having me. I'm just really stressing about whether or not I should drop out of college. There's just so much pressure and confusion right now.
That sounds really overwhelming, dealing with all that pressure and uncertainty. What’s been contributing to these feelings of stress and confusion for you?

client(exploring): Well, it feels like I'm being pushed into something I'm not even sure I want. Plus, there are all these mixed messages from my family, and it's just really confusing to figure out what I should do.

It seems like you're caught between your own uncertainties and the expectations of your family, which must be quite challenging. What kind of messages are you getting from your family, and how do they affect your thoughts on staying in college?

It feels like my family wants me to go to college because it's what they think is best for me, but they don't really understand what I want. I'm worried about disappointing them, but I'm also scared of making the wrong decision for myself.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a comprehensive narrative including their feelings, thoughts, and the context behind the decision to attend college, revealing the influence of family expectations and financial considerations. The client has expressed a conflict between their desires and familial pressures, and there's mutual understanding of the client's situation. This indicates readiness to advance to Guiding to explore motivations and elicit change talk.

Balancing those possibilities sounds tough. Considering both scenarios—staying in college and choosing a different path—what aspects of each option align with your values and long-term goals?

Honestly, staying in college could align with the idea of stability and having a degree to fall back on, which seems important for future job prospects. On the other hand, exploring work or other paths might align more with my current need for independence and figuring out what I really want without the immediate pressure of school.
Both options hold unique possibilities for your future. Can you share more about what's most important to you right now in terms of stability and independence, and how they might shape your decision?

Right now, I think I really value having the freedom to explore what I truly want without feeling trapped. But then again, having some stability to ensure I won't end up stuck would be comforting. It's hard to figure out which matters more at the moment.

concern:
title: I need advice on dropping out, please help
So my dad just got approved for ssdi, I (18 F) qualify for $900 a month if I'm at least part time enrolled in school. Well, it took my dad a long time to get approved so I thought that once he got approved I could apply to a college and then start getting money pretty quick. Apparently thats not how it works, my dad has to get processed too. Now because no one told me that, (only how he had been accepted after waiting like a year or two already) and I was being pressured to start college for other reasons, I started looking at potential colleges. My grandmother found a pretty nice one and texted me one day to come over to her house and we would look at the school and see how we like it. Well when I got there she already had all the information typed out on the application form for a degree I never wanted in the first place. If it were up to me, I wouldn't have even gone to school in the first place. But it wasn't, I knew how much it meant to my other grandmother (I will be referring to her as Nana). I had already decided that with the "free money" (I say that very lightly lol) and my Nanas eagerness for me to start school, that I would do it, I just wanted to wait a little bit. Well, I thought I had mentioned my unwillingness enough times to stick. I already have a few job offers I could take for the summer this year if I really wanted to. Anyway, I asked my grandmother if I had to do this. She told me I had too. So obviously I thought her and Nana had talked it out and they determined I had to start right away, which was the only reason why I caved in. So I accepted and she called Nana and they paid. When I got home that night, my Nana and Dada (primary caregivers/parental figures) asked me if this is what I wanted. I told them this: "No, but it's something I have to do" referring back to what my grandmother had said previously. Well, here I am a few days later and I just now got off the phone with my Nana who told me she had no idea and that she was never gonna force me to go to college, as well as it would take until the end of the year most likely before I would receive the ssdi benefits and none of which would include money I would have made if I was getting paid as soon as I started school. So now I'm at a crossroads, I never wanted to start school in the first place because I was scared I would give up halfway through or change my mind and switch majors. I wanted to wait and plan everything out and not jump right in. I jumped right into work right after high school and worked myself sick, I didn't wanna repeat that. Tomorrow i think, is the deadline to ask for our money back. I don't wanna be labeled a college dropout. The mere thought of it makes me want to cry tbh. I know that this is mostly my fault for not checking in with both parties. Most of the time they do consult each other about my school so I just assumed they both knew everything. Now I have no idea what to do, I have less than 24 hours to figure out if I drop out and get the money back, or switch majors which will still leave me with the same issue because I have no idea what I want to do. I'm open to hear what literally anyone has to say.

dialogue.statement: Hi there! How are you feeling today? What's been on your mind lately?
Hey. I've been feeling a bit anxious about starting college soon. I'm worried about how people might react to the scars on my arms.
That sounds really tough, and it's understandable to feel anxious about that. What has your experience been like with sharing or hiding your scars in the past?

client: It's been a mixed bag, honestly. Some people have been really understanding or didn't even mention them, but others have reacted in ways that made me feel uncomfortable or judged. It's hard not to worry that it'll be the same in college.

Those mixed reactions must make it challenging to know what to expect. Feeling judged can be really uncomfortable. Can you share more about what helps you when people have been understanding about your scars?

client: Well, when people are understanding, it just feels like they see me for who I am, not just my scars. It helps when they just treat it like it's not a big deal, you know? Like when someone doesn't stare or make a big fuss and just goes on with the conversation. It makes me feel more normal and accepted.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared meaningful insights into their concerns about reactions to their scars, particularly in the context of starting college. They've discussed past experiences and what has helped them feel more accepted. The conversation has established empathy and a preliminary understanding of their perspective. concern:
title: How would you react to a classmate with old self harm scars? I’m scared of how people will treat me in college
I’ve finally committed to stopping self harm for good, and I haven’t done it in a long time, but my scars are going to be with me for life, no matter how much they fade. They are clearly self inflicted. It’s going to be pretty difficult for me to hide them at all times, especially if I end up living in on-campus housing. What would you do if you had a classmate or roommate with old scars like mine? I’m afraid that I’ll attract people who think I’m an easy target or that people will avoid talking to me if they know that I used to self harm. I’ve gotten a lot of negative and extreme reactions to my scars over the years. Some people have made it very clear to me that they think wearing short sleeves is selfish and that I should simply face the consequences of my actions and cover up no matter what in order to spare people the “horror and shock of seeing my arms”. To what extent do you agree with them? Should I just get sleeve tattoos and skin grafts in order to avoid all this mess as soon as I turn 18? Would you be uncomfortable around someone who looks like me? Would you think that I’m a freak or that I’m crazy?

concern:
title: I feel like I screwed myself over freshman year and now I’m panicking.

So going into college I was dead set on majoring in political science. I liked it in college, I want to go into law, it seemed natural. But the more I researched and took classes I didn’t feel like it was worth it. There didn’t seem to be a lot of job security with higher pay like I was looking for, and so I wanted to switch. I really enjoyed my geology classes and it seemed like that was the route to take. But I have always wanted to double major and never even considered just majoring in one thing. So I was going to do polisci and geology.


But still, even after last semester, polisci just didn’t give me good feelings. I took a business class and I loved it. It was difficult but I felt like it was a fun kind of difficult that I felt proud of myself for figuring out over time. I then started thinking, would it be bad if I majored in geology and something business related? I was also looking into computer science as I love computers and such but might be going in over my head. I feel like it’s late in the game and I’m planning on transferring so I don’t want to have to restart as a freshman. 



Is it too late to do this? My biggest concern is transferring, as I really don’t know if switching now would be an option. I’m a sophomore planning on transferring in the fall, but this is making me sick to my stomach.

concern:
title: Torn between getting a business, psychology, or creative computing degree
If you've taken any of these 3 courses before, what advice would you give someone who is choosing between them?

I'm in Creative Computing right now but I have the option to transfer while its still early.
I chose it because it seems like the course that has the most potential for a good job in the future, considering where the world is headed.

However, I find maths and coding a bit challenging. It was our first coding class today and I already felt left behind. Some of my classmates already studied the basics before they went into uni so I felt really dumb.
I know I can learn it as I go along but it just feels really daunting. Like can I really do this for my whole life? 

I used to be interested in taking Psychology or Business but after seeing all the advice online from people who have Psychology and Business degrees... they mostly say that they're "useless" unless you do a Masters or be good at networking. 

Part of me wants to take on the challenge of doing a more difficult degree while another part of me wants to go the more comfortable route. I'm a pretty sociable person and I'm good at writing essays and being creative, that's why I chose creative computing because I thought it would be more creative but the coding part is what I find difficult.

... what do you think?

concern:
title: Graduating soon and worried about repaying loans. Any advice?
I am absolutely terrified to graduate simply because of only having six months to find a job and establish myself before starting repayment. I know federal loans can be based on income, but I also have a huge private loan because of an error with my university’s financial aid office ($30k). I’m going to be graduating with a not so useful environmental biology/zoology degree. The reason why I felt secure in this degree is because I absolutely do plan to go for my Master’s, but I’d really like to take a yearlong break. On top of this, I plan to move out of state (permanently) to attend school for my Master’s since there’s a ton of universities in the state with great programs, and also because this state has way more job opportunities for my degree. A ton more than my home state. 

I’m in my early 20s and I feel like I should have learned how to be an adult by now but I feel everything I’m talking about and my expectations for my future may be immature and naive. Reality is probably going to hit me like a truck.
